DOC.HEAD: Former `Partridge Family' Star Arrested on Drug Charge
DOC.TEXT: Danny Bonaduce, who played the red-headed, wise-cracking Danny on television's ``Partridge Family,'' has been arrested on a charge of buying crack in a housing project, police said Saturday. Bonaduce, 30, a disc jockey at WEGX-FM in Philadelphia since late 1988, was arrested early Friday by Daytona Beach police and spent nearly 12 hours in jail before posting $5,000 bond, dispatcher Claire Smith said. Ms. Smith said Bonaduce was observed by a member of the city's street crime unit allegedly purchasing several crystals of crack, a smokeable form of cocaine. She didn't know when Bonaduce was scheduled to appear in court. Bonaduce played teen-ager Danny Partridge on the ABC series that ran from 1970 to 1974. The show featured Shirley Jones as the head of a family of six children who become a rock 'n' roll band. Telephone calls late Saturday to WEGX went unanswered.

DOC.HEAD: Some in College Group Make it Out of Haiti
DOC.TEXT: A dozen U.S. college students and two of their advisers made it out of Haiti on Saturday, leaving behind 15 colleagues who had trouble traveling to the nation's capital to catch the airplane. The group from Geneva College arrived about 8 p.m. at Greater Pittsburgh International Airport. Those left behind were in a remote section of western Haiti, but they weren't in danger, officials said. Sam Siple, an aide to U.S. Rep. Joe P. Kolter, D-Pa., said the 12 students and two advisers left in Haiti couldn't make it to airport in the capital city of Port-au-Prince from Kuichard, about 120 miles to the west. The only road to the capital was blocked by burning tires in a popular uprising that brought on Saturday's resignation of Haitian ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, Siple said. ``There's no threat to any American civilians at this time,'' Siple said. The group from the Beaver Falls college went to different parts of Haiti to do missionary work, said James Boelkins, the school's vice president for academic affairs. ``None of them have been in danger at any time,'' Boelkins said Saturday. Kolter and school officials worked later Saturday on arranging a charter flight to get the rest of the Geneva contingent out by Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Police Investigate Whites' Attack on Blacks
DOC.TEXT: Five black people going home from a movie were attacked Saturday by at least 20 white people yelling racial slurs, police said. Two black men and three black women were pelted with bottles, beer cans and mud as they drove in a car through a predominately white neighborhood about 1 a.m., Officer Simeon Frost said. The driver had to pull over, and three white men forced the black men to the ground and began to beat them, Frost said. The victims and witnesses reported the whites yelled racial insults and told the blacks to stay out of the neighborhood, Frost said. One victim said about 20 more whites left a party nearby and joined in the attack, spraying the black women with beer, police said. The two black men, ages 18 and 19, suffered minor injuries in the attack, police said. The three black women, ages 17 to 20, were uninjured. All the victims were from Chicago. Police said the neighborhood where the attack occurred is about 75 percent white. There were no arrests.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Separates moved as a0609 on Stewart and as a0547 on Martindell.
DOC.TEXT: Michael Stewart, the former British Foreign Secretary, died Saturday at Charing Cross Hospital after a brief illness, a hospital spokesman said. He was 83. The nature of Stewart's illness was not disclosed. During 1964-70 Stewart served as foreign secretary twice in the Labor government of former Prime Minister Harold Wilson. He also held the position of secretary of state for economic affairs. Stewart was a Labor member of Parliament for 34 years before receiving a life peerage in 1979. He became Lord Stewart of Fulham and moved into the House of Lords, where he remained active until his illness.
DOC.HEAD: Jackson Martindell
DOC.TEXT: Jackson Martindell, the former publisher of Who's Who in America, died Wednesday of cancer. He was 89. Martindell, who was born in Amarillo, Texas, by 1932 had founded Fiduciary Counsel Inc., which advised prominent business families. Over the next two decades, he made a reputation as a banker, financier, consultant and economic adviser. After World War II, Martindell worked as a U.S. government volunteer to help the Yugoslavian government re-establish that nation's economy. In 1948 he married Anne Clark, who later became a New Jersey state senator and U.S. ambassador to New Zealand. In 1956, Martindell became publisher of Marquis' Who's Who of Chicago, which published the annual Who's Who in America. He sold the publication to ITT in 1969 for a sum he described as ``fantastic'' and retired.
DOC.HEAD: Clifton Blue
DOC.TEXT: H. Clifton Blue, a former newspaper editor and publisher and speaker of the North Carolina House of Representatives, died Saturday at a nursing home. He was 79. Blue served nine terms as a state representative from Moore County and was the Speaker of the House during the 1963 General Assembly session. Blue began his career in newspapers in 1932 when he established the weekly paper The Captain in Vass. The paper later consolidated with The Sandhill Citizen. In 1958, he started the weekly Robbins Record in Robbins and continued to publish both papers until he sold them to Park Newspapers in 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Smoke Prompts Emergency Evacuation Of USAir Flight
DOC.TEXT: Smoke from an overheated air conditioner spewed into the cabin of a USAir jetliner Saturday, and the 116 passengers were evacuated down emergency chutes after the plane landed, an airline spokesman said. No one was injured in the evacuation of the Boeing 737 at Baltimore-Washington Airport, said USAir spokesman David Shipley. The flight from Phoenix to Baltimore landed at 9:23 p.m. The crew first had problems when pilot was preparing to land and cockpit instruments failed to indicate the landing gear was in place, Shipley said. The pilot flew by the airport tower and also did backup checks and determined the malfunction was in the monitoring equipment, Shipley said. The smoking air conditioner apparently was unrelated to the first problem, Shipley said.

DOC.HEAD: Said To Be Tired, Mandela Gives Short Speech
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela was described as ``very tired'' on Saturday and gave his shortest speech so far in a three-week tour of African nations that have supported his cause for an end to white rule in South Africa. Mandela, 71, the black nationalist leader released from a South African prison last month, spoke for two minutes and 45 seconds in this provincial capital about 125 miles west of Dar es Salaam, the capital. ``He is very tired and the program ends here,'' said a Tanzanian official who would only identify himself as a representative of the prime minister's office. Morogoro is home to about 2,500 black refugees from South Africa and contains a school and training farm run by the African National Congress. Mandela is deputy president of the ANC, which is fighting to end white domination in South Africa. Mandela, his wife, Winnie, and a number of other ANC leaders arrived in Morogoro in the afternoon, five hours behind schedule. They had come from Iringa, about 155 miles to the southwest. Reporters were not allowed to accompany Mandela and his party to Iringa, which houses at least five military training camps for ANC guerrillas. In his remarks to the refugees at Morogoro, Mandela once again thanked Tanzania for its support of black South Africans. Mandela's tour so far has taken him to Zambia, Zimbabwe, Tanzania and Ethiopia. He is scheduled to speak to the Liberation Committee of the Organization of African Unity in Dar es Salaam on Sunday, then fly to Sweden. Mandela was jailed 27 years on charges of plotting against the South African government. He was freed Feb. 11.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Hearing on Puerto Rican Status; Statehooders March
DOC.TEXT: About 150,000 supporters of statehood knocked down a cardboard ``Wall of Colonialism'' and carried small U.S. flags with 51 stars Saturday, the second day of congressional hearings on the issue. Puerto Rican political and professional leaders told the visiting U.S. congressional panel that the hearings about next year's proposed plebiscite on the island's future status were confusing and undefined. Jose Alberto Morales, president of the University of Sacred Heart, told the panel Puerto Ricans need to know what the hearings will achieve and what to expect from Congress after the consultation process has taken place. In one of the largest pro-statehood demonstrations ever on the island, marchers erected a huge cardboard wall inside the University of Puerto Rico in the Ponce campus. Calling it the ``Wall of Colonialism,'' the marchers knocked it down with their hands. They said ending Puerto Rico's commonwealth relationship, in which Puerto Ricans are U.S. citizens but can't vote for president, and making the island the 51st state would end the vestiges of U.S. colonialism in this hemisphere. The eight-member congressional delegation will wind up Monday in the city of Mayaguez on the proposed June 1991 plebiscite. The hearings are led by the House Interior's Insular and International Affairs Subcommittee, chaired by U.S. Virgin Islands congressional delegate, Ron de Lugo. In the plebiscite, voters would choose whether Puerto Rico, a U.S. commonwealth, will become the 51st state, become independent or have an ``enhanced'' form of commonwealth that would give it more autonomy. The Caribbean island, now home to 3.3 million people, was ceded to the United States by Spain in 1898 after the Spanish-American War.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Sources Say Indonesia Executes Convicted Plotters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Single Indonesian names are cq. throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Diplomatic sources and a human rights activist said the government on Sunday executed six men convicted of taking part in a failed coup attempt 25 years ago. No government officials were immediately available to confirm or deny that the long-delayed death sentences were carried out despite protests by European countries and human rights groups. The six were executed by firing squad, said lawyer Johannes C. Princen, director of the Institute for the Defense of Human Rights. ``According to reliable sources who are always in touch with political prisoners, the six were executed at 5:30 this morning. They were taken out of the Cipinang Prison last Monday,'' Princen told The Associated Press. Western diplomatic sources, who declined to be further identified, confirmed the executions. Four former palace guards convicted in the failed putsch were put to death in mid-February. Armed forces chief of staff Gen. Try Sutrisno told reporters Saturday that the executions of the six had ``to wait for the right time.'' They were an internal matter to be settled by Indonesia and outsiders had no right to meddle, Sutrisno said. In explaining the long delay in carrying out death sentence, Indonesian officials earlier said those marked for the firing squad still had information of value to impart. The six reported executed were identified as Ruslan Widjayasastra, 70, Sukatno, 60, Iskandar Subekti, 67, Asep Suryaman, 62, I. Bungkus, 61, and Marsudi 53. They were convicted of plotting to overthrow the government of the late President Sukarno. Six army generals were killed in the Sept. 30, 1965 uprising which was blamed on the Indonesian Communist Party. The coup was crushed within days by troops loyal to then-Maj. Gen. Suharto, now president of Indonesia. If the executions took place as reported, it was 24 years to the day since Sukarno issued a letter of authority to Suharto to restore law and order in the strife-torn country. The executions were protested last week by Princen's organization, London-based Amnesty International, the 12-nation European Community and the Netherlands. Dutch Premier Ruud Lubbers on Friday offered political asylum in the Netherlands for the six. The Netherlands froze a $12.5 million aid package to its former colony after the February executions, but a $90 million assistance program is continuing. Indonesia, once the Dutch East Indies, gained independence in 1949 after four years of fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers Deciding Whether to Return to Work
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with strikers apparently favoring contract but union leader declaring impasse; EDITS to tighten
DOC.TEXT: Striking teachers voted Saturday on a proposal to return to their classrooms so that negotiators can try again to settle a pay dispute that led to their 3-day-old walkout. Voting teachers appeared to favor the proposal, said Kayetta Meadows, president of the larger of two unions representing the striking teachers. But late Saturday, Meadows accused Gov. Gaston Caperton of reneging on an alleged promise to call a special legislative session to address teacher pay, and she said, ``We have no choice but to continue a statewide strike.'' Caperton said Friday he would recommend that county school boards refrain from docking teachers' pay and benefits for the days they missed so far if they return to work Monday. Teachers from the 16,000-member West Virginia Education Association and the 3,000-member West Virginia Federation of Teachers began voting on the proposal Saturday, and voting was scheduled to continue in some counties Sunday. Union officials refused to release results Saturday. The federation leadership recommended that members vote for the plan, calling it ``a fair and honorable way to end this strike.'' But the federation said teachers in some counties voted not to accept it. Meadows said association members overwhelmingly voted to return to work _ on condition there was no loss of pay or benefits, negotiations would resume immediately and the special legislative session was called. But Caperton said later in the day there would be no special session, and Meadows declared, ``We are at an impasse.'' Caperton spokesman G.C. Morse called Meadow's announcement ``very regrettable.'' ``We did not commit ourselves or close the door to a special session,'' he said. ``This is ludicrous. The strike began Wednesday after a 5 percent pay raise proposal by the governor and legislative leaders collapsed. The WVEA says the average West Virginia teacher salary of $21,904 ranks the state 49th in the nation, ahead of Mississippi.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 80 Sent to Hospitals When Two Buses Crash in California
DOC.NOTE: Eds: NEW throughout with updated injury reports, quotes; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto RO1
DOC.TEXT: Two tour buses collided in a snowstorm Saturday, seriously injuring a driver and sending 85 passengers to hospitals, authorities said. The driver of one of the buses had his right leg amputated and four passengers were admitted to hospitals, but most of the other injuries appeared to be minor, California Highway Patrol and hospital officials said. The accident occurred about 4 p.m. on Interstate 80 about a mile east of here when a Reno Express bus from Hayward, Calif., lost control in snow and an Ernie's Tours bus from Daly City, Calif., hit it head-on, said CHP dispatcher Dick Cunningham. He said two other vehicles were involved, but their occupants escaped serious injury. ``It was pretty scary,'' said Danielle Burger of San Leandro, Calif., a passenger on the bus that lost control. ``Everybody was screaming and panicking. It happened so fast. ``All I remember is we started sliding and we went into a 360-degree turn when the other bus hit us. We were very lucky because it could have been a lot worse.'' Forty-three people were taken to Tahoe Forest Hospital here and another 43 were taken to Washoe Medical Center in Reno. Officials said late Saturday that three people were admitted in satisfactory condition at the Truckee hospital; one was admitted in fair condition at the Reno hospital with fractured ribs. A storm had dropped several inches of snow in the area before the accident, and chains were required on the highway, Cunningham said.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Leadership Meets In Moscow
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party Central Committee met Sunday to fix the agenda for an extraordinary session of the Soviet Parliament, which is expected to annul the party's monopoly on power and elect a vastly more powerful president. The meeting of the ruling party's policy-making body comes the same day the Lithuanian parliament is expected to declare its republic's independence from the Soviet Union. During the closed-door Central Committee meeting, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev could come under fire for Lithuania's independence movement. The republic's Communist party already broke with the national party in Moscow in December. The Central Committee convened at 10 a.m. in the Kremlin, the official Tass news agency said in a brief dispatch. At the top of its agenda were preparations for the session of the Congress of People's Deputies, scheduled to convene Monday, Tass said. Officials reportedly will consider ending party control of the management of almost every factory and institution in the country. In February, party leaders agreed to give up their monopoly on power and compete in a multiparty system. But reformers say the change will be ineffective unless the party also abolishes its committees in plants, farms, army units, courts, police precincts and elsewhere. Sunday's session will also consider a revamped set of party rules, including the election of delegates to a party congress by the rank and file. Previously, party leaders approved the delegates, who in turn confirmed the leaders in a system that preserved the status quo. The Congress meeting that opens Monday is expected to approve the party's proposal for a more powerful presidency, despite growing objections from reformers and outlying republics that the plan would concentrate dictatorial power in Gorbachev's hands. The Soviet news service Interfax said the Central Committee will return to its session to nominate its candidate for president after the Congress passes the appropriate constitutional amendments. Gorbachev is expected to be elected to the post, probably during the coming week.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Fails To Agree On U.S. Peace Plan; Gov't Breakup Possible
DOC.TEXT: Israel's decision-making Inner Cabinet on Sunday failed to reach agreement on U.S. peace proposals, and Vice Premier Shimon Peres said his Labor Party will decide whether to break up the government. Peres, who has vowed to end the coalition with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir unless there was progress in peace efforts, said on Israel radio he viewed the lack of a decision as a rejection. He said he would leave it to the party, which is set to meet Monday, to decide whether to stay in the government. ``It's the end of the (coalition) agreement, which could be the only basis for maintaining the national unity government,'' Peres said. ``We served notice that a lack of vote would be seen as a decision and I see this as a negative decision.'' The Cabinet debated proposals by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III for holding talks in Cairo, Egypt, between Israeli and Palestinian delegations. The Cairo talks would negotiate implementation of an Israeli plan approved by the Cabinet last May 14 for holding elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Palestinian negotiators would be chosen in the balloting to talk with Israel about an interim autonomy plan for the 1.7 million residents of the occupied territories. Baker sought to meet Palestinian demands that an exiled Palestinian and a resident of east Jerusalem to be represented in the initial Cairo talks. U.S. officials said the wording of Baker's plan allowed for Palestinains who worked or had second homes in Jerusalem to be included in the Palestinian negotiating team along with Palestinians who had been deported for anti-Israeli activities. Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc objected, saying this would give symbolic concessions to Palestinian demands that Israel relinquish control of the Arab sector of Jerusalem and recognize the right of return for three million Palestinians living abroad.

DOC.HEAD: Military Denies Coup Plotters Executed in Indonesia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with diplomatic sources and a human rights activist now saying executions didn't take place. TRIMS. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The military denied Sunday that the government had executed six men who took part in a Communist coup attempt 25 years ago. Diplomatic sources and a human rights activist had said earlier Sunday that the six were executed at dawn, despite appeals on their behalf from Amnesty International and the European Community. But when a military spokesman, Brig. Gen. Nurhadi Purwosaputro, denied the report, the sources checked with the prison and issued another statement saying their initial report had been mistaken. Nurhadi said the attorney general alone has the authority to announce when executions are carried out and that he had not done so. Nurhadi confirmed the six men had been removed from the prison, but there was no immediate word on where they were taken or why. He refused to elaborate. The six were identified as Ruslan Widjayasastra, 70, Sukatno, 60, Iskandar Subekti, 67, Asep Suryaman, 62, I. Bungkus, 61, and Marsudi, 53. Ruslan, Sukatno and Iskandar were ranking Communist officials, while Marsudi was a sergeant major in the air force. They were convicted of plotting to overthrow the government of the late President Sukarno. Six army generals were killed in the Sept. 30, 1965 uprising that was blamed on the Indonesian Communist Party. The coup was crushed within days by troops loyal to then-Maj. Gen. Suharto, now president of Indonesia. The planned executions were protested last week by the London-based Amnesty International, the 12-nation European Community, and the Netherlands. Dutch Premier Ruud Lubbers on Friday offered political asylum in the Netherlands for the six men. Indonesia, once the Dutch East Indies, gained independence in 1949 after four years of fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Second Son Gives Up in Slayings of Beverly Hill Couple
DOC.TEXT: The second of two sons charged with killing their millionaire parents at the family's Beverly Hills mansion last year surrendered to authorities early Sunday, police said. Erik Menendez, 19, surrendered to detectives as he stepped off a plane at Los Angeles International Airport, said Beverly Hills Officer Michael Dillard. Menendez reportedly had been playing in a tennis tournament in Israel. Dillard said he did not know where the plane was from and did not have any details of the arrest, which occurred shortly after 1 a.m. Family members had said over the weekend that Erik Menendez would turn himself in to authorities upon his return to the Los Angeles area. His brother, Lyle, 22, was arrested Thursday and was being held without bail pending arraignment on Monday. The brothers are charged with murdering their parents, Jose Menendez, 45, and Mary Louise ``Kitty'' Menendez, 44, who were shot to death Aug. 20 in their $5 million mansion. The sons reported finding the bodies upon returning from a night on the town. The young men are heirs to the $14 million estate of Jose Menendez, a successful executive of a Hollywood video distribution company, Live Entertainment Inc. of Los Angeles. Police have said two killers committed the crime, then picked up ejected shell casings from the .12-gauge shotguns they used before fleeing the scene. The Los Angeles Times reported Saturday that a friend of Lyle Menendez found a spent .12-gauge casing in one of the young man's jackets. Police who served search warrants at a psychologist's office Thursday also have obtained tape recordings, apparently of counseling sessions, which likely will be the subject of a court hearing for their admissibility.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Elects First Non-Communist President of a Soviet Republic
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania on Sunday became the first Soviet republic to elect a non-Communistpresident. The move was the latest in the Baltic republic's drive to secede from the Soviet Union. Lithuanian lawmakers chose Vytautas Landsbergis by a wide margin over Algirdas Brazauskas in the election for the presidency, officially known as the chairmanship of the Presidium of the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet. Landsbergis, a professor of music, is the leader of the Sajudis grassroots movement that has spearheaded Lithuania's independence drive. Brazauskas had already begun talks on secession with the Kremlin, but Sajudis felt it would not be fitting to have a Communist president since the Communists lost their majority in the legislature. Brazauskas also advocated a more gradual approach to secession, whereas Landsbergis wants independence proclaimed immediately. Landsbergis' victory came after deputies grilled him on how he would oversee Lithuania's transition to independence. The vote on secession was expected later Sunday, and deputies said there was little doubt the motion to resurrect Lithuania's 1918 declaration of statehood would pass. Deputies applauded as results were announced showing Landsbergis had won the Lithuanian presidency. He received 91 votes, with 42 against. Brazauskas got 38 votes, with 95 against. Earlier this month, Sajudis-backed candidates won a two-thirds majority in the first contested elections to Lithuania's 141-seat Supreme Soviet, leaving the Communists in the minority. A vote later Sunday to restore Lithuania's indepedence would present Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev with his greatest crisis in five years in power. Lithuania, like the other independence-minded Baltic states of Latvia and Estonia, was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 while under Red Army occupation. The parliament will be asked to reaffirm an act first passed on Feb. 16, 1918, declaring the state independent. Lawmakers already have declared illegal Lithuania's incorporation into the Soviet Union in 1940 under a secret Nazi-Soviet pact. Lawmakers also will be asked to restore the 1938 constitution that was swept away by Josef Stalin's Kremlin in favor of a Soviet-style law. Gorbachev and other Soviet officials have indicated the Kremlin may grudgingly accept Lithuanian secession, at a steep price. Specifically, Gorbachev suggested a bill of $34 billion in hard currency in compensation for factories and other infrastructure built during a half-century of Soviet rule. Lithuanians replied that their bill to the Soviet Union for decades of repression would be higher.

DOC.HEAD: Civilian Team Conducts Unannounced Counterspy Review for Senators
DOC.TEXT: A panel of Washington insiders armed with top-secret security clearances is conducting a major, unannounced review of the nation's espionage laws in a search for better ways to catch and convict spies. Recruited from the private sector by the leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee, the panel members have visited the CIA, FBI, Pentagon and National Security Agency, among others, over the last nine months. CIA Director William Webster, FBI Director William Sessions and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh all have met with members of the group, according to executive branch sources. FBI and CIA spokesmen confirm their agencies have offered information and suggestions, but won't describe them. A Justice source says the department has yet to offer either formal or informal advice. The panel _ which includes former White House, CIA, State and Justice officials and a politically connected baseball team owner _ is working for Sens. David Boren, D-Okla., and William Cohen, R-Maine, chairman and vice chairman, respectively, of the Intelligence Committee. Many of the panel members already had security clearances from service in past administrations. But sources, who spoke only on condition of anonymity, said others received new or updated clearances especially for this project. ``We had to get some fingerprints,'' an intelligence community source said. Cohen said in an interview last week that he and Boren were motivated by ``the decade of the spy and a long series of counterintelligence failures, like Whitworth, the Walkers, Ed Howard, Clyde Lee Conrad _ a string of people who have sold (or been suspected of selling) highly classified information costing us billions of dollars in technology that has been compromised, not to mention some of our human intelligence compromised.'' ``We want to enhance security measures without turning into a Stalinist paranoid state,'' Cohen added. Senate sources said the panel has no chairman, but executive branch officials said Boren's friend, Eli Jacobs, who owns the Baltimore Orioles baseball team, has usually taken the lead. Jacobs, a venture capitalist, served on an arms control advisory group in the Reagan administration, still sits on Defense Department advisory committees and may once have worked for Army counterintelligence. He declined to be interviewed. The others have far more Washington experience. They are: former deputy CIA Director and National Security Agency chief Bobby Ray Inman; former CIA Director Richard Helms; former Carter White House counsel Lloyd Cutler; former Reagan White House counsel Arthur B. Culvahouse Jr.; former ambassador and senior State Department official Seymour Weiss; former Xerox executive, ambassador and Middle East negotiator Sol Linowitz; and former Deputy Secretary of State Warren Christopher. Columbia University Law Professor Harold Edgar, an expert on the application of espionage statutes to leaked government information, is helping write proposals in legislative language. In interviews, Cohen and Inman said greed has emerged as the most common motivation for spies over the last decade. Ideology, they said, had declined among spies even before it came unraveled in the communist world during the last year. To counter that, one source said, the FBI has mentioned its longstanding desire to be able to examine tax and consumer credit records in intelligence investigations before there's full evidence of a crime _ authority it now has only for bank records. ``If a guy goes from a Vega to a Jaguar in a year's time, something's wrong,'' Cohen said. Inman refused to discuss the work of the panel, but said he personally has begun thinking about how to use data that are now unavailable to counterintelligence officials. He suggested that a computer could be given a list of people with access to secrets and the IRS could then ``tell you if there was any significant change, either a bankruptcy or a large gain.'' But he warned against opening tax records merely for ``fishing'' expeditions. Inman also said polygraph tests might be shortened to focus narrowly on contacts with foreign agents _ and then administered randomly among those with the most sensitive jobs. He's also weighing the idea of bounties for family members who report turncoat relatives. But this is early thinking. Cohen said legislative proposals are still about two months away. However, Boren and Cohen already have stolen an arrow from the executive quiver by turning first to prominent private citizens for advice _ a standard weapon of presidents to marshal political support in advance. Cohen is frank to admit that. ``It's always resisted from the executive branch whenever we start talking about changes, so you have to have backup.'' In the government, each spy arrest is at once a success for those who caught the traitor, a failure for those who were fooled in the first place. So too, the Boren-Cohen advisers have divided the intelligence community. At the most cynical, one intelligence official pointed out that the leadership of the Senate committee rotates regularly and said, ``this is an effort to produce a legislative monument to the tenure of Boren and Cohen.'' Another executive branch official, citing the record string of spy convictions in the 1980s, said, ``Our big counterintelligence problem is not new legislation, but new values in society so people won't be so willing to sell out their country.'' But an intelligence community official praised the panel for tackling tough questions. And he added, ``When you consider who they are and the demands on their time, I'm impressed by the amount of time they put in.'' Further, ``the philosophical range on the panel is broad. If they can come up with some consensus maybe we can get some problems looked at seriously without arousing civil liberties concerns.''

DOC.HEAD: Polls Show One in Four Party Lawmakers Want Thatcher to Quit
DOC.TEXT: At least one-quarter of Conservative Party lawmakers surveyed believe Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher should resign before the next election, according to polls published Sunday in three newspapers. The surveys appeared in The Sunday Times of London, The Independent on Sunday and The Mail on Sunday. They were the latest signs of growing discontent with Mrs. Thatcher and her three-term government. The Sunday Times said it questioned 100 Conservative members of Parliament and that 10 said Mrs. Thatcher should resign now. Eighteen believe she should step down just before the next election, which must be held by mid-1992. The newspaper said 59 lawmakers responded that Mrs. Thatcher should remain in office until after the election. The remaining 13 believe it is up to her to decide when to leave politics. Of the 650 members in the House of Commons, 374 belong to the governing Conservative Party. All three newspapers said they questioned lawmakers from all factions of the party. The polls capped a week of national protests against a new system of taxation, under which each adult in a local district must pay the same amount for municipal services. The new ``community charge'' does not take into account a person's income, and community charges vary widely depending on the level of services offered in a local district. The protests turned violent at times and sent jitters through the financial community. The result was a 2{-cent drop in the value of the British pound and lower share prices on the London Stock Exchange. Opposition to the tax, along with rising inflation and 15 percent mortgage interest rates, has helped put the opposition Labor Party as much as 19 points ahead of the Conservatives in recent opinion polls. The Independent said Mrs. Thatcher's grip on the party leadership had weakened substantially since December, when only 10 percent of lawmakers voted against her in the annual leadership review. Mrs. Thatcher defeated little-known legislator Sir Anthony Meyer 314-33 in the vote. The Independent said that of the 171 Conservative lawmakers it sampled, 41 want Mrs. Thatcher to resign before the next election. It said 13 felt that ``maybe'' she should step down, but 113 want her to stay. Four did not respond. The Mail on Sunday approached 146 lawmakers and said 116 replied. Of those, 45 said Mrs. Thatcher should consider stepping down before the next election and 71 said she should not. All three surveys found that former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine was the favorite to replace Mrs. Thatcher. The Mail on Sunday also reported that some lawmakers planned to ask Heseltine to campaign for the party leadership. Heseltine denied the report. He repeated predictions that Mrs. Thatcher will lead the party to victory in the next election.

DOC.HEAD: Counting the Homeless, a Special Effort
DOC.TEXT: An army of federal workers is about to try to make thousands of nearly invisible people part of America. The occasion is the first census of the homeless. Often in sight _ if not always seen _ these people do not exist for purposes of federal aid and representation unless they can be counted. How many are there? Where do they live? What kind of help to they need? To many of the homeless, though, being counted seems likely to make little difference in their lives. ``I don't see nothing I stand to lose or gain,'' said Spencer Cox, a homeless New Yorker. ``It's just useless. What's the point?'' A homeless man in Stamford, Conn., echoed Cox's view. ``What good would it do?'' to cooperate, said the man, who would identify himself only as Bob. Estimates of the number of homeless nationwide have ranged from 250,000 to 3 million in recent years. Counting them _ a task some consider impossible _ will be attempted on the night of March 20-21, less than two weeks before the Census Bureau's official counting day for the rest of the nation. ``It's the first time we've gone out in the street'' to count people, said Cynthia M. Taeuber, who is directing the effort. Advocates for the homeless, local governments and other organizations have been enlisted to help, and most are cooperating, she said. In some cases that assistance is being given ``grudgingly,'' however, since the groups have concerns about whether there will be a complete and accurate count. ``The Bush people are not into taking care of people who need help,'' said Karl Kirman, contacted at the Columbus House shelter in New Haven, Conn. ``And they don't want to know why we need help.'' But Kirman said he would answer the census questions anyway. Simone Baxter, 29, of Hartford, Conn., who said she has been homeless for four months, believes it is important to be counted. ``I don't think the government realizes how many homeless people there are,'' she said. William Barrios, who lives in a shelter for veterans in New York, said people in shelters will be cooperative. ``They get a census every night when they check in,'' he said. ``The homeless people on the streets, they're not going to cooperate. They're druggies and alcoholics looking for their next fix,'' Barrios added. In Washington, Mitch Snyder of the Center for Creative Non-Violence is urging the homeless to snub the Census Bureau. ``You can't count all the people in the streets. Experience quickly teaches the homeless that to be identified as such is to risk harassment ... and abuse,'' Snyder said. In Detroit, Toylce Cheatham is worried about talking to government officials, even though the Census Bureau promises to keep the answers secret. ``They'll tell you it's confidential. But you can get cut off if you say the wrong thing,'' said the 24-year-old Cheatham, who was staying at the Salvation Army's Booth Center. And she wasn't convinced that getting the homeless counted would result in more shelters or other aid anyway. ``That's what they're been going to do. But they're been saying that for umpteen years.'' In Chicago, officials of the Pacific Garden Mission said they will aid census-takers. ``Whether they're aware of it or not, they're being counted,'' said Boyd Sylvester, assistant superintendent of the mission. ``I think it's a great idea,'' said Breon Lucas, 26. ``The government can help people who don't have a job find a place to work and give them something to eat at night.'' Another Chicagoan, Anthony Kunevich, 60, was skeptical: ``They think about the Army and give them raises. They don't think about the poor people, the homeless.'' Because of problems in finding all the homeless, and concerns about worker safety, Taeuber admits that she expects the tally to be conservative. A decade ago census takers went to shelters but did not try and count people living in alleys, under bridges and in parks and similar locations. In the end it won't announce any specific number of homeless, since officials decline to try to define that term. Instead, the bureau simply will report that its special count found so many people in shelters, so many in missions, so many in flophouses, so many walking or sleeping on the streets, and so forth. Beginning at 6 p.m. March 20, census workers will visit public and private emergency shelters, hotels and motels used to shelter the homeless and other hotels costing less than $12 per night. This effort is expected to last until about midnight, covering a period when people are generally settled for the night. Then, from 2 a.m. to 4 a.m. census workers will travel the streets, checking places not intended for habitation but where homeless people may be found. Security can be a problem for workers taking to streets and shelters in the middle of the night, and they will be dispatched in groups of two or three. They have been told to leave any area where problems develop, Taeuber said. Because of safety questions, she explained, the decision was made not to enter abandoned buildings even though people may be sleeping in them. And, she added, ``sleeping persons will not be awakened to answer questions.'' Instead, ``enumerators will estimate as best they can the person's age, sex and race.'' The same goes, she said, ``for persons who are not in a state of mind to answer questions, or who refuse.'' ``We will attempt to ask all persons in shelters and all persons living on streets the basic'' questions, she said, but ``our main effort will be just to get a person counted.'' People living in shelters for abused women, in tents at commercial campgrounds, seeking temporary shelter in local jails and other such institutions will be counted in the regular census on April 1.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Would Include Military in New Procurement Corps
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon should establish an acquisition corps in each of the services to handle its purchases of more than $100 billion in weapons each year, a House subcommittee said Sunday. ``The words `procurement disaster' comes to our lips far too often,'' Rep. Nicholas Mavroules, chairman of Armed Services subcommittee on investigations, said in unveiling draft legislation to change the military's buying practices. The bill envisions an acquisition corps consisting of both military and civilian personnel overseen by the under secretary of defense for acquisition, commonly known as the Pentagon's procurement czar. It also proposes the creation of a Defense Acquisition Management University to conduct research and train a professional procurement corps. The subcommittee said it had found that half of the people who work in Pentagon contracting lack a college education. ``We are dissatisfied with the current acquisition system and committed to developing a more professional acquisition workforce,'' said Rep. Larry J. Hopkins of Kentucky, the ranking Republican on the panel. Mavroules, D-Mass, rejected as a ``non-starter'' recent suggestions that a new acquisition agency separate from the military services be created. ``Talk of such radical changes simply stymies efforts to achieve real change,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Horror Story Began a Year Ago with Mark Kilroy's Disappearance
DOC.TEXT: The ritual slayings of 15 people, including a Texas college student who disappeared a year ago during spring break, have led to books, speeches and warnings, but no verdicts yet. University of Texas student Mark Kilroy vanished early March 14, 1989, while out bar hopping with three friends in this border city. After a monthlong search, his mutilated corpse was found buried at a ranch. Fourteen other victims were unearthed there and at a nearby farm. A drug-smuggling cult allegedly performed the ritual slayings seeking magical protection from the law and rival smugglers. Here's what those involved have to say a year later: _ Helen and James Kilroy of Santa Fe, Texas, say some good has come from the death of their 21-year-old son: They have been warning other young people about the evils of drugs through speaking engagements and the Mark Kilroy Foundation. They also are writing a book. The parents said they haven't read the books already published, including one titled ``Hell Ranch,'' but have heard they sensationalized the killing. ``In our book we intend to tell the true story, and exactly what all went on, how we felt about it all,'' said James Kilroy. _ Bill Huddleston, a Texas A&M junior who accompanied Kilroy to Matamoros, called a news conference Wednesday to urge college students who go out drinking to stay together and check up on each other. ``I feel like I owe it to Mark to get the message out to everyone,'' Huddleston said. He said he'll be skiing in New Mexico this spring break. For those who go across the border, he recommended participation in a voluntary sign-in program Mexican officials have begun. _ Five men arrested in April remain jailed in Matamoros, awaiting verdicts from a state district judge. Three others, including alleged cult ``godmother'' Sara Maria Aldrete Villarreal, were jailed in June after a shoot-out with police in Mexico City. Mexican officials in January reported that one of the three, Omar Orea Ochoa, died of complications from AIDS. Cult ``godfather'' Adolfo de Jesus Constanzo reportedly ordered himself and follower Martin Quintana Rodriguez killed as police closed in on the Mexico City apartment. _ State District Judge Francisco Salvador Perez said the fact that two of the suspects are in Mexico City has slowed paperwork and he could not say when he will reach verdicts. Under Mexican law, he said the defendants in this case are presumed responsible, but have the opportunity to prove themselves innocent. Perez said the greatest punishment any single defendant in the case could receive would be 40 years in prison, the penalty for homicide, the worst crime alleged. One of the seven, a caretaker at the ranch, is charged only with covering up the crime. _ Alex Perez, sheriff in Brownsville just across the Rio Grande, says the gruesome crime still haunts him. ``In my life, I've seen a lot of it, but this was the one that got me not to sleeping at night,'' he said. Experts concluded that the cult practiced a perverted form of the Afro-Cuban religion Palo Mayombe, in which believers use human bones, but don't normally kill people to get them. Police said Constanzo's cult reported inspiration from the 1987 film ``The Believers.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Talent Scout Faces Criticism with Affability
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf pvs, bgng: Untermeyer was, with 2 grafs to ADD background as Texas state representative. Picks up 15th graf pvs, Untermeyer, who. Originally moved in advance March 7 as b0419.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX14 of March 6
DOC.TEXT: Chase Untermeyer says that being George Bush's chief talent scout is ``rather like painting the Golden Gate Bridge.'' ``Once you finish the job, you have to start in at the other end and start painting it again,'' says the 44-year-old White House personnel director and Bush protege. From a crowded office in the West Wing of the White House, Untermeyer and his staff assemble resumes and sort out the winners from the also-rans in the quest for presidential appointments. With White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, the affable Houston-raised and Harvard-trained Untermeyer makes the final recommendations to Bush on 3,500 jobs. Untermayer and his staff also ride herd on Cabinet and agency heads in filling more than 2,000 other political posts. Untermeyer, once a political reporter, said in a recent interview that ``it's sort of a rule of thumb in this business (that) every time you make an appointment you earn nine enemies and one ingrate.'' There also has been some criticism of the speed with which the White House has filled appointments. Last September, Democrats on Capitol Hill accused Bush of operating ``a Swiss-cheese govermnent'' riddled with high-level vacancies. Untermeyer defends the administration's performance, saying that background checks are time-consuming and that the criticism would have been far worse ``if we had slam-dunked people into jobs.'' ``I personally don't mind being the target of a bad news story or two in 1989 if we are spared in 1990 and thereafter a series of news stories about some cretin or boob or otherwise incompetent individual who was named to office by George Bush,'' he told the Heritage Foundation last year. ``You can bet that the folks writing those stories would not say, `On the other hand, the White House in 1989 acted with admirable speed in putting this fine citizen into office,''' said Untermeyer. In the interview, Untermeyer said the opposition turned up the heat on the pace of appointments ``essentially because we had denied the Democrats ... the so-called sleaze issue.'' ``Practically none of our nominees has come under any controversy, whereas that happened all the time under President Reagan.'' However, several Bush nominees to major posts were defeated or forced to withdraw, including John Tower as defense secretary and William Lucas as the Justice Department's civil rights chief. In addition, Fred Bush, the chief fund-raiser for the 1988 Bush campaign but no relation to the president, was rejected as ambassador to Luxembourg after coming under scrutiny for contracts he had received from Reagan's Department of Housing and Urban Development. Untermeyer served as a Navy officer during the Vietnam war. After a stint with the Houston Chronicle, he entered politics and served two terms in the Texas House of Representatives. He became executive assistant to then-Vice President Bush at the outset of the Reagan administration. Later, he spent five years in the Pentagon as a deputy and then assistant secretary of the Navy for manpower and reserves, responsible for recruiting, training, health and other matters for the Navy's 600,000 sailors and 200,000 Marines. Untermeyer, who said he longs to leave personnel work and ``return to a policy rule,'' has stayed off the social circuit, partly to avoid being button-holed by job seekers. He routinely logs 12- to 14-hour days, customarily getting by on four or five hours of sleep a night. At his desk on a recent Sunday afternoon, Untermeyer acknowledged that 1989 had ``its grim points, but it had its upside, too. I also met the woman that I'm now engaged to marry.'' He and Diana C. Kendrick, 27, executive assistant to C. Boyden Gray, the White House counsel, plan an October wedding. ``It was a White House romance. You might say that we met on a Sunday working on paperwork _ which is exactly what's happening now.''

DOC.HEAD: Met Celebrates 50 Years of Texaco
DOC.TEXT: The theme at the Metropolitan Opera was the past and Golden Anniversary nostalgia, but the accent was on youth and the future. In place of its usual Saturday matinee opera, the Met threw a gala concert featuring some of its shining _ and rising _ stars in arias, duets, trios, even a quintet. The occasion was the 50th year of continuous Met radio broadcasts sponsored by Texaco, and the concert was heard by the faithful audience of millions that tunes in each week during the season. What they heard were mostly familiar operatic excerpts made special by some exceptional young American singers. Chief among those was Dawn Upshaw, the soprano who has been staking a claim to many of the roles identified with Kathleen Battle. Miss Upshaw was radiant in an aria from Stravinsky's rarely heard masterpiece ``The Rake's Progress.'' Another highlight was a pair of performances by baritone Thomas Hampson. He rattled off a dazzling rendition of ``Largo al factotum,'' from Rossini's ``Il Barbiere di Siviglia,'' and later showed potential for heavier roles as he joined soprano Carol Vaness in the Act Two duet from Verdi's ``La Traviata.'' Miss Vaness was good in that, but she was downright awesome a short while in the tricky ``Come scoglio,'' the first-act showstopper from Mozart's ``Cosi fan tutte.'' Runs, trills, leaps _ all were letter-perfect. Others who made favorable impressions included recent debutantes Delores Ziegler, in the composer's aria from Strauss' ``Ariadne auf Naxos,'' and Ashley Putnam, whose ringing high C's stood out in the final trio from Gounod's ``Faust.'' There she was joined by Francisco Araiza and Samuel Ramey. Ramey _ who also sounded splendid in an aria from Verdi's ``Ernani'' _ was one of the few superstars on hand for the afternoon. Bass James Morris chimed in with a thoughtfully sung aria from Verdi's ``Don Carlos,'' and tenor Neil Shicoff sobbed his way affectingly through the third-act aria from Puccini's ``Tosca.'' The great German bass Kurl Moll was sort of wasted in a brief scene from Wagner's ``Der Fliegende Hollaender.'' The most entertaining number of the day was the quintet from Rossini's ``Il Barbiere,'' nicely sung and acted by Miss Ziegler, Araiza, Gino Quilico, Renato Capecchi and Ferruccio Furlanetto. The concert opened with artistic director James Levine conducting the overture to Mozart's ``Le Nozze di Figaro,'' the first opera ever broadcast by Texaco, in 1940. Original plans called for Marilyn Horne to appear, but she did not. Another mezzo mainstay of the company, Tatiana Troyanos, withdrew at the last minute because of illness. But, in the end, maybe the shortage of familiar star power was all to the good. It threw the emphasis on the emerging generation of singers on whom those Saturday afternoon broadcasts will depend for years to come.

DOC.HEAD: Clydesdales Taking Their Beer Wagon to California
DOC.TEXT: Anheuser-Busch's trademark Clydesdales are being moved to California as part of a cost-cutting program at the world's largest brewery. Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc. announced Friday that it plans to move its 24-year-old breeding center from suburban St. Louis to a 900-acre facility in Warm Springs, Calif., where the animals will have more room to roam. The huge draft horses, which have pulled the Budweiser beer wagon since 1933, make about 500 promotional appearances around the country each year. There are 74 horses in the company's herd. ``It makes economic sense to manage our breeding and stock management operations at a larger, more rural site,'' said Michael Roarty, Anheuser-Busch's director of marketing. The current breeding center at Grant's Farm, the estate of the late August Busch Jr., grandson of the brewery's founder, is only 75 acres. As part of the move, the breeding herd, which provides less than half of the company's Clydesdales, will be cut in half, Roarty said. Visitors still will be able to see Clydesdales at Grant's Farm and at the brewery's stable in St. Louis, he said. August Busch Jr. started the Clydesdales in 1933 as a present to his father to celebrate the repeal of Prohibition.

DOC.HEAD: Party Votes To Change, Occhetto Re-elected Communist Leader
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Italian Communist Party, the largest in the West, voted Sunday to embark on a new course that is expected to lead to a change in its name and the dropping of the hammer-and-sickle symbol. Party leader Achille Occhetto was re-elected at the extraordinary congress and will preside over the changes. The next party congress, which may not be convened for a year, is expected to approve the details of the Communists' new line. Occhetto had campaigned hard for relaunching the Italian Communist Party, which is the second-biggest political grouping in Italy. It has an estimated 1.4 million members. After the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe, Occhetto argued that Italy's Communists could not ignore the march of history. A new political formation could reverse the decline in party membership and the steady slip in electoral strength, he said. If the new party moves closer to the mainstream of European socialism, Occhetto has argued, it could help unite Italy's political left and forge a viable alternative to the Christian Democrats. The Christian Democrats and their allies have dominated every Italian government since the end of World War II. Occhetto supports the Communist Party becoming a new grouping of leftist forces representing the workers, the poor, the weak and the disenfranchised. His motion to eventually change the party's name and symbol was supported by 726 delegates in balloting Sunday. That represented 67 percent of the ballots. A motion to reject major reforms received just 37 votes, or 3 percent. Central Committee members elected Sunday morning met for the first time and re-elected Occhetto as party secretary. The vote was 213 in favor and 23 against, with 71 abstaining and five blank ballots. The Communists nearly came to power in 1976 when they won 34 percent of the vote, but they dropped to about 27 percent in the last parliamentary elections in 1987. For many Communists in Bologna, Occhetto's proposals seemed to be merely a formal recognition of how the party has already changed. The party has long proclaimed its independence from Moscow, supporting Western parliamentary democracy and even Italy's membership in NATO. It has seen itself as a critic of international communism: it condemned the Soviet interventions in Czechoslovakia in 1968 and Afghanistan in 1979, and the bloody Chinese crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators last year. Still, Old Guard Communists rebelled against Occhetto's proposal. They favored reform but fought against changes that would mean a new name or elimination of the party symbols. The differences appeared to vanish Saturday when, after making an impassioned plea for unity in his final address, a tearful Occhetto was embraced on the platform by Pietro Ingrao, another respected old lion of the party. Now Occhetto must design the shape and politics of the new party. He has pledged that the party's new identity will be chosen through a free and open debate and then presented to the next party congress.

DOC.HEAD: Pinochet Keeps Grip on Army, His Base of Power
With AM-Chile, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Augusto Pinochet is giving up the presidency but not his control of the 60,000-man army, the muscle in his long authoritarian rule. If anything, he plans to keep flexing it. ``I was ready, and always will be, to take on the enemies of liberty and of democracy,'' Pinochet said in his farewell speech to the nation, delivered in dress military uniform Friday night. A 10-year-old constitution written by his government gives the armed forces a powerful role as watchdogs over institutional order. In speech after speech before stepping down, he promised to wield that authority. From his new army commander's office, which is directly across Santiago's main boulevard from the presidential palace, he will be able to literally keep watch over the new leadership. Pinochet's constitution also bars any new president from replacing him as commander for eight more years _ twice the term of new President Patricio Aylwin, who took office Sunday. After winning election in December, Aylwin asked Pinochet to retire from the army when the change in government took place. The general refused. Aylwin contends that Pinochet has come to represent hate and division among Chileans, and that his presence in any position of power is an obstacle to national reconciliation. Pinochet told Aylwin that, with him at the army's lead, Chile's political transition is more secure. On Sunday, Aylwin said of Pinochet, ``I hope he will limit himself to the functions of a chief commander, and will not try to interfere with the political progress of the state.'' But Pinochet frequently has indicated that he sees himself as much more than just a military functionary. He has said that, on matters of importance, he will not answer to the minister of defense but deal only directly with Aylwin. The ranks of the army, by far the most powerful military branch, are believed to be solidly behind Pinochet. Traditionally a well-disciplined force, it has receieved unprecendented benefits during his rule. These include higher pay, healthy pension programs, good housing and more and better weapons and training. During his final weeks in power, Pinochet pushed through legislation that trimmed Aylwin's authority and made the military virtually autonomous. One law, which has the weight of a constitutional amendment, bars the new government from cutting defense spending. It also gives the armed forces the power to conduct any business, including weapons purchases and sales, without presidential approval. The military's main concern at the moment is preventing trials of officers for human rights violations that occurred after Pinochet seized power in a bloody 1973 coup. Leftist parties and human rights activists are demanding vigorous prosecution, but Pinochet has declared he won't stand for it. Unlike many Latin American countries, where the end of military rule was hastened by economic bungling and social upheaval, Chile's armed forces are returning to the barracks intensely proud of their administration. They leave a stable, productive ecomony with one of Latin America's lowest inflation rates. On more than one occasion, Pinochet has predicted that Chile some day will miss his law-and-order government. He also has cited the case of Cincinnatus, a Roman military ruler who, after retiring to till the soil, was called back because of growing disorder.

DOC.HEAD: Amusement Parks Squabble Over `World's Tallest Roller Coaster' Claim
DOC.TEXT: Texas Giant has taken on Hercules, but the title of ``world's tallest wooden roller coaster'' may wind up being settled in the courts instead of on the tracks. The Texas Giant ride had barely completed its test runs before it drew threats of a lawsuit from an Allentown, Pa., amusement park that claims it has the tallest wooden roller coaster. Whether the new attraction at Six Flags Over Texas or the Hercules at Dorney Park & Wildwater Kingdom has the right to the title is a bit confusing. There is no certifying agency and no universally correct way to measure a roller coaster. Texas Giant has the highest first hill, at 143 feet. Six Flags officials measure the ride from the loading station to the top of the first hill, or lift. Hercules sports a lift of only 100 feet. But the Allentown Park says the correct way to size up a roller coaster is by the length of its vertical drop. Hercules riders wind up 157 feet lower than the height to which they are towed. The Texas Giant's vertical drop is 137 feet. Dorney Park spokesman Harry Schmerling said the park plans to protest the Texas Giant's claim as being false and to defend Hercules' reputation as being No. 1. He said attorneys representing his park are continuing to ``actively study'' the legal aspects of the roller coaster tussle. ``It's a major difference between being the world's tallest wooden roller coaster and not being the world's tallest wooden roller coaster,'' Schmerling said. The Arlington Convention and Visitors Bureau already is circulating materials promoting the new attraction in the Dallas-Fort Worth area as being the world's tallest. Sandy LaPlant said her agency won't change those materials unless ordered to do so by Six Flags management. At any rate, the new roller coaster is an eye-opener. Or an eye-closer, for those who find their courage quickly waning as the cars creep toward the summit. Randy Geisler, president of the American Coaster Enthusiasts club in St. Paul, Minn., hasn't taken sides, but he does plan to take a spot in line. His group plans to hold its annual convention in Arlington in June, and more than 400 members are ready to test the Texas Giant, tallest or not.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Sperm Bank Faces Second Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: The sperm bank accused in an alleged racial mix-up faces a separate lawsuit by a couple alleging it threw away the sperm of a man about to undergo treatment for testicular cancer, according to a published report. Idant Laboratories was sued by Gasper and Catherine Mastrobuoni last year after the sperm was thrown out because of a billing mix-up, the Daily News reported in its Sunday editions. ``I was devastated when I found out they destroyed my husband's sperm,'' Mrs. Mastrobuoni told the News. ``It was our only chance for having a child.'' Idant is accused in another lawsuit filed last week of providing the wrong semen to a white woman who later bore a black child. The woman's husband, also white, had his sperm stored before undergoing chemotherapy for cancer. Idant has denied fault in that case. The News said it was unable to reach company officials for comment on the Mastrobuoni claim. A call placed by The Associated Press to Idant's answering service Saturday night wasn't returned. When Matrobuoni's cancer was discovered, a Veterans Administration hospital referred him to Idant, the News said. He agreed to pay the bank $200 and it stored some of his semen in January 1985, before he started radiation treatment. When the couple didn't hear from Idant, they called and learned the husband's sperm had been discarded because the lab had only received a $20 payment from the Veterans Administration. By that time, Mastrobuoni had started his radiation treatment. ``We never received any type of billing,'' Mrs. Mastrobuoni told the News. The newspaper said it could not reach Veterans Administration officials for comment. Mastrobuoni's cancer has been cured but an attorney for the couple, Joseph Filardi, said ``it's very unlikely his sperm count is high enough to effectuate conception.'' He added that radiation treatments also adversely affected the sperm.

DOC.HEAD: Former State Prosecutor Probed by Feds
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury is wrapping up an investigation of a former state prosecutor's alleged drug use in a case raising questions about a previous investigation by the state attorney general. Richard Guida was a deputy attorney general until 1986, when he resigned after a radio reporter's allegations that he was a heavy cocaine user. Then-Attorney General LeRoy S. Zimmerman found no evidence of any wrongdoing, but Guida said staying on the job while fighting what he called rumors would burden the department. The FBI and federal officials have been on the case since at least last May, and the grand jury has been hearing secret testimony from a string of Guida's acquaintances and former girlfriends for at least seven months. Insiders say the jury could wrap up its probe within a month. A recently obtained federal court document says last August acting U.S. Attorney James West told the court the probe ``involves allegations of possession and use of controlled substances'' by Guida while a prosecutor. Guida denied the allegations, said he never used cocaine and as recently as last month said he was not aware of any investigation. The court document said Guida was told he was a target of the probe last May. Guida was a highly regarded prosecutor whose role in winning convictions in a highly publicized murder won him a consulting job in a television miniseries about the case called ``Echoes in the Darkness.'' The show portrayed him as a hard-nosed prosecutor. Sources familiar with the investigation, including a grand jury witness, say it includes allegations that Guida provided cocaine to friends and that other officials may have tried to cover up his problems. The witness, Brenda Snell, would not discuss specifics of her grand jury appearance. But in a recent interview, the self-described former drug dealer and recovering addict said she told the FBI she sold cocaine to Guida three times and purchased small quantities of the drug from him twice. In 1985, she alleged, she sold a pound of cocaine to Guida for $17,000. She claimed Guida gave her the money in $100 and $20 bills in a paper bag at a snack shop in the building housing the attorney general's office. At the time, Guida was chief of the prosecutions section, supervising lawyers whose work included drug cases. Ms. Snell's attorney, Don Bailey, was present during the FBI interviews and confirmed she provided the details to investigators. Guida said he doesn't know the woman and called her allegations ``absolute lies.'' An FBI spokesman would not comment. Other sources, including lawyers representing grand jury witnesses, said the FBI became interested in Guida while investigating drug dealer Jack Alan Hull. Hull, 33, of Hershey was convicted in state court last year of cocaine and marijuana possession, subsequently pleaded guilty to federal charges of cocaine distribution and appeared before the grand jury earlier this year. In a sentencing memorandum signed by Assistant U.S. Attorney Gordon Zubrod, the government said Hull was providing information about his former drug contacts. ``Most of Jack Hull's clients were well-heeled professionals in the Dauphin County area,'' Zubrod wrote. ``His list included attorneys, physicians, stockbrokers and businessmen.'' Guida was Hull's attorney until Hull pleaded guilty and decided to cooperate. Guida said, ``He couldn't afford me any more.'' Hull is in protective custody at a state prison and could not be interviewed. But WHP-TV, quoting a source, reported that Hull ``alleges he was getting protection from Guida in the attorney general's office.'' Guida denied that allegation, too. Sources, who asked not to be named because of the confidentiality of grand jury proceedings, said federal officials obtained records from the attorney general's office relating to Guida's tenure and the 1986 internal probe. Zimmerman, now a lawyer in private practice, said when Guida left that the investigation by his office cleared the deputy. In a recent interview, he recharacterized the outcome as finding no evidence to support prosecution. West, who worked for Zimmerman and with Guida before moving to the federal system, took himself off the case because of a potential conflict of interest. Still, Ms. Snell's attorney Bailey asked U.S. Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., to withdraw West's nomination as U.S. attorney. Bailey, a Democratic former state auditor general long at odds with West politically, alleged that West and the FBI were covering up for Guida. Specter asked FBI Director William S. Sessions to investigate Bailey's allegations as part of a background check on West. The check apparently turned up no incriminating information about West; his file was sent to President Bush in January, clearing the way for his nomination.

DOC.HEAD: Minor Earthquake Strikes Near Algiers
DOC.TEXT: A mild earthquake rumbled through a lightly populated area near the capital Sunday. No damage or injuries were reported. The quake, which measured 4 on the Richter scale, struck about 30 miles southeast of Algiers. It was the latest of several mild quakes that have hit the Algiers area since Oct. 29, when a strong temblor occurred. That quake left at least 26 people dead, damaged 50,000 dwellings, and caused extensive damage in the legendary Casbah of old Algiers. The Richter scale is a guage of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph.

DOC.HEAD: Arab League Headquarters to Move to Cairo
DOC.TEXT: The headquarters of the 22-member Arab League will return to Cairo, ending an 11-year stay in Tunisia where it moved in protest after Egypt made peace with Israel. Egyptian Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid announced the decision Sunday at a biannual Arab League session. Egypt's Middle East News agency reported the announcement in a dispatch from Tunis, the Tunisian capital. Abdel-Meguid said the move would take place in September. The offices of the Arab Organization for Education, Culture and Science, and the Arab Broadcasting Union will remain in Tunis, the agency said. The Arab League charter names the Egyptian capital as seat of the organization, which was set up in Cairo in 1945. The 1979 decision to transfer the headquarters from Cairo was a sanction against Egypt for signing a peace treaty with Israel. Egypt was also suspended from the league. All Arab nations but Libya have officially restored diplomatic ties with Cairo. Egypt's suspension was lifted in May.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Representative Reported Under Arrest
DOC.TEXT: Police have arrested an Amnesty International representative who was gathering information about the government crackdown on the pro-democracy movement, sources said Sunday. Ram Kumar Jivanmitra was arrested Friday after leaving the Supreme Court building, according to the Human Rights Organization of Nepal. Police found documents in Jivanmitra's pockets that detailed arrests and allegations of torture by security forces, members of the rights group said. They spoke on condition of anonymity. There was no official word on the reported arrest. The sources said Jivanmitra was reporting information about the crackdown to Amnesty International, a human rights group based in London. The government has arrested hundreds of people to quell a movement launched by two banned political parties seeking a return to a multiparty system. At least 12 people have been killed in confrontations between demonstrators and police, according to the government. Activists say the toll is about double the government figure. The two parties _ the Nepali Congress and a coalition of left-wing groups _ are demanding an end to a 29-year-old ban on political parties. Power in Nepal is shared by King Birendra and a non-partisan Rashtriya Panchayat, or National Assembly. One-fifth of the assembly's 140 members are nominated by the monarch, and the rest are elected.

DOC.HEAD: Students Protest Anti-Islamic Measures
DOC.TEXT: Students distributed leaflets Sunday to protest what they called an anti-Islamic, pro-Western educational policy at the nation's only university. It was only the second protest reported in the country's two decades since independence. The protesters said foreign teachers at United Arab Emirates University in Al-Ain are encouraging Moslem women to abandon the veil. Most teachers and professors at the university are foreigners. ``Foreign teachers are selling their Western lifestyle among students regarding the relationship between men and women: intermingling among sexes, giving up the Islamic veil and other Western habits,'' the students said in their leaflet. The document was distributed along with the monthly magazine of the university's student federation. The magazine is distributed free to all government departments and companies. The university has 8,000 students, two-thirds of whom are women, but there are no women on the board of the student federation. In line with Islamic norms that govern society here, the men and women are strictly segregated at the university. The protest was directed at the university's rector, Abdul-Hafez al-Kurdi, an Egyptian-born naturalized American. It did not demand his replacement but called for appointing qualified U.A.E. nationals in leadership positions at the university. The student federation said a poll of students showed 65 percent believed university standards were declining, and 53 percent blamed Kurdi. The United Arab Emirates has a population of 1.6 million, of which only one-third are nationals. The rest are foreign labor from Asian, Arab and Western nations. Only one previous demonstration has been reported in the country since 1971, when the seven former Trucial Coast sheikdoms under British protection became the United Arab Emirates. That protest was against a declaration by President Sheik Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan that he planned to step down.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Tehran Papers Accuse U.S. of `Insinuating' Link to Iran
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 7th pvs, `The more...' to UPDATE with legislator called for probe of phone call hoax. Pickup 8th, `Rafsanjani told...'
DOC.TEXT: Two radical Iranian newspapers on Sunday accused the United States of trying to undermine President Hashemi Rafsanjani by insinuating he wants to mend relations with Washington. The Persian-language Jomhuri Islami also attacked ``certain local mass media'' for their statements on Western hostages in Lebanon. The newspaper did not elaborate, but it appeared to be referring to the English-language newspaper Tehran Times. That newspaper recently called for the release of the 18 Westerners held by pro-Iranian factions. Jomhuri Islami is aligned with the radical faction in Tehran that opposes Rafsanjani's efforts to improve relations with Western countries. Any contact with the United States is anathema to the radicals. The newspaper referred to the recent revelation that President Bush had spoken on the phone with a man who claimed to be Rafsanjani, but really wasn't. ``Washington wants to insinuate ... that efforts are being made behind the curtain for establishment of ties between Iran and the United States,'' the newspaper wrote. ``The more the United States makes such endeavors, the less it will gain,'' it said. ``Washington has not only failed to evaluate the Islamic republic but has confirmed, in fact, that the Islamic republic enjoys a sound and unshakable policy toward the United States.'' A parliament deputy called for an investigation Sunday into the phone hoax. Mohammad Qomi, deputy from Veramin, said Rafsanjani should look into the matter because it is unlikely anyone from Iran would have tried such a hoax. Rafsanjani told a news conference last week he believed the hostage problem was nearing a solution, but he repeated denials of any direct talks on the issue between Iran and the United States. Iran denies any connection with the kidnappings. It has said, however, it would use its influence on the hostages' behalf if the United States fulfills certain conditions, such as freeing billions of dollars in frozen Iranian assets. ``The writings of certain local mass media in connection with the hostages should be more carefully taken into consideration,'' wrote Jomhuri Islami. ``It is naive to see no link between these writings and the plans sketched by the White House and arrogance media.'' ``Arrogance'' is a term used by Iran to refer to the United States. The newspaper added: ``Such evidence unveils certain suspicious efforts that are made to undermine the administration of President Rafsanjani.'' Another radical Tehran newspaper, Abrar, made similar comments Sunday. It wrote, ``Washington may intend to create doubt among the forces loyal to the Islamic revolution by insinuating the idea that the existence of relations between Tehran and Washington is not too far from reality.'' The Westerners held in Lebanon are eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. The longest held is Terry A. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leader Told He Cannot Leave Country
DOC.TEXT: An opposition leader was released from house arrest Sunday but ordered to remain in the country indefinitely. Laurent Gbagbo, who was put under house arrest Saturday, said the order was lifted by the internal security minister, Gen. Issouf Kone. But Kone said he cannot leave Ivory Coast until the president announces plans to reverse the country's economic crisis. No explanation was given for the decision, Gbagbo said. No date has been set for the president to address the economic situation. Ivory Coast is suffering a severe economic crisis rooted in slumping prices of cocoa and coffee, its main exports. Austerity measures proposed by President Felix Houphouet-Boigny led to widespread student protests, which Gbagbo supported. The president three times has postponed a National Council meeting to discuss the new measures, which would cut government salaries by up to 40 percent and impose a 10 percent tax on private sector employees. Gbagbo, a history professor and leader of the Ivorian Popular Front, has blamed the economic crisis on the autocratic rule of Houphouet-Boigny and his Democratic Party. Gbagbo has repeatedly called for multiparty elections. ``The minister told me I've been talking too much,'' said Gbagbo. On Saturday he was put under house arrest for the third time since 1988. Houphouet-Boigny, 84, has ruled Ivory Coast since its independence from France in 1960. He argues the multiparty system creates tribal divisions on a continent wrought by ethnic rivalries. The proposed austerty measures last month led to violent protests, which soldiers and police broke up with truncheons, tear gas and stun grenades.
