Protesters stoned and burned cars and ransacked stores. The government defused the unrest by promising to review the economic proposals. It also pledged to cut prices of staple foods and rents on government housing.

DOC.HEAD: `Heat of the Night' Star Admits Alcohol, Drug Addictions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 6 p.m. EST, Time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: Howard Rollins, co-star of NBC's ``In the Heat of the Night,'' admits he was addicted to drugs and alcohol but firmly denies tabloid newspaper reports that he has AIDS. The actor, who portrays detective Virgil Tibbs, said his addictions drove him to consider suicide just three days before Christmas. An inner voice, he said, was telling him: ``Just go ahead and kill me. I'm sick of it. I'll never straighten out my life, I'll never have the career I want. How can I talk about a career when I can't even stop using drugs? Why can't I just take a gun to my head and be out of this misery?'' He said he took his last drug on Dec. 28. Then he packed up his drug paraphernalia and stomped it to pieces. ``I have a thing inside, a needing or craving, that I am constantly dealing with,'' he said in an interview published in the March 17 issue of TV Guide magazine. Rollins said he was only an occasional user when he landed the Tibbs role in 1987, but was hopelessly addicted within six months. During the first season, he was arrested in Baton Rouge, La., on charges of cocaine possession and drunken driving. That led to him twice entering rehabilitation centers, but both times he failed to stop using drugs. Toward the end of the show's second season, he began to miss work. ``I got too tired and it was too much to be able to keep that front up. Everyone knew I was high,'' he said. In November he was hospitalized after suffering chest pains and was told he had developed an enlarged heart chamber because of his drug use. That news led him to enter the drug clinic at Atlanta's Anchor Hospital. While there, his file photographs were sold to the tabloids. ``They apparently paid people to take my dietary files, then paid someone to tell them what I said in confidence in therapy sessions,'' he said. He said he told the therapy group, ``It's really hell having to live in a world where you have to deal with diseases like AIDS, or you have to deal with racism.'' That remark, he said, was twisted around to make it seem as if he had the disease. Asked in the interview if he had tested positive for the virus that is responsible for AIDS, Rollins said, ``No, no, no.''

DOC.HEAD: New Jersey Teen-Ager Wins Cook-Off
DOC.TEXT: A high school senior who served up grilled Norwegian salmon to a panel of finicky chefs won first prize in a cook-off contest and a $30,000 scholarship to pursue a culinary career. Carl Fortin, 18, of Hope, N.J., beat out nine finalists Saturday to win the National Recipe Cook-Off Contest for high school students sponsored by Johnson & Wales University. The four-year scholarship has a value of $30,504. The 10 finalists were culled from regional cook-offs during the past few months. Students had three hours to order the food they needed from the school's kitchens, prepare the meal and serve it to the judges. Dishes were judged on creativity, taste and nutrition. Scott Luscier of Stamford, Vt., placed second, winning a $5,000 scholarship with his spinach-stuffed chicken breast. James Hlavacek of North Haven, Conn., was third and claimed a $4,000 scholarship with his orange chicken twist.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: Officials of the Dallas Zoo, looking for a way to beat the Texas heat, may turn to a gorilla on the rocks. A ``gorilla cooler'' isn't some kind of exotic drink. Designers of the zoo's new gorilla habitat are working to develop ``cool rocks,'' refrigerated fake rocks, to encourage the zoo's four gorillas to stay outside when it's hot. ``But at times, they just won't be seen,'' said zoo curator Ron Kagan, ``and we're going to say to people, `That's good. Like you, you go to the bathroom and close the door, and so do they.' Sometimes that can add to the element of mystery and discovery at the zoo.'' The zoo's gorillas, which are being kept indoors, will be moved into their new, $3.6 million outdoor home in April.

It's not quite shooting fish in a barrel, but a dedicated angler who stocked his backyard swimming pool with fish for the winter says it guarantees that the big ones nearly always are biting. ``There are days I can go out there and catch fish over and over,'' said Lamar Collins, a 49-year-old contractor. ``Most of them know what my baits are and where I bought them.'' Later this month the bass, crappie and bluegill go back to the Tennessee River and Flint Creek, where they were caught with rod and reel, and people again will swim the pool. There are about 50 fish in the pool, maybe more. Feeding time is every two weeks, when Collins puts about 10 to 12 dozen minnows in the pool, he said. Collins began his backyard fishing hole last year by pumping down his pool, letting it refill with rain water, then stocking it when cool weather started around Oct. 1. ``I hardly miss a day picking up a rod, either for practice throwing or to see if they're biting,'' he said. If he plans to fish the river, Collins said trying his luck in the pool can be a good indicator of how the fish will be biting. ``You can observe from the water depth as to where you need to fish in the river,'' he said. ``If they're in the shallow end of the pool they'll probably be feeding in shallow water wherever you fish.''

An architectural draftsman who followed his girlfriend to Massachusetts and couldn't get a job has become an FM radio personality after putting his plea for work on a billboard: ``Help! I Need A Job.'' About 100 calls, nine radio and television appearances and two newspaper stories later, Bill Whiteman starts Monday at rock station WAAF in Worcester. The idea didn't take off immediately, however. The first day the billboard went up on a Boston thoroughfare, Whiteman said he got no calls. So the second day the 30-year-old went out and stood under it wearing a sign around his neck: ``Need Job. Ask Me About One Month Free Special.'' More than 60 interested employers called Whiteman, who left his job in Syracuse when his girlfriend got a job as a nurse at a Boston Hospital. One of those intrigued by the billboard was Ron Valeri, the programming director for WAAF. ``I'm always impressed by this kind of guerilla self-promotion in the field,'' Valeri said. ``This is exactly the kind of things more DJs should practice. This gets attention.'' Valeri said Whiteman, who had trial appearances on WAAF Thursday and Friday, is a natural. ``Have you ever met someone and thought `That person should be in show business?' Bill Whiteman is a disc jockey in disguise.'' WAAF broadcasts from Worcester to Boston and its targeted audience is males between the ages of 18-34. Valeri, who describes Whiteman as ``a little bit strange,'' said his new hire should fit right in at the station. Whiteman, who on Monday begins his daily shift between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., said he was nervous at first. But he has calmed down some, he said. ``The worst thing I could be is unemployed, and I was that already,'' he said. As he understands it, the job entails ``playing some music and being sort of friendly.'' And it has its perks, he said. ``I don't have to be there until one in the afternoon,'' he said. ``I can work on my golf game.''

DOC.HEAD: Rash of Bank Robberies in Columbus Perplexes Officials
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Douglass is cq in 3rd graf. Banc One Corp. is cq in 12th graf bgng `Ed Billman....'
DOC.TEXT: Brash and sometimes bumbling criminals have staged a rash of bank robberies in Ohio's capital city and its suburbs. The Columbus area, with a population of about 1.2 million, has had 42 bank robberies this year, more than Chicago, Detroit, Pittsburgh and Cleveland combined. ``Why are there so many bank robberies? Frankly, right now we don't have a clue,'' said FBI agent Douglass Ogden. ``If we knew that, we'd stop them.'' Authorities suspect many of the robbers are down-and-out drug addicts looking for quick cash. That theory was borne out with the arrest Friday of a man who admitted to robbing eight banks since Feb. 7, claiming he used the money to support a $900-a-day crack habit. The man, named Jesse ``James'' Dalton Jr. although authorities say he is no relation to the outlaw Jesse James or the Dalton brothers, confessed to the robberies after being shown photos taken by bank cameras. A man who robbed a bank Tuesday lost his fake beard and looked directly at the bank camera before fleeing, police said. ``These are not real sophisticates,'' said Capt. Frank Phillips, head of the police detective bureau. ``They're not getting much during the robbery, and most of them aren't getting away, either.'' Ogden said the robberies have involved small amounts _ generally no more than $1,000. He would not release specific figures. There have been 21 arrests in the 42 robberies. All of the defendants are awaiting trial. One man was arrested while counting his booty in his getaway vehicle _ a city bus _ March 5 after he allegedly robbed the same Bank One branch for the third time in a week. Police charged him in six bank heists. Ed Billman, vice president of Banc One Corp., which owns Bank One, said security has been increased at the branch. He said more plainclothes security guards would be stationed at his banks and that police have agreed to stop in periodically. ``I think there's a combination of bravery and stupidity at work here,'' said Phillips. ``I mean, most of these people are walking into the banks with no gun and, in most cases, no disguise, and they're looking right at the camera. This isn't Bonnie and Clyde we're dealing with.'' But authorities aren't taking the trend lightly. On March 2, five banks were hit, prompting Mayor Dana Rinehart to call for more bank security and more FBI presence. ``So far, nobody has been hurt. These people come into the bank, get the money and leave,'' Rinehart said. ``But sooner or later, somebody will get hurt. ... This will all end when one of these robbers gets shot with a .45 in the chest. It's a heck of a way to terminate the problem, but it sure gets the word out.'' Ogden said the FBI, police and bank security officials have met to determine the best way to stop the robberies. He would not give details, but he indicated security would be increased inside and outside bank branches in Franklin County, which includes Columbus. He also hopes to increase his number of agents. He would not say how many agents are assigned to the Columbus office, which oversees 12 counties. Ogden said his office is ``quite overwhelmed'' by the robberies in Columbus this year. Last year, bank robberies were down 50 percent from 1988, when 98 were reported, a record for the Columbus area. FBI figures show that Chicago has had 10 bank robberies so far this year, Detroit had nine, Pittsburgh four and metropolitan Cleveland three. Los Angeles, in contrast, has had 110. ``These things go in cycles,'' said Ogden. He pointed out that the Columbus freeway system makes for easy getaways. Two interstates cut through the city in each direction, and both connect with an outerbelt. Banks are fighting back by giving informants rewards of up to $2,000 and providing tellers with dye packs _ cannisters of paint that can be programmed to explode, marking the loot. ``I know of one teller who stuffed a dye pack down a robber's shirt. There's some guy out there with a real red chest right now. It shouldn't be too hard to find him,'' Billman said.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Bracing For Sharp Cutbacks in Aid After Upheavals in East Bloc
DOC.TEXT: Cuba is bracing itself for the possibility of a U.S. invasion and for sharp cutbacks in its foreign trade as a result of the upheavals in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. At the same time, President Fidel Castro is as determined as ever to stay on the socialist path despite the trend elsewhere toward free-market economies. Throughout Havana, signs remind citizens of that determination. ``Socialism come what may,'' said a large banner in an auditorium where Castro spoke last week. The development of a strong defense to guard against a U.S. invasion has been a high priority for years, and even more so lately. A young Cuban who recently completed three years of military service told a visiting American the other day that he spent virtually the entire time digging tunnels along the north coast for hiding soldiers, tanks and planes and for sheltering hospitals. ``I was a pick and shovel man,'' he said, looking down at his hands and recalling the harsh labor. For the past decade, Cuba has devised a strategy whereby in the event of aggression, the entire population would be mobilized in defense. Castro said in a speech Wednesday that efforts are being made to ensure maximum military self-sufficiency. If the United States imposes an air and naval blockade, steps have been taken to guarantee that ``all the bullets, all the rifles, the mines, the grenades, all the arms necessary'' are available to fight the enemy, he said. Any invading force, he said, would spill a ``river of blood.'' Castro said Cuba is manufacturing much of its own weaponry these days, utilizing iron imported from Angola. It is one of the country's few remaining allies. Castro ridiculed the United States for its habit of deposing unfriendly leaders in small countries and then declaring a ``colossal victory.'' ``As a rule, in their military adventures, the tears begin when the remains (of the soldiers) begin to arrive, when the coffins begin to arrive,'' he said. ``And those we can supply in great quantity if they invade Cuba,'' he added. ``Industrial quantities we can supply so they won't get bored and won't stop crying a single day.'' Castro also warned of the possibility of a peacetime crisis. Special measures would be required, he said, if problems in the Soviet Union lead to a cutoff of oil supplies to Cuba. The supplies average 12 million tons annually. ``What would happen if suddenly we don't have the 12 million?'' he asked. ``If there are only four, we have to know that.'' In case of this, all construction of schools, day care centers, health centers and housing would stop, the president said. Bus service in Havana could be reduced from 30,000 trips a day to 10,000. On the farm, mules would have to replace tractors. The anti-Communist upheavals in Eastern Europe have cast doubt on Cuba's future trade and political relations with that region. Castro heaped ridicule on the four Warsaw Pact members _ Hungary, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria _ which either co-sponsored or supported a U.S. proposal in the U.N. Human Rights Commission last week calling attention to alleged rights abuses in Cuba. The proposal was approved 17-12. The shifting political allegiances of the East Europeans could mean a cutback in Cuba's trade with those nations, but Castro almost seemed to welcome that possibility. In exchange for Cuban citrus fruits, nickel and other products, the East Europeans often provided ``junk'' in return, he said. As an example, he said, ``Hungarian buses get six kilometers (four miles) per gallon, fill the city with smoke and poison everybody.'' Soon, he added, ``We're going to free ourselves from all that,'' with the help of higher-quality buses made in Cuba.

DOC.HEAD: Oliver Stone Says Directors' Award May Speed His Work to the Screen
DOC.TEXT: Oliver Stone, whose films often follow tortuous paths to the screen, said winning the Directors Guild of America award for ``Born on the Fourth of July'' should speed his filmmaking process. ``It's giving me more freedom,'' Stone said Saturday night after collecting the guild's top honor at its annual awards ceremony, a bellwether for the Academy Awards. ``It's a tremendous validation for me. It means I'm doing the right thing,'' said Stone, a self-described anarchist who has directed a variety of deeply personal films, including ``Salvador'' and ``Wall Street.'' ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' Stone's account of the patriot soldier Ron Kovic whose attitudes about war are shattered in Vietnam, took more than 10 years to make. ``Platoon,'' the acclaimed Vietnam film that Stone also directed, similarly was a hard sell. He said some film projects _ like ``Born on the Fourth of July'' _ can be improved when they have a long time to percolate. He was quick to point out, too, that simply winning prizes and producing box-office hits does not make movie making a cake walk. ```How sweet it is and how fleeting,'' he said when collecting his award at a black-tie dinner at the Beverly Hilton Hotel. Backstage, he said his triumph soon would be old news. ``Success and failure are both impostors,'' he said. Nevertheless, Stone joins an elite list of directors who have taken the guild's top honor twice in their careers (Stone also won for ``Platoon''). Other dual winners include Joseph Mankiewicz, George Stevens, David Lean, Robert Wise, Francis Ford Coppola and Milos Forman. Stone, who becomes the odds-on favorite to win the Oscar for best director, said he plans to make a third film about Vietnam in the next several years. He declined to say what the film will focus on, saying only that it will not concern combat but ``another aspect'' of war. Stone currently is working on a movie about the musical group The Doors. In the 42 years the guild has been handing out the awards, only three of its picks failed to win the Oscar. In addition to Stone, those nominated by the guild for best director of a feature film were Woody Allen for ``Crimes and Misdemeanors,'' Rob Reiner for ``When Harry Met Sally ...,'' Phil Alden Robinson for ``Field of Dreams'' and Peter Weir for ``Dead Poets Society.'' The Academy did not nominate Reiner or Robinson. Allen, Stone and Weir are Oscar nominees, along with Kenneth Branagh for ``Henry V'' and Jim Sheridan for ``My Left Foot.'' The guild awards _ chosen by a vote of the 9,000 members _ also recognize best director in several other categories: television comedy series, dramatic series (day and night), musical-variety, dramatic specials, sports and commercials. Among the others honored were the directors of TV's ``Murphy Brown'' and ``L.A. Law'' series. In television, the award for best director in a comedy went to Barnet Kellman for the episode ``Brown Like Me,'' on CBS' ``Murphy Brown.'' Other TV awards: Dramatic special, Dan Curtis for ABC's ``War and Remembrance''; dramatic nighttime series, Eric Laneuville for the ``I'm in the Nude'' episode on NBC's ``L.A. Law''; dramatic daytime series, Victoria Hochberg for the ``Jacob Have I Loved'' episode on PBS' ``Wonderworks.'' Also, for musical variety show, Don Mischer for ``Gregory Hines: Tap Dance in America,'' on PBS' ``Great Performances''; television documentary, Peter Rosen for ``The Eighth Van Cliburn International Piano Competition'' on PBS; sports event show, Bob Fishman for the 1989 U.S. Open Tennis Tournament on CBS.

DOC.HEAD: Military Commanders Say Their People Will Lose in Budget Battles
DOC.TEXT: Vice Adm. J.M. Boorda, a sailor since he ran away to join the Navy at age 16, tends to use a salty phrase or two when he thinks of what Gramm-Rudman budget-cutters may do to his beloved service. As Congress and the White House remain locked in a test of political wills over major military personnel cuts, Boorda can see only one result: His people will lose. ``There are two trains running together, the administration and ... Democrats, and my sailors are sitting in the middle,'' Boorda told a House panel last week. He says the seaman on patrol in the Mediterranean or the Army soldier who landed in Panama are too busy to know what the Office of Management and Budget is, or who sits on the House or Senate armed services committees _ known on Capitol Hill as OMB, HASC or SASC. ``All they know is they got screwed by the people in Washington,'' Boorda said. Boorda, a handful of service personnel and even the joint chiefs have been making the rounds in Congress, appearing before House and Senate committees to try to avert major personnel cuts. The battle is over the Pentagon's request to transfer $935 million from weapons accounts to military personnel to avoid the impact of the Gramm-Rudman budget-cutting law. Without the authority to shift funds, the Defense Department says it will have to lay off tens of thousands of men and women in the military, freeze promotions and put transfers on hold. President Bush had the option last August to exempt military personnel from the law as the Reagan administration had done in previous years. Instead, White House Budget Director Richard Darman and the administration decided not to exclude personnel, assuming that four committees _ House and Senate armed services and House and Senate defense appropriations _ would later allow them to shift the funds. So far, the gamble has failed. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, declined to bring up the request before his panel, telling the Pentagon he didn't want to play their ``shell game.'' ``Putting weapons before people was their decision and now they're stuck with it,'' Aspin said. The House chairman has the backing of the Democratic leadership. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said last week that Congress can't allow the administration to shift funds on military accounts when it can't be done on domestic accounts. ``The administration is responsible for this decision, not Congress,'' Foley said. Although House Democrats are standing firm, the fight continues. The Senate Armed Services Committee voted last week to grant the Pentagon part of the authority to transfer funds, allowing $795 million of the $935 million requested. But Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services panel, accused the Pentagon of making a ``conscious decision to exploit a loophole'' in the budget-cutting law. ``I want to make it clear that we voted on the side of the men and women in the military who were put at risk by the administration's decision not to use its authority to exempt the military personnel accounts,'' Nunn said Friday. Christopher Jehn, the Pentagon's assistant secretary of defense for force management and personnel, told a Senate subcommittee that the department did not ask Bush to exempt personnel because there wouldn't have been enough money to train them. ``The trade-off was whether we should protect personnel accounts and wind up with what amounted to an imbalanced budget,'' Jehn said.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Wounds 14 in Beirut
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded six feet from a Syrian army checkpoint in Moslem west Beirut on Sunday and wounded 14 people, police said. They said a light blue Mercedes-Benz rigged with explosives detonated at 4 p.m. It damaged at least six parked cars and shattered windows in several nearby buildings. Nervous Syrian soldiers sealed off the scene as ambulances converged on the area in the Qasqas residential district. No group claimed responsibility for the attack. Syria has about 40,000 soldiers in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate. They are stationed in all areas except the Christian enclave and the southern zone along the Israeli border. Also Sunday, troops of renegade Gen. Michel Aoun traded sporadic machine-gun fire with Lebanese Forces militiamen in Christian east Beirut, killing a man, police said. They said the two sides battled in the east Beirut districts of Ashrafiyeh, Dora and Sin el-Fil. The man, a civilian, was killed in Dora, according to police. They had no further details. Aoun's command said a Lebanese army soldier died in hospital Saturday of bullet wounds he suffered from sniping the day before. That increased to 754 the number of people killed since Jan. 30 in the battle for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave. The battle pits Aoun's mainly Christian soldiers against the fighters of Samir Geagea, leader of the Lebanese Forces Christian militia.

DOC.HEAD: Two Youths Killed in Train Accident in Sudan
DOC.TEXT: Two men riding illegally on top of a train were killed when the train derailed and they fell off, the Sudan Railways Corporation said Sunday. The corporation reported that the accident occurred Saturday on a line linking the capital, Khartoum, to the Mediterranean town of Port Sudan. It said two 20-year-old men were killed. One 20-year-old man and three teen-agers were wounded, said the railway statement. The accident took place at the Ogarin station, 175 miles northeast of Khartoum. The crowded train carried both people and cargo. Many people were riding on top of the cars, which is common but illegal in Sudan.

DOC.HEAD: 39 Drug Smugglers Hanged in Iran
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-nine convicted drug smugglers were hanged Sunday, the latest executions carried out under the government's anti-narcotics crackdown, Tehran radio reported. The radio broadcast said the 39 were charged with smuggling or selling a total of 3,470 pounds of opium and 139 pounds of heroin. The hangings occurred in 12 cities. Iranian law mandates the death sentence for possession of even small quantities of drugs with intent to sell. More than 1,200 drug smugglers have been hanged in Iran since a crackdown began in December 1988. The radio has reported as many as 80 hangings in a single day. Opposition groups maintain the drug-related hangings are used to mask executions of political dissidents. Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani urged police Sunday to continue the crackdown on drugs, the radio said. ``The fight in this direction is a serious step toward rehabilitating our economy and society. It blocks the way for corrupt individuals, and will stop innocent people from falling into corruption,'' Rafsanjani was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEAD: `Today' Show Gets Rude Awakening in Ratings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, ``Today'' ratings ..., to CORRECT affiliation to NBC, sted CBS; SUBS grafs 10-27, ``It takes ..., to CORRECT spelling of Reilly, sted Riley.
DOC.TEXT: These are tough times for NBC's venerable ``Today'' show, the program that invented the morning TV format. Last week it lost in the ratings to ABC's ``Good Morning America'' for the ninth consecutive week, and it lost the February ``sweeps'' to ABC for the first time since November 1985. Is the sun going down on ``Today''? Is this a new dawn for ABC's ``Good Morning America''? Will ``CBS This Morning'' emerge from the twilight of third place? Has success spoiled Bryant Gumbel? ``Today'' ratings began declining with co-host Jane Pauley's poised and public departure from the show after 13 years. Her replacement, NBC newswoman Deborah Norville, apparently reminds some women of their least-favorite college roommate. ``The `Today' show has experienced a serious decline, about 15 percent on average, since Deborah Norville took over,'' said David Marans, head of media research for the J. Walter Thompson advertising conglomerate. ``There was a clear reaction to the change in casting,'' he said. ``We could see no other reason for the needle really moving.'' CBS' morning efforts generally have run a distant third in ratings almost since the network began competing with ``Today'' in 1954. Predecessors of ``CBS This Morning'' changed personnel, sets and style so often that a loyal viewer was someone who occasionally tuned in just to see who or what was still there. The current CBS edition's latest attempt at innovation, in February, was to cashier Harry Smith's co-anchor, Kathleen Sullivan, in favor of ex-ABC newswoman Paula Zahn and a barely discernible improvement in ratings. ABC, keeping the same cast before its cameras, won the No. 1 spot without significantly increasing its ratings. ``It takes a long time to develop a team,'' said Jack Reilly, executive producer of ``Good Morning America.'' ``It takes an even longer time for the audience to accept it.'' Reilly noted that, historically, ``Today'' has led in household ratings but ABC's show has been more popular among advertisers' most desirable target groups _ women aged 18 to 49 and men and women aged 25 to 54. NBC officials insist that they're not worried about the numbers. ``We knew there was going to be a drop in the ratings for the `Today' show,'' said NBC research chief Bob Niles. ``The good news is that we were pretty good about forecasting it. The bad news is we didn't want to see those numbers.'' Niles said a similar ratings dip occurred after Gumbel replaced Tom Brokaw as co-host in January 1982. For the next two years, ABC beat ``Today'' like a gong. One week in August 1983, ``Today'' finished third for the first time. Overall, since January ``Today'' has lagged an average six-tenths of a rating point behind ``Good Morning America,'' for a loss of about 600,000 viewers, Niles said. Niles said the decline has not prompted NBC to conduct any immediate audience research to discover just what the problem is. ABC's Reilly said: ``Everyone forgets that the pressure that brought on all these problems over there there was that we were beating them.'' And, he noted, it took ``Today'' five years to climb back to No. 1 after Gumbel joined the show. Gumbel presaged the current troubles with a memo criticizing weatherman Willard Scott and other ``Today'' personalities. The memo to then-producer Marty Ryan savaged Scott's cornball act and the timeliness of movie maven Gene Shalit's reviews. It also faulted consumer reporters David Horowitz and Betty Furness and medical reporter Dr. Art Ulene. Only Pauley escaped Gumbel's wrath. Ryan was succeeded by Tom Capra, a longtime news producer, who was moving from California to New York on Friday and could not be interviewed for this story. Gumbel, who declined to be interviewed, will be questioned by Barbara Walters on ABC's ``20-20'' Friday in what should be a benchmark among interviews of network anchors by other anchors. Walters made her own reputation on ``Today,'' which began Jan. 14, 1952, under the late Dave Garroway. While ``Today'' is losing viewers with the latest cast change, there's a hitch for the network competitors. ``They're going elsewhere,'' Marans said. ``For the past eight weeks, there hasn't been a significant increase in ABC or CBS viewership.'' So where are they going? Analysts suggest they're tuning in to increasingly sophisticated local TV morning shows or disappearing into the cable box. ABC's Reilly said the vanishing viewer has been a problem for the networks for five years. ``There is no one alternative that comes near (the networks), but collectively there are so many options out there that people use them.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel May Demand Reparations From A United Germany
DOC.TEXT: Israel is entitled to and may demand reparations for the Holocaust from a united Germany, the Israeli ambassador to West Germany said in an interview released Sunday. ``I can't rule out that Israel will demand reparations at some point,'' Benjamin Navon, a Holocaust survivor, told the mass-circulation daily Bild in an interview to be published Monday. A 1950s reparations agreement with West Germany ``spells out explicitly that we are entitled to do so in the case of German unity,'' the ambassador said. The interview was released in advance of publication to other media. West Germany has paid $44 billion in reparations to Israel and Jewish Holocaust survivors around the world under the agreement. By the end of this decade, payments are expected to reach $55.5 billion. But East Germany for years refused to accept moral responsibility for the Holocaust or pay reparations. The former Communist leaders argued that they themselves were persecuted by the Nazis and therefore could not be held accountable for the genocide in which 6 million Jews perished. After the hard-line leadership was toppled by a popular rebellion in the fall, the new government announced that all German people share responsibility for the ``terrible crimes against the Jewish people.'' Also last month, Israel and East Germany held preliminary talks about establishing diplomatic ties. Israel has said it would only establish relations if East Germany accepted moral responsibility for the Holocaust and paid reparations. Israeli officials have said privately that considering East Germany's crumbling economy, they would be willing to settle for token payments. Navon said in the Bild interview that East Germany was ``morally obligated'' to pay reparations. ``East Germany also was part of the former Third Reich, but has always refused to deal with its Nazi past,'' he said. Asked about Israel's views on German unity, he said: ``We have faith in the German democracy. We are convinced that a united Germany will nurture positive and friendly relations with my country and my people.'' However, Navon pointed out that many Israelis were concerned about the rapid move toward German unification. ``You have to understand: tens of thousands of Israelis carry the death camp number on their arm, they have suffered terribly.'' After World War II, Israel served as a refuge for tens of thousands of Holocaust survivors. When Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens embraced the idea of a unified democratic Germany, his statement caused an uproar in Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Stars Converge on Miami To Honor Broadway Legend, Fight AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Broadway stars from yesterday and today came together to honor George Abbott, one of Broadway's greatest playwrights and directors, during a benefit to raise money for AIDS research. Sophia Loren was host and producer-director Hal Prince, director-choreographer Tommy Tune, and performers Van Johnson, Nancy Walker, Eddie Albert, Eartha Kitt, Margaret Whiting and Nanette Fabray were among luminaries on hand Saturday night. The evening's highlight was a two-hour revue of songs from Abbott's most famous shows, which include ``A Funny Thing Happened On The Way To The Forum,'' ``Pajama Game,'' ``Pal Joey,'' and ``Damn Yankees.'' Abbott, 102, lives on Indian Creek Island with his 58-year-old wife, Joy. About 700 guests paid $500 or more to attend the event at Williams Island sponsored by the Community Alliance Against AIDS. Organizers raised more than $425,000 for an AIDS unit at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami. Loren also was host at the event last year. The actress is a spokeswoman for the luxury development at Williams Island, which underwrote the dinner for the second year. The event started in 1987 with Elizabeth Taylor as chairwoman.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Consensus Wavering as Afghan Rebels Show No Sign of Winning War
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS grafs 4-5 pvs, bgng: The administration, to include states and party affiliations for Solarz, Hamilton
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The stalemate in the Afghanistan war is unraveling the political consensus that has characterized U.S. policy toward the embattled nation for the past 10 years. When the Soviets withdrew their troops from Afghanistan, CIA analysts predicted that in a matter of months the Mujahedeen rebels would topple the Soviet-installed government and march triumphantly to the presidential palace in Kabul. A year later, the fighting is at a stalemate. And Congress, until recently solidly behind the administration's policy with covert allocations that reportedly hit $600 million annually, is starting to rebel. The administration should not expect ``the automatic and routine continuation of a program that wasn't challenged for a decade,'' said Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., chairman of the House subcommittee on Asia who convened a hearing last week on Afghanistan. At a hearing on the direction of U.S. support for the Mujahedeen, Solarz and Rep. Lee Hamilton of Indiana, the No. 2 Democrat on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, repeatedly questioned the need to keep the Afghanistan program secret and argued for public debate of U.S. policy. The State Department and the CIA, meanwhile, appear engaged in a turf battle over policy toward the rebels. U.S. Afghan policy began to unravel soon after the Soviets completed the pullout of their troops in February 1989, a period that coincided with the transition from the Reagan to the Bush administrations. In the time it took the new administration to settle in, a vacuum formed which the CIA was happy to fill with the personnel it already had in place, said Barnett R. Rubin, an expert on Afghanistan who testified at Solarz's hearing. Subsequently, the State Department began to weigh in but many of the operational decisions such as which rebel factions should get how many weapons are still in the CIA's hands, said Rubin, who is a research fellow at the congressionally endowed Institute of Peace. He said ``there are extremely divergent views within the government about'' the situation in Afghanistan and where U.S. interests lie. ``What disturbs me most about the American role in all this is the degree to which the United States has become involved in what are essentially internal Afghan affairs,'' said Robert Peck, who until last June was the administration's chief specialist on Afghanistan. With the Soviet enemy gone and Afghan factions vying for political ascendancy, ``the logic of the Afghan situation argues that we should be disengaging, (rather than) plunging in more deeply,'' he said in congressional testimony. For 10 years, the United States secretly trained and armed the Mujahedeen rebels so they could defeat the Soviet troops who invaded Afghanistan in 1979. Saudi Arabia was a major contributor to the effort, and the Pakistani secret service was put in charge of distributing the American weapons to the array of rebel factions headquartered in Pakistan. The murky situation, in which the Pakistani secret service is reportedly exploiting divisions among the rebel leaders and playing the groups off against each other, was not helped by the March 6 coup attempt against President Najib. At least 56 people died and 200 others were injured in the revolt by soldiers loyal to the renegade defense minister, Gen. Shah Nawaz Tanai. Tanai was supported by Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, a fundamentalist guerrilla leader who until last year was among the rebel commanders in the U.S.-backed Mujahedeen coalition. In recent months, it has become increasingly clear that Najib's government _ with massive infusions of Soviet weaponry to the tune of more than $300 million a month _ was far more durable even without help from Soviet troops than the CIA predicted. The Mujahedeen, hampered by internal divisions and by its orientation primarily as a guerrilla force, has been unable to wrest control of Afghanistan's cities from government troops. And the administration has been forced to rethink its moves. The objective is still the same, U.S. officials say _ getting rid of the Soviet-installed Najib. But the focus is shifting from doing so by military might to achieving that goal through a political settlement. ``A military solution could be protracted,'' said one official who asked not to be named. ``We want to try and shape events toward a political solution.'' Later this month, State Department officials will meet with their Soviet counterparts to discuss Najib's future. The Kremlin is willing to support Najib's eventual ouster but insists he remain in charge of a transitional government, U.S. officials say. The United States insist he must go. The United States is directing its sights toward the convening of a council of all Afghan opposition groups this summer, a forum known as a ``shura,'' which would elect representatives to negotiate a transition to elected government. Experts outside government are skeptical the shura will take place. ``Unfortunately, putting Afghanistan back together again is likely to take a long time _ even if we knew how to do it,'' Peck said. ``If there is one learn we should have drawn from our role'' in Afghanistan ``it is that Afghans are not easily programmed. They do not hold the advice of outsiders in particularly high esteem.'' Instead of negotiating with the Soviets about Najib, the United States should agree with the Kremlin for both sides to stop arming the combatants, Peck said. Conservatives in Congress argue vehemently against such a move, saying it would give the Najib government, with its large stocks of weapons, an unfair advantage over the Mujahedeen.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Ruth Sinai has been covering foreign policy in Washington for The Associated Press since 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Chile's New President: A Veteran Politician Who Turned Against Pinochet
With AM-Chile, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Patricio Aylwin is a veteran and savvy politican who broke with Gen. Augusto Pinochet and helped lead the movement that voted the right-wing leader out of office. Aylwin, a 71-year-old lawyer who took office Sunday, often says he lacks a leader's personality. In fact, the tall and lanky politician with sloping posture and a plaintive voice is fond of saying he is ``not presidential.'' But his long career in politics belies that self-portrait. He has been president of the Senate, seven times president of his centrist Christian Democratic Party, and in the 1960s he presided over the U.N. General Assembly. During that time he became known as a persuasive negotiator who believes in compromise but who also can stick to his principles when pushed. Aylwin is the son of a Supreme Court chief justice. He was born Nov. 26, 1918, in San Bernardo, then a rural community just south of Santiago and now a bustling suburb. As a law student, Aylwin joined the then-budding socialist movement in Chile. Soon afterward, however, he turned to the Christian Democrats, partly because of his strong belief in Roman Catholicism. In the party, which is Chile's largest, he gained a reputation as a conservative and an enemy of the left. He never accepted the label rightist, however, calling himself a centrist. He explains that in Latin America ``leftists have often said that social changes are legitimate, and they must be carried out even if to do so it is necessary to break the law.'' ``I've always rejected that because I think that breaking the law brings more aggravation than progress to the poor,'' he said in an interview shortly before his landslide election victory in December. ``The law is the protection of the weak against the powerful.'' He also severely criticizes the right, saying it ``is selfish and thinks only of protecting its economic interests.'' Aylwin initially supported the bloody 1973 military coup in which Pinochet seized power and toppled an elected leftist government during a period of economic and political turmoil. Like many Chileans, he believed the armed forces would quickly return to the barracks after establishing order. He became disillusioned when it became evident Pinochet had no plans to surrender power and instead was wielding it harshly to repress dissent. Aylwin gradually joined the ranks of the goverment's outspoken critics. When Pinochet called an October 1988 referendum on a proposal to extend his rule to 1997, Aylwin emerged as leader of a broad coalition of centrist and leftist groups that successfully campaigned for the general's defeat. To nobody's surprise, he won nomination as the coalition's presidential candidate in Dec. 14 elections, winning 55 percent of the vote. His nearest challenger, a former Pinochet finance minister, won just 29 percent. During his campaign, Aywin promised to respect human rights and civil liberties and to increase spending on social programs. But he said he plans no major changes in the country's fairly successful free-market economic program. His election, he said, indicated the public's strong desire to recover ``the right to decide by themselves'' and ``their dignity.'' Aylwin and his wife, Leonor Oyarzun, have three adult sons and two daughters.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs Paris-dated 3rd item to omit reference to ring as a bauble in 3rd graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: A five-carat diamond ring lost by Ringo Starr turned up recently at a jewelry shop and has been returned to the former Beatles drummer, police said Sunday. Starr, 49, lost the ring after a concert last October in the French capital. Police estimated its worth at more than $172,000. The ring surfaced a few weeks ago at a jewelry shop in the St. Ouen district of northern Paris, sold to the owner by a man police said did not know it belonged to the rock star. By that time the diamond already had passed ``through several persons,'' police said. Investigators later found and matched it against a description provided by the insurance company. The ring has been returned to Starr and police said the jewelry shop owner and the man who sold him the ring will face unspecified criminal charges.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrations Against Communists, Secret Police
DOC.TEXT: Anti-government demonstrators marched Sunday through the capital and in Timisoara, the cradle of the December revolution, protesting what they said was the continued prevalence of Communists and the dreaded Securitate. ``Down with Iliescu,'' chanted demonstrators in Timisoara, referring to interim President Ion Iliescu, a former Communist who ran afoul of deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Iliescu led the National Salvation Front that took power during the chaos of the revolution and now heads the multiparty Council of National Unity. The Council is the makeshift parliament that succeeded the Front. The crowd, estimated at up to 15,000 by Ion Micu, an editor at Radio Timisoara, also called for the resignation of Interior Minister Gen. Mihai Chitac. Chitac has been accused of direct involvement in the violent suppression of the December demonstrations in Timisoara, in which scores were shot by forces loyal to Ceausescu. The violence in Timisoara, about 250 miles west of Bucharest, sparked the revolution that swept the country and finally toppled Ceausescu Dec. 22. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were executed on Christmas Day. Supporters say Chitac contributed to the success of the revolution by siding with the Timisoara demonstrators against the Securitate, Ceausescu's security force. Several hundred people also demonstrated in the northeastern city of Iasi for the exposure of Securitate members and the removal of former Communists from state bodies, the national news agency Rompres reported. ``The Front Confiscated The Revolution,'' read one sign carried in the Bucharest protest, which was attended by about 1,000. The Front, dominated by former Communists who ran afoul of Ceausescu, has since been forced to share power until May 20 elections. ``This government came to power illegally,'' said Bucharest demonstrator George Vijan, standing in front of the provisional government headquarters in Victory Square. ``They did not come from the revolutionary people.'' ``They represent a group of Communists from the 1950s who are guilty of crimes against the people,'' he said. ``Iliescu said that there is no more Securitate,'' said demonstrator Marin Tileau, a 44-year-old hospital worker. ``But the Securitate is still functioning in policemen's clothes.'' The Securitate was officially disbanded after the revolution, and its personnel were transferred from Interior Ministry to Defense Ministry control. Some officers have gone on trial. Last month, the Defense Ministry published a breakdown on the makeup of the Securitate and said the new security organization being set up would not use repression or intimidation. It is a common anti-government theme here that the interim government wants to maintain some totalitarian aspects of the Ceausescu leadership. Opposition parties in the Council of National Unity are trying to get the election postponed until autumn, on the grounds that the Front now has an unfair advantage because of its domination of Romanian politics since taking power in the revolution. All three demonstrations were peaceful and no arrests were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Colombians Vote After a Night of Violence
DOC.TEXT: Colombians voted for federal, state and local candidates Sunday in an election that followed a night of violence in which six people were killed, including two city council candidates. No violence was reported at polling places as people lined up to vote for senators, House representatives, state legislators and municipal officials. The governing Liberal Party also chose its candidate in presidential elections to be held May 27. One of three Liberal frontrunners _ Cesar Gaviria, Hernando Duran Dussan and Ernesto Samper _ was expected to win the primary and eventually succeed President Virgilio Barco. Polls opened at 8 a.m. (same time EST) to allow the first of an expected turnout of 7 million voters to cast ballots. There are 13.8 million Colombians, 18 years or older, who are allowed to vote in the elections. The polls remained open until 4 p.m., and the first official results were expected at 8 p.m. Colombians elected all 313 members of the nation's bicameral legislature, 9,042 city councilmen, 1,009 mayors, and 421 state assembly members. Former leaders of a leftist guerrilla group _ April 19 Movement, or M19 _ campaigned in many races Saturday, just hours after signing a treaty with the government that ended their 16-year insurgency. But two other rebel groups, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia and the People's Liberation Army, refused to put down their arms. And a third leftist guerrilla group, the National Liberation Army, said it will never enter peace talks. The group's campaign of kidnappings and other terrorism to disrupt the election continued Saturday night. In Chaparral, a town 125 miles south of Bogota, National Liberation Army guerrillas killed two soldiers guarding voting precints late Saturday, the Tolima state government office reported. Members of the group also killed Pablo Caro Ruiz, a Liberal Party candidate for the city council of Tame, 205 miles north of Bogota, according to a communique from the Interior Ministry. In the northern town of Bello, another Liberal Party candidate for the city council, Libardo Antonio Taborda, was killed. Local police said they had not established who was responsible for the crime. Two local organizers for the leftist Patriotic Union Party were shot and killed late Saturday in the town of Chigorodo, 155 miles north of Bogota, state government officials said. Since its founding in 1985, the Patriotic Union has been targeted by right-wing death squads.

DOC.HEAD: Killings Continue, Black Paper Criticizes Anti-Apartheid demand
DOC.TEXT: Five people were reported killed in factional fighting in black townships, and a black newspaper Sunday said anti-apartheid groups should not be demanding an end to police emergency powers. The leaders of black townships said the restrictive measures, introduced in 1986, should not be lifted amid the wave of violence that has claimed about 200 lives during the past month. ``For once, many of us are beginning to question the logic of calling for the lifting of the state of emergency when we are still senselessly killing each other like animals,'' City press said in a Sunday editorial. A black policeman was among those killed in factional fighting and clashes with police over the past 24 hours. The violence, in all four provinces, included 13 attacks on police vehicles or homes, Pretoria police said. Police used birdshot, tear gas, rubber bullets and a revolver against crowds of blacks armed with stones and petrol bombs, police said in a daily report. They said 16 people were injured and 20 were arrested. Residents of townships near Johannesburg and in Natal province have asked the army to bring in reinforcements to stop the factional fighting. But removal of troops from black townships has been a standing demand of anti-apartheid groups since the state of emergency was declared June 12, 1986 to put down anti-government protests and black-on-black clashes. Police reinforcements were sent to Kathlehong, a black township 12 miles east of Johannesburg, government radio reported. In a march on Friday, residents appealed for police to stop the violence in which 23 people have died and scores were injured over the past week. Township Mayor Tau Molotsi said the clashes began as a dispute between rival taxi companies. He said dozens of people sought refuge at the local police station and hospital and parents have sent their children away. The emergency regulations allow police to detain suspects for up to six months without charge, ban protests, and bar journalists and the general public from protests and areas of unrest. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok told Parliament Friday the government was prepared to use its extensive powers under the 3{-year-old state of emergency to quell violence. Most of the recent clashes occurred in South Africa's 10 tribal homelands, whereas fighting in the mid-1980s occurred mostly in urban townships. Four of the homelands are independent republics, although they are not recognized by any other country. They were established in the 1960s as national states, where the 28-million black majority could exercise political rights and own land. Anti-apartheid organizations say the system is a ploy to deprive blacks of South African citizenship, and the homeland leaders have been criticized by the African National Congress as collaborators with the white minority government. Frank Ravele, leader of one nominally independent homeland of Venda on Saturday legalized the African National Congress, the Pan Africanist Congress, the Communist Party and other organizations. South African President P.W. Botha legalized the groups in February and the Xhosa republics of Ciskei and Transkei recently followed suit. Now they are only outlawed in Bophuthatswana. Under apartheid, the black majority has no voice in national affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Former Editor-Publisher Dies
DOC.TEXT: James Wesley Coldsmith, former editor and publisher of newspapers in Alexandria, Va., died Saturday at his home of leukemia. He was 60. Coldsmith was an editor or publisher of newspapers in the northern Virginia city from the 1960s through the 1980s and ran twice for the city council as a Republican. He expanded an advertising flyer into what became The Journal group of newspapers in the Virginia and Maryland suburbs near Washington. Coldsmith earlier had been editor and publisher of the Alexandria Port Packet and the Alexandria Gazette. Born in Parsons, Kan., Coldsmith worked for The Associated Press in Tokyo, Denver and Chicago, before moving to Virginia in 1966. Earlier, he served in the Army and was news editor of the Stars and Stripes in Tokyo.

DOC.HEAD: Selma Mayor Says City Hall Campers Violating Court Order
DOC.TEXT: Activists protesting the ouster of Selma's first black school superintendent camped out Sunday at City Hall despite a court order barring them from the building outside business hours. ``We're waiting to notify the judge that they're violating the order,'' Mayor Joe Smitherman said. The mayor claims the demonstrators have reduced city government to ``anarchy'' in the past month. Police said a half-dozen protesters were inside City Hall over the weekend, and some pitched two tents on the lawn in front of the building, which Smitherman said also violated the court order. Circuit Judge Leslie Johnson issued a temporary ruling Saturday barring protesters from spending the night, eating and playing cards in City Hall, or from disrupting City Council business. Blacks have staged nearly continuous protests at City Hall and have shouted down council members at meetings recently to protest the white-controlled school board's decision against renewing the contract of Norward Roussell. Roussell and his supporters blame his dismissal on racism. The school board, which is appointed by the majority-white City Council, cited Roussell's management style in voting in December not to renew his contract when it expires June 30. The controversy has included school boycotts by students and teachers, and Selma's 6,000-student public school system was closed for nearly a week in February for fear of violence. The school system is 75 percent black, and the city's population is about 52 percent black. The mayor said he was not certain what the city might ask the judge to do at a hearing this week or next. A spokesman for the group organizing the protest, the Best Education Support Team, said members planned to continue the sit-in, despite the judge's order. ``They certainly feel that the order does not serve justice. They're going to stay there until justice rings,'' said BEST vice president Ronald Peoples. Smitherman has blamed the protest in part on the 25th anniversary of the Selma-to-Montgomery voting rights march, saying black leaders were trying to build interest in the march re-enactment by drawing fresh attention to the city. The commemoration of the 1965 march ended Saturday with about 3,000 people marching on the Alabama Capitol.

DOC.HEAD: Arrests of Sons in Rich Parents' Slayings Evokes Memories of Similar Cases
With AM-Mansion Murders
DOC.TEXT: The arrests of two brothers in connection with the slayings of their wealthy parents had a familiar ring to police, prosecutors and some readers of the popular press. It brought back memories of Ricky Kyle and the Billionaire Boys Club, two of the more notorious cases in Southern California involving murdered parents. But district attorney's spokeswoman Sandi Gibbons cited two others Friday: _In what became known as the ``Ninja'' or ``Yom Kippur'' case, Stewart Woodman was convicted of paying hit men to kill his elderly parents on the Jewish holiday in 1985 to collect $500,000 in insurance. He faces a possible death sentence; his brother Neil goes on trial in the case in April. _Jeffrey Percell goes to trial April 6, charged with the slaying of his 61-year-old parents, who were bound, gagged and shot in the head. The November 1988 slaying was the first in years in sleepy, prosperous Sierra Madre. But it is the Billionaire Boys and Ricky Kyle cases most brought to mind by the arrests of Lyle and Erik Menendez for investigation of murdering their father, Hollywood executive Jose Menendez, and their mother Kitty, a former beauty queen. Lyle Mendendez, 22, was arrested Thursday in the August slayings, in which the couple were found shot to death in their $5 million mansion. His 19-year-old brother surrendered to authorities Sunday. Henry Harrison ``Ricky'' Kyle Jr. was sentenced in June 1987 to five years in prison for killing his father, Texas millionaire Henry Harrison Kyle Sr. The elder Kyle was in many ways similar to the elder Menendez. Both were aggressive, hard-nosed businessmen. Menendez, a self-made multimillionaire, had fled the Castro regime in Cuba to become a top executive with RCA, Hertz, and finally the head of Live Entertainment, a big-time video outfit affiliated with the company that makes the ``Rambo'' pictures. Kyle had built a $100 million empire that included apartments, restaurants, dairy farms, a bank and a TV studio before heading to Hollywood in 1983 after buying Four Star Productions. Prosecutors alleged Ricky Kyle killed his father because he feared he would be cut out of his will after the father called him a cocaine-using liar and thief. He claimed he was searching for a prowler in the darkened dining room of the family's Bel-Air mansion when he mistook his father for the intruder and shot him to death. Kyle described his father as an abusive terror. After a first trial ended in a mistrial, a second jury convicted him of involuntary manslaughter. The Billionaire Boys Club was a nickname adopted by a group of scions of some of Southern California's wealthiest families who used their inheritances to bankroll risky investments. They were accused of a number of scams and murder plots, including the 1984 death of Hedayat Eslaminia, a one-time close associate of the Shah of Iran. Eslaminia suffocated, apparently accidentally, after he was abducted from his Belmont condominium and stuffed inside a steamer trunk for transport to Beverly Hills. Eslaminia's son, Reza, and another Billionaire Boy's Club member, Arben Dosti, were convicted of murder and kidnapping for extortion and conspiracy in the plot to kidnap the elder Eslaminia for his money and then kill him. They were sentenced to life in prison without parole. The club leader, Joe Hunt, was sentenced in July 1987 to life in prison without parole in the slaying of Ronald Levin. Levin, who had conned Hunt in a commodities investing deal, vanished in summer 1984. His body was never found.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine Survey Finds Conservationists, Business Groups Unimpressed
DOC.TEXT: Conservation groups gave President Bush an overall grade of D on an environmental report card compiled by U.S. News & World Report. Bush, who campaigned for president as an environmentalist, did not fare much better at the hands of business groups. They gave him a mark of C in the survey. The magazine, for its March 19 issue, asked 10 conservation groups and 10 business and industry organizations to rate Bush's performance in a dozen areas. Here are the results. The conservationists' grades are first, the business grades second: Clean Air: C-, C
Clean Water: C, C+
Wetlands: D, C
Public lands: D, B-
Marine environments: F, B-
Ancient forests: D-, C
Endangered species: C-, C
Wilderness and parks: D+, C
Toxic-waste cleanup: D+, C
Energy and resource conservation: D, B-
Enforcing environmental laws: C, B-
International leadership: D, C+

The magazine tallied the overall grades as a D and C. The conservation groups were: National Audubon Society, Center for Marine Conservation, Greenpeace, Izaak Walton League, National Parks and Conservation Association, National Recreation and Park Association, National Wildlife Federation, Nature Conservancy, Sierra Club, Wilderness Society. The business and trade groups were: American Business Conference, American Farm Bureau Federation, American Iron and Steel Institute, American Recreation Coalition, Edison Electric Institute, Multiple Use Land Alliance, Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association, National Coal Association, National Solid Waste Management Association, U.S. Chamber of Commerce.

DOC.HEAD: Key Events in Recent Chilean History
With AM-Chile, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of key events since Gen. Augusto Pinochet took power in Chile: Sept. 11, 1973 _ The elected Marxist goverment of President Salvador Allende is ousted by the military, headed by the commander in chief of the Army, Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Allende is believed to have killed himself with a machine gun in the besieged presidential palace when it became evident his government was falling. According to official figures, 2,796 people die, 750 disappear, and thousands are jailed. Dec. 17, 1974 _ Pinochet assumes the office of president. Under his rule, congress is suspended under a state of siege. A crackdown on leftists and dissidents is launched, earning Pinochet's government a worldwide reputation for human rights abuses. Sept. 11, 1980 _ Voters approve a constitution providing for a return to democracy after a minimum of eight years. The vote is marred by opposition charges of massive fraud. March 11, 1981 _ The new constitution takes effect. Sept. 7, 1986 _ Pinochet survives an ambush by pro-Communist guerrillas. Five bodyguards are killed. Oct. 5, 1988 _ Voters reject Pinochet's bid to extend his authoritarian rule for eight more years, until 1997. The vote clears the way for an open presidential election in December 1989. Pinochet is to stay in office until the elections and the installation of a new president. July 31, 1989 _ Chileans vote to approve a series of democratic reforms to the 1980 constitution. Dec. 14, 1989 _ Voters elect presidential candidate Patricio Aylwin, leader of the centrist Christian Democratic party. He is backed by a coalition of 17 leftist and centrist parties. Dec. 21, 1989 _ Aylwin asks Pinochet to step down as commander of the 60,000-member army, but the general refuses. His 1980 constitution gives Pinochet, now 74, the right to remain commander for another eight years. Jan. 9, 1990 _ Aylwin names an 18-member Cabinet dominated by centrists and moderates. March 11, 1990 _ Aylwin is inaugurated. Pinochet's critics and supporters rally on his last day as president. He remains military chief.

DOC.HEAD: S.C. Democratic Staff Chief Resigns After Calling Governor `Fascist'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Party Chairman ..., with 2 grafs to include earlier Connors remarks.
DOC.TEXT: The executive director of the state Democratic Party resigned one day after calling Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell a fascist. Hap Connors said he resigned Saturday to ``take the heat off'' the state's senior Democrats, Lt. Gov. Nick Theodore and former Gov. Dick Riley. ``It's unfair to put them in this spot,'' Connors said. State Republicans called Saturday for Theodore and Riley to denounce Connor's comment. A message left at Theodore's home was not returned and Riley's home telephone number is unlisted. A Campbell spokesman, Tucker Eskew, said he hoped the resignation would ``close the book on a very unfortunate chapter in South Carolina politics.'' Connors' comment came after a state representative and four county officials announced they were leaving the Democratic Party for the GOP. ``I'll call him a fascist,'' Connors said of Campbell. He also criticized his opposite number in the state Republican Party: ``I think Tony Denny, if he were a youth in the 1940s, he'd be wearing a brown shirt,'' a reference to Fascist uniform styles. In November, Connors said Democratic Party members were shunning Democratic state Sen. Theo Mitchell's run for governor not because Mitchell is black, but because of Mitchell's 1982 indictment for food stamp fraud. Party Chairman Frank Holleman, in announcing Connors' resignation, said the Mitchell comments as well as those on Campbell and Denny were occasions when Connors ``made statements that did not represent the views of the Democratic Party.'' Holleman also wrote Campbell and Denny to apologize for the remarks. Connors said he was unsure what he would do now, but hoped to ``do something a little more creative.''

DOC.HEAD: Rain in the Central U.S.; Snow in West
DOC.TEXT: Rain deluged parts of Texas, Kansas, Missouri, Oklahoma and Arkansas on Sunday, prompting the National Weather Service to issue flash flood watches across a broad region. Heavier rainfall totals for the six hours ending at 1 p.m. EST included nearly 2 inches at the Dallas and nearly 1{ inches at Oklahoma City. Flash flood watches were in effect for parts of north-central Texas, most of Oklahoma and parts of south-central and southeastern Kansas. Meanwhile, cold rain extended across the upper Mississippi Valley and the upper Great Lakes region, where temperatures were in the 30s and 40s Sunday afternoon. Flash flood watches also were in effect for northern Wisconsin, much of northern Iowa, parts of southeastern Minnesota and southern Wisconsin. A cold front brought snow and gusty wind to much of the western United States. Thunderstorms developing along the cold front produced 4 inches of snow in two hours at Salt Lake City and 5 inches at Austin, Nev. A winter storm warning was in effect for western Utah and the mountains of Utah. Up to 14 inches of snow was expected by Sunday night. Snow advisories were posted for portions of Nevada, California's northern Sierra Nevada, southeastern Idaho and areas of Wyoming and Montana and parts of the Colorado Rockies. Strong and gusty winds were recorded in Arizona and California. Strong winds were blew across the Texas panhandle and in the southwest corner of the state, where gusts reached 63 mph at Guadalupe Pass. Unseasonably warm weather prevailed from the southern and central Plains to the Atlantic coast. Temperatures were in the 60s in New England, in the 70s throughout the Ohio Valley and into the 80s across Florida. The nation's low Sunday was 14 degrees at Lakeview, Ore.

DOC.HEAD: Second Brother Arrested in Slaying of Video Exec, Wife
DOC.TEXT: The second of two sons charged with killing their millionaire parents at the family's mansion here quietly surrendered Sunday to waiting police at Los Angeles International Airport. Erik Menendez, 19, had arranged through his attorney to turn himself over to detectives, said Beverly Hills Police Lt. Bob Curtis. He had been playing in a tennis tournament in Israel. ``It was a very low-key thing,'' said Curtis. ``They met him at the airport and arrested him for the murder of his parents. ... I don't even know how many people noticed what was going on.'' Menendez and his brother, Lyle, are heirs to the $14 million estate of Jose Menendez, 45, an executive of a Hollywood video distribution company, Live Entertainment Inc. Menendez and his wife, Mary Louise ``Kitty'' Menendez, 44, were shot to death Aug. 20 in their $5 million mansion. The sons reported finding the bodies on returning from a night on the town. Lyle Menendez, 22, was arrested Thursday and held without bail pending a Monday arraignment. Erik Menendez, arrested about 1 a.m., was booked and taken to Los Angeles County Jail where he was held without bail. ``It was a voluntary surrender. Immediately upon being made aware of the allegations against him, he made arrangements,'' said Robert L. Shapiro, Menendez's attorney. His reaction to the murder charges ``is demonstrated by the fact that he has voluntarily come back to this country,'' Shapiro said. ``It shows tremendous character and strength to immediately face these allegations.'' Curtis said police didn't try to have Menendez extradited from Israel. Shapiro said he wasn't present at the airport when his client was arrested, but had kept officers informed of the progress of the flights, especially when there were delays in Europe. Curtis said he was uncertain whether court paperwork could be done in time for Erik to be arraigned with his brother Monday. Criminal complaints were filed against both brothers last week in Beverly Hills Municipal Court, charging them each with two counts of homicide. Curtis said the arrest of the two brothers ends the search for suspects in the case, but added the usual caution, ``We certainly aren't closed to the possibility there are others.'' Police have said two killers committed the crime, then picked up ejected shell casings from the .12-gauge shotguns they used before fleeing the scene. The Los Angeles Times reported Saturday that a friend found a spent .12-gauge casing in one of Lyle's jackets, and it was held as evidence. Police who served search warrants at a psychologist's office Thursday also obtained tape recordings, apparently of counseling sessions, which likely will be the subject of a court hearing for their admissibility.

DOC.HEAD: White House Urges U.S.S.R. to Let Lithuania Go
With AM-Lithuania Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration urged the Soviet Union on Sunday to ``respect the will of the citizens of Lithuania'' following the unanimous vote by the new Lithuanian parliament to secede from the U.S.S.R. The White House, in a statement released shortly after the dramatic vote in Vilnius, called upon Mikhail Gorbachev's government to undertake ``immediate constructive negotiations'' with the government of the breakaway Baltic republic. The United States said it also ``expects the government of Lithuania to consider the rights of its minority population.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, in a written statement, said: ``The United States has never recognized the forcible incorporation of the independent states of Estonia, Latvia or Lithuania into the U.S.S.R. We have consistently supported the Baltic peoples' inalienable right to peaceful self-determination. ``The new parliament has declared its intention to restore Lithuanian independence. The United States would urge the Soviet government to respect the will of the citizens of Lithuania as expressed through their freely elected representatives and expects the government of Lithuania to consider the rights of its minority population.'' Fitzwater added: ``The United States believes it is in the mutual interest of Lithuania, the Soviet Union and all CSCE countries to resolve this issue peacefully. We call upon the Soviet government to address its concerns and interests through immediate constructive negotiations with the government of Lithuania. We hope that all parties will continue to avoid any initiation or encouragement of violence.'' The CSCE is the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, also known as the Helsinki process. It includes all the nations of Europe except Albania, and also the United States and Canada. The Helsinki process, which produced pan-European agreements on arms control and human rights, is now being looked to for helping shape the new Europe in the wake of the dramatic shifts toward democracy in the East Bloc states. The United States has never accepted the Soviet Union's annexation of Lithuania and the other two Baltic states. The three states were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Russia had ruled Lithuania in the 19th century, but Lithuania had gained independence following World War II. Gorbachev, the Soviet president and communist party chairman, had urged the Lithuanians not to secede, warning that it could undermine his efforts to bring political and economic reforms to the entire Soviet Union. A Lithuanian diplomat said Sunday that Western governments are likely to wait to recognize Lithuania's declaration of independence until its leaders resolve disputes with Moscow and establish control over their country. Stasys Lozoraitis, charge d' affaires in Washington for Lithuania, said U.S. officials had told him beforehand ``they want to see the government take over effective control'' before formally recognizing it. ``All Western powers are inclined to wait,'' the Lithuanian diplomat said. But he predicted recognition could come ``after one month or two.'' Bush, like other American presidents before him, had reiterated the U.S. refusal to recognize the Soviet Union's annexation of the Baltic States. In an annual proclamation last June 14 declaring ``Baltic Freedom Day,'' Bush said: ``Since their forcible annexation by the Soviet Union in 1940, the people of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia have suffered political oppression, religious persecution and repression of their national consciousness. Their cultural heritage has been denigrated and suppressed, and Russification has threatened their survival as distinct ethnic groups. ``However, half a century of repression has not broken the spirit of the Baltic peoples. Today, their longing and hopes for liberty remain strong,'' Bush said in the proclamation. ``The future looks brighter today than at any other time in the Baltic States' postwar experience.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Shoots Wife, Turns Gun on Himself Inside Church
DOC.TEXT: A man apparently upset over divorce proceedings walked into a church Sunday, shot his wife twice, then turned the gun on himself as 55 churchgoers watched, authorities said. The woman, Tawanna Jo Lynch, 32, was shot twice in the head and was listed in critical condition at St. Anthony's Hospital in Oklahoma City, a hospital spokeswoman said. Her husband, David Leon Lynch, 31, was dead at the scene, he said. The shooting occurred at the Byng Freewill Baptist Church about 11 a.m., said Pontotoc County Undersheriff Jeff Glase. ``The family is going through a divorce. They split up a couple of weeks ago,'' Glase said. ``There's been a little tension about separating the property.'' Glase said that ``with as many witnesses as we have, unless something unusual develops it's a pretty open and shut case.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Calls for More Local Party Autonomy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with Gorbachev's remarks at plenum, no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev Sunday told Communists to prepare to fight for political leadership in a multiparty system and proposed rules that would increase autonomy of local party bodies but fall short of key demands by reformers. He spoke to the party's policy-making Central Committee as it met in the Kremlin on the fifth anniversary of Gorbachev's 1985 accession to power. It was also the eve of a special session of the Soviet parliament that was expected to elect Gorbachev to a vastly more powerful national presidency. In Vilnius, the capital of Lithuania, lawmakers Sunday night declared the Baltic republic independent from the Soviet Union. But there was no initial reaction to that bold move in state-run news reports of the Central Committee meeting at the Kremlin. Gorbachev, who serves both as president and Communist Party general secretary, asked the committee Sunday to formally propose that the parliament, the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies, revoke the party's legal monopoly on power fixed in Article 6 of the constitution. At a meeting late last month, the party leadership agreed in principle to that step. It would legalize a multiparty system throughout the Soviet Union and force Communists to compete for office in contested elections. The committee approved a proposal for the Congress on Article 6, as well as on another constitutional provision that awards the Komsomol Young Communist League, official trade unions and other sanctioned organizations a special role in ``managing state and public affairs,'' the official Tass news agency reported. Gorbachev proposed the party schedule a national congress for July 2. He is expected to use the meeting to further transform the party and weed out opponents of his campaign for ``perestroika,'' or economic and social restructuring. ``Of course, the fight for political leadership in the framework of democratic procedures, of election campaigns will now become one of the basic functions of the CPSU (Communist Party of the Soviet Union),'' Gorbachev told the Central Committee in remarks later distributed by Tass. The 248 party leaders that Soviet television said attended the closed-door meeting were given drafts of new party rules. Gorbachev said the rules would guarantee grass-roots party organizations the right to take independent approaches to problems and decide whom they should admit as members. They could also keep up to 50 percent of the party dues paid by members. But Gorbachev did not embrace demands by some Communist reformers for abolishing city and regional party committees. They customarily dominate local government authorities and grass-roots party organizations alike. Gorbachev said the fate of Communist parties in Eastern Europe showed the danger that arises when party organizations in cities and regions are dissolved. Significantly, the Soviet leader also failed to endorse mandatory election by rank-and-file Communists of delegates to the July party congress, which reformers say is necessary to prevent local party barons from imposing their slates. Gorbachev stressed that the party should be ``a union of like-minded Communists.'' He thus ruled out the possibility that factions would finally be admitted in party ranks in contrast to the practice laid down by Soviet founder Vladimir I. Lenin. Likewise, the new rules would permit the creation of a federalized party with independent organizations in the Soviet republics, as some party reformers wanted, Gorbachev said. But he said the republic-level parties would be granted ``real autonomy'' by the rules and a new party program that will be submitted to the July congress for adoption. Radicals and reformers inside and outside the Communist Party say that even if it is put on the same legal footing with other groups, the party will retain its dominant role in Soviet life.
