It does so through groups of Communists organized in government agencies, farms, army units, police precincts and virtually every other institution. Gorbachev repeated it was necessary for the July congress to endorse a new role for the party that would get it out of running day-to-day Soviet affairs. But he said party organizations based at the workplace would remain. He also staked out a special position in society for the Communist Party, even if its legal status is altered, as ``the ruling party, politically responsible before the people,'' and one that will not engage in ``trivial parliamentary games.'' According to the Interfax news agency of state-run Radio Moscow, the Central Committee will reconvene later in the week to nominate its candidate for the new presidency, presumbly Gorbachev, after the Congress of People's Deputies passes the constitutional amendments creating the post.

DOC.HEAD: Chile Restores Diplomatic Relations With Soviet Union, Eas Bloc Nations
With AM-Chile, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Only a few hours after its installation Sunday, the Chilean government of President Patricio Aylwin restored diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union, East Germany, Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia and Poland. Foreign Minister Enrique Silva, who signed the documents during separate ceremonies on behalf of Aylwin, said restoration of diplomatic ties with Cuba ``is still under consideration.'' Signing the documents for the Eastern European countries were officials who arrived in Chile to attend the Aylwin inauguration earlier Sunday in the port city of Valparaiso. They included two vice preidents, Valt Komarek of Czechoslovakia and Borislav Jovic of Yugoslavia. The East bloc countries broke relations with Chile immediately after the 1973 coup in which Gen. Augusto Pinochet toppled President Salvador Allende, a Marxist. Silva did not explain why relations were not immediately restored with Cuba. However, Aylwin has said that that will only happen if the Communist regime of President Fidel Castro stops supporting the Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front, a pro-Communist guerrilla group in Chile.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Declares Itself Independent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-14 bgng, `But outside...' with 14 grafs to UPDATE with lawmakers asserting control over police, Landsbergis quotes on talks with Moscow; pickup 15th graf pvs, `Gorbachev has....' EDITS thereafter to tighten.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos VIL1,NY5
DOC.TEXT: The Lithuanian parliament voted Sunday to break away from the Soviet Union and restore the independence the Baltic republic lost when it was forcibly annexed by the Kremlin 50 years ago. Legislators joined hands, raised them over their heads and chanted ``Lietuva, Lietuva,'' or ``Lithuania,'' after they voted to proclaim their homeland independent once more. The vote was 124-0 with six deputies abstaining. The move was not immediately recognized or sanctioned by Moscow, and legislators acknowledged that full independence would only be won after long, difficult negotiations with the Kremlin. The lawmakers also declared that the KGB and police now must take their orders from Vilnius, not Moscow. Outside the parliament hall, a small crowd broke into wild cheers over the declaration of independence. Earlier, the crowd ripped down a metal Soviet crest from the outside door of the legislative building and carted it away. Some stamped on it. ``That's the end of the Soviet regime,'' said a jubilant deputy looking on. ``Expressing the will of the people, the Supreme Council of the Republic of Lithuania decrees and solemnly declares the restoration of the exercise of the sovereign powers of the Lithuanian state, which were annulled by foreign force in 1940,'' said the legislative decree. ``And from this moment, Lithuania again becomes a sovereign state,'' it said. For Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the vote represented perhaps his biggest crisis yet on his fifth anniversary as Soviet leader and the eve of a national parliamentary session. The outgoing president of the Lithuanian parliament, Communist Party chief Algirdas Brazauskas, said before the vote that approval of secession could have a ``contagious effect'' on other republics. The would only add to Gorbachev's troubles, which already include rumblings for independence elsewhere, and serious economic problems and ethnic strife in many areas of the nation. Leaders of the pro-independence Sajudis political movement that dominates the new Lithuanian legislature acknowledged that full independence would have to be won in long, difficult negotiations. ``We have to sit down at the table,'' said the republic's new president, Vytautas Landsbergis. ``We're not going to be beating our fists, but we have to start settling accounts.'' Landsbergis, the chairman of Sajudis, earlier Sunday was the first non-communist to be elected president of a Soviet republic. The bearded 57-year-old music professor easily defeated Brazauskas. At a news conference after the close of Sunday's session, Landsbergis said talks with Moscow will start ``when the Soviet government adopts an appropriate decision on that issue.'' Lithuanians rushed to hold their session this weekend to establish their claim to independence before the national parliamentary session, which is expected to expand Gorbachev's powers to include declaring a state of emergency in a republic and suspending its parliament. However, Landsbergis told reporters: ``Perhaps the election of Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the post of president of the Soviet Union would make this problem easier and bring the date of the talks nearer.'' Gorbachev has told Lithuania that it will cost the republic $34 billion to pay for the factories and other infrastructure built during a half-century of Soviet rule. Lithuanians say their bill for decades of Soviet repression will be even higher. But Gorbachev and other Soviet officials have indicated the Kremlin may grudgingly accept Lithuanian secession. Tass, the official news agency, said the session ``temporarily'' recognized independent Lithuania's 1938 constitution as the supreme law of the land instead of the Soviet Constitution. In Washington, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the United States will urge the Soviet goverment to ``respect the will of the citizens of Lithuania.'' ``The United States has never recognized the forcible incorporation of the independent states of Estonia, Latvia or Lithuania into the U.S.S.R. We have consistently supported the Baltic peoples' inalienable right to peaceful self-determination,'' Fitzwater said. The Lithuania Supreme Soviet also changed the republic's name from the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic to the Republic of Lithuania and dropped its Soviet emblem. The deputies stood, applauded and then broke into cheers as a plain beige drape descended to cover a gold banner behind Landsbergis depicting a Lithuanian crest that included a Soviet hammer, sickle and star. They stood again as a former political prisoner in a traditional embroidered shirt presented the new crest, a white knight on a dark shield. Deputy Rolandas Paulauskas, a Sajudis editor from Kaunas, said the declaration of independence would not change anything immediately, but ``as a political act it gives a push to negotiations.'' He noted that Soviet Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov had reportedly told Lithuanians he would not be willing to talk about concessions concerning withdrawal of the Soviet Army until after such a political gesture. Justus Paleckis, ideology secretary of Lithuanian Communist Party, said Lithuania was assured of getting independence but ``real independence will only be achieved in some years.'' Sajudis-backed candidates had won a two-thirds majority in the first contested elections to the Baltic republic's 141-seat legislature. Several of the seats were not filled, but pro-independence activists decided not to wait for a full slate of deputies to be present before they called the legislature into session. Sajudis leaders decided it would be unfitting to re-elect Brazauskas now that his Communists were in the minority, said Sajudis activist Haroldas Subachius. Landsbergis received 91 votes for the presidency, with 42 against. Brazauskas got 38 votes, with 95 against. Brazauskas led Lithuanian Communists into splitting off from the Soviet party in December and joining the drive for restoration of the independence that the Ireland-sized state enjoyed between the world wars. But he favored a more gradual approach to breaking relations with Moscow. Lithuania, like the other independence-minded Baltic states of Latvia and Estonia, was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 while under Red Army occupation. On Friday, the Georgian parliament passed a resolution condemning the republic's annexation to the Soviet Union, mirroring moves already made in the Baltics.

DOC.HEAD: Inmate Killed Trying to Go Out with the Garbage
DOC.TEXT: An inmate killed when he tried to leave the state prison with the garbage was a victim of a policy that requires trucks to drive over refuse once it reaches the dump, a spokesman said Sunday. ``Obviously, we don't want inmates to escape,'' said Nevada State Prison spokesman Glen Whorton. ``Anybody who hides himself in the trash is running that kind of risk. It's one way to protect the public.'' Whorton said the purpose of the policy is to ``disable'' escapees and discourage other inmates from escaping that way. The body of Willis Walton, 26, was discovered at the dump Sunday. He apparently was crushed to death by the truck, authorities said. Whorton said it also was possible that Walton's death may have been caused by a bulldozer that subsequently moved the garbage and covered it with dirt. Walton was serving a 19-year sentence for burglary and possession of a controlled substance. He entered the prison in September 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Tank Explodes During Cleaning, Kills Three
DOC.TEXT: An empty petroleum storage tank at Kerr-McGee's Cotton Valley Refinery exploded while it was being worked on Sunday, killing the three men inside. The men were on a crew that was cutting the top off of the empty tank when a piece of equipment apparently ignited vapors inside, said Sheriff's Deputy Charlie Horton. Nearby residents said they heard what sounded like thunder, looked out and saw fire and smoke in the air. The fire was very brief and confined to the tank, Horton said. He was unable to identify the dead.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Postpones Decision, Shamir Blames U.S. Statements
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with Shamir saying he will fight any effort to bring down the government, SUB grafs 4-5 pvs, bgng, `Shamir, leader...' and INSERT 2 new grafs after 15th pvs, `What's the...' Pickup 16th pvs, `Secretary of...'
DOC.TEXT: Israel's Cabinet again failed to decide on a response to U.S. peace proposals Sunday, and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir blamed the United States for upsetting peace efforts with recent comments about the status of Jerusalem. An angry Vice Premier Shimon Peres left the nearly three-hour session of the 12-member Inner Cabinet after Shamir refused to call a vote and announced that a few more days of debate were needed. Peres, head of the center-left Labor Party, said he would seek a free hand from his party to break up the coalition governmment. Shamir, leader of the right-wing Likud bloc, indicated he was open to compromise and said he would fight any effort to bring down the government. After nearly six months of dicussing U.S. proposals, Perez said he viewed the lack of a decision as a rejection. ``What happened in the Cabinet today, no doubt, put an end to the possibility of conducting the peace process ... and put an end to the reason behind the National Unity Government,'' Peres said after the session. His actions made it almost impossible for the 15-month-old coalition government to continue without deciding soon whether to accept U.S.-sponsored peace talks with Palestinians. Prominent Palestinians also expressed exasperation at Israeli leaders who, for the second week in a row, failed to come to a decision on whether to start a peace dialogue. Faisal Husseini, a prominent Palestinian who has been mentioned as a possible negotiator, said: ``When they decide, yes or no, we would have something to talk about. But a government that cannot decide anything is just blocking the way.'' After caucusing with Labor Cabinet ministers, Peres announced he would ask the party's 1,300-member central committee Monday to empower the 39 Labor members of Parliament to ``take the necessary steps.'' The wording indicated Peres was seeking a flexible mandate that would give him room to coordinate a joint policy with Likud or vote in favor of a no-confidence motion that would bring down the government. Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, a Labor leader who has favored keeping the coalition together, said the burden was now on Likud to come up with an acceptable solution. He noted he had proposed a compromise, which involved giving Washington a positive answer and then hammering out an agreed Labor-Likud position on outstanding issues. ``Now it is (Likud's) turn,'' he said. ``The way I see it is the peace process is stuck.'' Speaking on Israeli Television, Shamir chastised Peres for seeking a ``hasty'' decision. ``What's the hurry? To break up the unity government which we have built with such efforts? So what if the discussion takes another day or week, will the world turn over?'' Shamir added that he would try to block any Labor attempt to form a narrow government. ``I shall try to convince parliament members and their parties not to help Labor in achieving this goal, but to vote against them if they try to bring down the government,'' he said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III's proposals for an Israeli-Palestinian meeting are meant to further Israel's proposal for Palestinian elections as a step toward peace. The Israeli plan was accepted in May. Shamir saved his harshest criticism for recent U.S. policy statements by President Bush and other officials opposing the settlement of Jews in the Arab sector of east Jerusalem, which Israel annexed in 1967. ``I hear the voices coming today from Washington on the issue of Jerusalem, things that enrage every Jew in Israel, and I have to react, I have to consider it,'' said Shamir. Shamir also said the Bush administration was trying to involve the Palestine Liberation Organization in negotiations. Israel views the PLO as a terror organization. ``I think the Americans did not act correctly or properly in their entire course of action related to the peace process,'' he said. Aides said the U.S. statements were behind Shamir's insistence that more debate and coordination with Labor is neccessary. Baker has made several proposals designed to get Palestinian and Israelis to talks in Cairo. These include a suggestion that east Jerusalem residents and exiled Palestinians be allowed into negotiations. Labor accepted the U.S. ideas, but Shamir remains opposed. He says participation of east Jerusalem residents would signal an Israeli willingness to discuss yielding control over the Arab sector, which the PLO wants as the capital of a Palestinian state. He also opposes having Palestinians who were deported from the territories sitting in on the talks. He says this would implicitly recognize the right of 3 million Palestinian refugees to return to homes that are now part of Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Showdown Set over Teacher Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with superintendent's decision to see what happens Monday, quotes from union officials. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `Late Saturday...'
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Gaston Caperton and the state's largest teachers union prepared for a Monday showdown. The union refused to end its strike and Caperton warned that teachers who stay off the job can be dismissed. State School Superintendent Hank Marockie called the 55 county school superintendents to Charleston on Sunday to detail what he said is their duty to punish teachers who continue the walkout. Marockie said he would wait to see how many teachers return to work Monday before deciding what action to recommend. Teachers are employed by county school boards, and it is up to the county school superintendents to take any action against striking teachers, including suspension or firing. ``The law's pretty clear,'' said Caperton, referring to a state attorney general's ruling that the strike is illegal. ``County superintendents will follow those rules and make it strict and the consequences are pretty bad.'' Meanwhile, the leaders of the two main teacher unions requested a meeting with Caperton. WVEA President Kayetta Meadows said communications between the governor's staff and her group have been ``distorted,'' leading to confusion about what has been offered by both sides. ``I think it's time that we as leaders set aside our differences and sit down and talk about the issues before this thing gets out of hand,'' said Bob Brown, executive director of the West Virginia Federation of Teachers. Gubernatorial spokesman G.C. Morse was out of his office and unavailable for comment on the request. Late Saturday, the 16,000-member West Virginia Education Association accused the governor of backing off a promise to call a special legislative session to discuss pay if teachers returned to work. Union officials sent word to county associations Sunday that the walkout was still on. Caperton said the union's contention that he promised to call a special session was ``a total lie.'' The strike began Wednesday and by Friday had spread to 40 of the state's 55 counties. Classes were canceled in 24 counties and sharply curtailed in the rest. Teachers voted overwhelmingly Saturday to return to work under several conditions, including that the governor call a special session within 30 days. ``The essence of the problem is the ballot that we sent out was very clear in stating, `Will you go back if the governor agrees to all of the following?' and he didn't,'' union executive director Dennis Giordano said Sunday. Gubernatorial spokesman G.C. Morse said Caperton would not agree to a special session under the threat of a continued strike but would consider one once the teachers returned. Attorney General Roger Tompkins ruled last week that the strike was illegal and said any teachers who walk off the job can be suspended, fired, barred from teaching for a year and charged with misdemeanors. Caperton on Friday recommended that striking teachers lose no pay or benefits if they returned to work Monday, but he said that offer won't be repeated if the strike continues. The West Virginia Federation of Teachers, with 3,000 members, recommended Saturday that teachers end their strike but said the decision was up to teachers in each county. The average West Virginia teacher salary of $21,904 ranks the state 49th in the nation, the association says. Teachers received a 5 percent raise from that figure in February, but objected when the governor provided no money in his 1990-91 budget for a further raise.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Activists Reported Detained in Cuba
DOC.TEXT: Cuban authorities rounded up seven political activists, including a leading human rights advocate, in a crackdown on dissent, sources said Sunday. Human rights groups have said there has been a general crackdown over the past year on groups seeking greater political freedom in communist Cuba. Samuel Martinez Lara, leader of the unsanctioned Pro-Human Rights Party, was detained Saturday, 17 days after completing a 10-month prison, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He was among a group of activists sentenced to prison terms a year ago for trying to organize a rally in support of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev during the Kremlin leader's visit to Havana. Also among the seven detainees was Tania Diaz Castro, who was released from prison last fall after serving a sentence for protest activities. She is not related to President Fidel Castro. There was no immediate official confirmation of the latest arrests. On two occasions last week, there were pro-government demonstrations in front of the homes of rights activists who were meeting with colleagues.

DOC.HEAD: International Efforts to Save Life of Condemned Journalist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with report that Jordan's King Hussein will try to help, INSERT new graf after 4th pvs, `A Foreign...' Pickup 5th graf pvs, `Bazoft, 31...'
DOC.TEXT: Journalists, relatives and government leaders appealed Sunday to Iraq to grant clemency to a London-based journalist sentenced to death on espionage charges and to a British woman ordered imprisoned for 15 years. A delegation of European Economic Community ambassadors went to the Foreign Ministry in Baghdad to make a ``humanitarian appeal'' on behalf of Farzad Bazoft and Daphne Parish, the EEC said in a statement. British Ambassador Harold Walker said he made a separate trip to the ministry to deliver a personal appeal from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. A Foreign Office spokesman said Britain would also be talking with its allies in the next few days ``to see what support they will give us in pressuring the Iraqis.'' King Hussein of Jordan, who met with Mrs. Thatcher on Sunday, volunteered to see what he could do to help, according to government sources quoted by Press Association, the British domestic news agency. Hussein is believed to have good relations with the Iraqi president. Bazoft, 31, was arrested in September and charged with spying for foreign powers after making an unauthorized trip to a military complex where a huge explosion had been reported. He was in Iraq on an assignment for the The Observer, a London newspaper. Mrs. Parish, 52, a senior nursing administrator for an Irish-run hospital in Baghdad, was accused of helping Bazoft by driving him to the Al-Iskandaria military complex south of Baghdad. She was sentenced to 15 years in prison. Under Iraqi law, no court appeal is allowed against the sentences. They were imposed by a revolutionary court Saturday after a closed trial. There was no indication when Bazoft might be executed. Observer editor Donald Trelford said he delivered a letter to the Iraqi Embassy on Sunday, calling on Ambassador Dr. Azmi Al-Salihi to urge Hussein to commute the sentences. Trelford said he had a ``heated exchange'' with the embassy's second-ranking official, whom he identified as Zuhir Ibrahim. ``He said that Farzad had taken soil samples from the military site and was therefore not acting properly. I argued I had heard nothing to suggest he had acted in any way other than as a journalist,'' said Trelford. Reports in London said as many as 700 people were killed in an explosion at the complex. The Iraqis later said 19 people were killed in a fuel depot blast. About 50 of Bazoft's friends and colleagues gathered outside the Iraqi Embassy, as did Michelle de Vries, the 21-year-old daughter of Mrs. Parish. ``Only two weeks ago I got a letter from the Iraqis saying the trial would be fair, which it has obviously not been,'' Miss de Vries said. Trelford said he stressed the innocence of both Bazoft and Mrs. Parish and requested that a representative of the newspaper be allowed to visit Bazoft. ``Farzad has no immediate family so his colleagues at the Observer are his family and we are asking to see him as members of a family should be allowed to,'' Trelford said. Bazoft is an Iranian exile who has lived in Britain since 1975 and travels on British documents. The British ambassador said in a British Broadcasting Corp. radio interview the Iraqi Foreign Ministry assured him Mrs. Thatcher's appeal ``would be passed on as a matter of urgency.'' He said the EEC delegation, consisting of the ambassadors of Ireland, France and Italy, and acting on behalf of all 12 member nations, was told the same thing.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Quake Hits Islands South of Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake with a preliminary reading of 5.5 on the Richter scale hit islands in the Pacific Ocean south of Tokyo early Monday, the Central Meteorological Agency said. There was no danger of tsunami, or tidal waves triggered by undersea disturbances such as earthquakes, according to the agency. Nor were there any reports of deaths, injury or damage, the Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department said. The agency said the epicenter of the quake, which occurred at 7:59 a.m., was about six miles under the seabed 180 miles south of Tokyo. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy an earthquake releases. Each increase of one number on the scale means the ground motion is 10 times greater; a measurement of 5 can cause considerable damage and 6 severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Four Die In Crash of Small Plane
DOC.TEXT: A single-engine plane crashed into a canyon during a storm, killing four people, authorities said Sunday. Sheriff's deputies said the plane, a single-engine Cessna, crashed and exploded at about 11 p.m. Saturday when it ran into a ridge in Topanga Canyon, said sheriff's Sgt. Jim Smith. All four bodies recovered from the wreckage were too badly burned to identify immediately, Smith said. The canyon is about 25 miles northwest of Los Angeles. The cause of the crash wasn't immediately known, Malibu area along with much of Southern California was struck by a fast-moving storm carrying wind and rain on Saturday night.

DOC.HEAD: Pinochet Steps Down, Aylwin Assumes Presidency of Chile
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT that Valparaiso is northwest of Santiago sted northeast, SUB 4th graf pvs, `To thunderous...' Pickup 5th graf pvs, `Chile returns...'
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Augusto Pinochet surrendered the government to elected President Patricio Aylwin on Sunday, ending 16{ years of military rule and completing South America's transition to civilian government. However, Pinochet remains chief of the 60,000-member army, despite a request from Aylwin that he give up that powerful post. Street celebrations of the partial return of democracy touched off scattered disturbances in downtown Santiago. Bands of leftist youths blocked streets with burning debris and clashed with police. More than 20 people were reported injured. To thunderous applause and cheers, Aylwin put on the red, white and blue presidential sash in the inaugural ceremony in Valparaiso, a seaport city 70 miles northwest of Santiago. ``Chile returns to democracy without violence, without blood, without hate,'' he later told supporters in Santiago. ``Chile returns by the road of peace.'' Aylwin's first official act was to pardon all political prisoners under the Pinochet regime. Pinochet shook the new president's hand at the inauguration and then quickly left the hall, where his entrance brought competing chants of ``Pinochet! Pinochet!'' and ``Murderer! Murderer!'' from the galleries. Upon the 74-year-old Army general's arrival for the ceremony, a group of protesters tossed tomatoes, stones and other objects at Pinochet's open-top limosine and shouted insults. The car, surrounded by military bodyguards, momentarily sped up. It bumped into a soldier on horseback, but no injuries were reported. A military band saluted Pinochet as he left the ceremony, held in a half-finished congressional palace being built to house an elected senate and house of deputies, which also assumed power Sunday. Under Pinochet, a military junta had acted as the legislature. Aylwin, a 71-year-old centrist politician, won elections in December. A Christian Democrat, he is backed by a coalition of 17 centrist and leftist parties. He has vowed to restore respect for human rights and civil liberties and put more emphasis on social services for the poor. But he plans no major changes in Pinochet's largely successful free-market economic program. Sunday evening, Aylwin stood on the balcony of the presidential palace in Santiago and urged Chileans to put aside differences and unite behind democracy. Hundreds of thousands of jubilant Chileans lined the route into Santiago from Valparaiso to cheer Aylwin's motorcade. They packed the square in front of the presidential palace, waving banners and chanting anti-Pinochet slogans. Just before Aylwin spoke, some celebrants broke through a police line beside the palace, and police scattered them with tear gas. First-aid workers at a nearby hotel treated three people overwhelmed by the gas and one man who was bleeding from the head, according to witnesses. As evening approached, people clashed with police up and down the capital's main boulevard. Authorities used tear gas and water cannons. Several people were seen bleeding or otherwise hurt, and local radio stations reported about 20 people injured. Police hauled off some protesters, but a police spokesman said he had no total for arrests. Pinochet was obliged to call the election when voters, in a 1988 referendum, rejected an extension of his rule to 1997. A clause in the 1980 constitution, written by Pinochet's administration, bars any new president from replacing him as army commander before 1998. Aylwin's term ends in 1994. Pinochet seized power in a bloody 1973 coup, ending a long democratic tradition in Chile. He toppled the elected government of President Salvador Allende, an avowed Marxist, during a period of economic and social turmoil. The general began his last morning as president by receiving Vice President Dan Quayle at his home in eastern Santiago for a 30-minute private meeting. Pinochet supporters outside booed and jeered Quayle. ``Gringo, understand, Chile isn't for sale,'' some chanted. Others held up signs saying, ``Go Home.'' Pinochet has bitterly criticized the United States for supporting the push for democracy in Chile and for cutting off weapons sales to Chile in 1976 because of systematic human rights violations. The arms embargo was proposed by Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., who came to Chile with Quayle and attended the inauguration. The embargo remains in effect. ``This is the dawn of a new era,'' Quayle said in Valparaiso. ``Democracy is here. We hope it is here to stay.'' ``I'm proud of what the Chilean people have done,'' Kennedy said. Chile is the last in a series of South American countries to restore elected civilian rule in the last decade, ending the dominance of authoritarian military leaders. Also in Chile for the inauguration was Joyce Horman, the widow of Charles Horman. He was an American free-lance journalist whose arrest and slaying during the 1973 coup inspired the movie ``Missing.'' According to the family and testimony collected by human rights groups, Horman was among many suspected dissidents held and executed at Santiago's National Stadium. The military government has denied the allegations. Mrs. Horman of New York was invited by the new government and was expected to attend several events surrounding the inauguration. In his first act as president, Aylwin decreed a pardon for all ``prisoners of conscience'' jailed by the Pinochet government. About 450 people are imprisoned for politically related crimes, although most are charged in connection with guerrilla activity. Aylwin has said he opposes freeing anyone guilty of blood crimes, and it was not immediately clear whom the pardon would affect. As the change in government was taking place, many foreign heads of state were arriving _ having delayed their visits until Pinochet's rule was formally ended. They included presidents Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela, Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua, Alan Garcia of Peru, and prime ministers Felipe Gonzalez of Spain and Giulio Andreotii of Italy. In Santiago, thousands of Pinochet supporters lined a two-mile stretch to bid him farewell before he attended a final military mass and flew off to the Valparaiso ceremony. ``You will return,'' many chanted. Some wept openly. The crowds repeatedly surged through police lines trying to touch the general, who was in an open car. The crowd grabbed and punched reporters accompanying Pinochet, who repeatedly has accused the press of unfairly attacking his rule and exaggerating human rights abuses. In Santiago, small bombs were tossed from moving taxis at or near the homes of three military officers, police said. Only minor damage was reported, and no one claimed responsibility for the attacks. Leftist extremist groups have operated in Chile for years, but it is widely speculated that many of the attacks attributed to them are carried out by right-wing organizations trying to dramatize the leftist threat.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle: Pinochet Pledges To Obey New Government
With AM-Chile Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts trafs 7-10, ``Meanwhile, Nicraguan xxx to update with Ortega news conference
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle, after receiving an unfriendly welcome from supporters of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, said Sunday the outgoing military ruler assured him he would obey Chile's new civilian government. Quayle, meeting with Pinochet on the last day of his 16{-year presidency, quoted Pinochet as saying ``there would be no problems between himself and President (Patricio) Aylwin _ when President Aylwin gave an order, that order would be complied with.'' Quayle was jeered by a throng of Pinochet supporters when he arrived for a 35-minute meeting at the general's walled residence. ``Go Away!'' they shouted. ``Son of a Whore!'' and ``Pinochet, Pinochet!'' Quayle waved to them as he got out of his limousine, apparently unaware that their shouts were unfriendly. There was no violence, but Secret Service agents canceled plans for Quayle to hold a sidewalk news conference near the demonstrators. Following the Pinochet meeting, the agents spirited him away in his limousine as the crowd booed and made thumbs-down gestures. Meanwhile, Nicaraguan president Daniel Ortega, who arrived in Santiago Sunday night, said he would like to meet with Quayle while here. `I think it will be a good opportunity to talk with Vice President Quayle,'' he said at a news conference when asked his reaction to Quayle's previous statements that he was willing to hold such a meeting. Until Ortega was voted out of office Feb. 25 and agreed to turn over power to his successor, Quayle and other Bush administration officials had avoided direct high-level talks with the Ortega government although the two maintained formal diplomatic relations. Quayle's chief of staff, Bill Cristol, attended the Ortega news conference and said: ``I suspect they'll (Quayle and Ortega) have a chance to talk one way or the other. We'll what happens tomorrow.'' Both men are scheduled to attend a luncheon Monday being hosted by Aylwin for all the visiting government officials. Pinochet still heads the Chilean military, and Quayle aides said the vice president told Pinochet the United States expected him to respect the new civilian authority. Pinochet has said he would honor Aylwin's authority but has indicated he would not necessarily consider other government officials his superiors. ``There was no debate. He knew who the people elected. He was willing to abide by the wishes of the people. I found that most encouraging,'' Quayle told reporters later. The vice president traveled to Valparaiso for Aylwin's inauguration later in the day on the third day of his South American trip. Quayle said he emphasized to Pinochet that ``his role in history is just beginning to be recorded.'' How he complies with the peaceful transition of government is as important to Pinochet's historical legacy, Quayle said, as the years of his presidency when widespread right-wing terror prevailed. Pinochet's regime came under increasing U.S. pressure to respect human rights and was subjected to a U.S. embargo on military aid and sales. U.S. officials traveling with Quayle said that, unlike most of the foreign representatives who came for Aylwin's inauguration, Quayle and the Bush administration had no qualms about a face-to-face meeting with Pinochet. Several other heads of state arranged go directly to the inaugural ceremony so they would not have to greet Pinochet. That included Venezuela's President Carlos Andres Perez and Spanish Prime Minister Philipe Gonzalez, both of whom Quayle met Friday in Venezuela en route to Santiago. But Quayle said Sunday morning that ``the right thing is to pay respects to the current president.'' U.S. officials who participated in Sunday's meeting described Pinochet as proud and unapologetic about the past but accepting of the election that brought his 16-year rule to an end. Pinochet wore a white military jacket and waved briefly from his balcony to his cheering fans. ``He was a very proud man. He's proud of what he's done for the people of Chile,'' Quayle said. Pinochet began the meeting by comparing himself to the reformers who are bringing democratic-style government to in Eastern Europe. ``Sixteen years ago, we did what is happening in Europe now. We weren't understood. What is happening with the Berlin Wall _ that happened to us 16 years ago,'' Pinochet said while posing for photographers prior to the Quayle meeting. Pinochet overthrew the elected government of Marxist President Salvador Allende in 1973. Thousands of Allende's supporters were rounded up and many were tortured or killed. Victims of the human rights abuses have vowed to press charges against the military once Aylwin takes office. A senior official traveling with Quayle said the disposition of those matters would be up to Chilean authorities. The Bush administration has emphasized human rights issues abroad, but ``we didn't come here to debate the last 17 years,'' the official said. However, Quayle and the other U.S. officials with him said the administration hopes to see progress under Aylwin on the prosecution in the 1976 assassination in Washington of Orlando Letelier, a former Allende cabinet minister. The U.S. government has pressed unsuccessfully for the prosecution of two Chilean military officers in that bombing. Quayle said, however, that issue did not arise in his meeting with Pinochet.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Threatens Strike, Though Hopeful on Transfer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with one more death; pickup graf 4 pvs `Opposition politicians...'
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ The opposition said Sunday it believes the military will yield power to a civilian-led government, but it threatened a general strike if ousted ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril stays in Haiti. At least 24 people had been killed in the seven days of protests and clashes that have left the government of this Caribbean nation in turmoil. Haiti remained under interim military control Sunday, the day after Avril's resignation. Soldiers firing from a speeding truck killed five people Sunday, radio report said. Elsewhere in the capital, news photographers said they saw police officers fatally shoot a young passer-by on a street and then prevent witnesses from trying to save his life. The state hospital reported treating 100 people, mostly for gunshot wounds, over the past two days. Opposition politicians, meanwhile, sought guarantees from a caretaker administration that there would be a transition to democratic rule with early elections for a civilian government. Haiti, one of the poorest countries in the hemisphere, has been ruled mainly by force of arms since it gained independence from France in 1804, and it would be the first time in its history that the civilian opposition has ruled. Maj. Gen. Herard Abraham, the army chief of staff, assumed control after Avril stepped down Saturday. He promised to yield power within 72 hours to a panel led by a civilian president that would organize elections for October. Avril, 52, was said to be at his home in suburban Port-au-Prince. Diplomatic sources speaking on condition of anonymity said Avril might leave the country in a matter of days. Unity Assembly, a coalition of 11 opposition parties and one civic group that was influential in Avril's downfall, had threatened an ``unlimited total paralysis of the country'' unless Avril resigned by Monday. At a news conference Sunday, the group issued a statement expressing confidence that Abraham would give up power. However, it called Avril a ``public danger'' and said it would not lift the strike call until the ousted leader left Haiti. ``The French and U.S. embassies say the matter of Avril's departure is settled, but only popular pressure will force him out,'' said business leader Antoine Izmery, a Unity Assembly member. Avril agreed to step down after negotiations reportedly involving the U.S. and French embassies, the Roman Catholic Church and opposition political parties. He had been in power 18 months. His resignation marked the Caribbean nation's fifth change of government since February 1986, when Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier fled into exile in France and ended the 29-year dictatorship of the Duvalier family. Thousands of people streamed into the streets Saturday to celebrate Avril's downfall, but scattered violence soon broke out. Roving gangs of youths reportedly ransacked the homes of at least three prominent sympathizers of the Avril and Duvalier regimes. Early Sunday, soldiers in a speeding pickup truck opened fire on pedestrians in downtown Port-au-Prince, killing five people, and then removed the bodies, independent Radio Metropole said. Later, the radio station said Army Maj. Renaud St. Bert was killed in a lottery booth in the suburb of Delmas. The report gave no details of the killing but said soldiers fired into the air to disperse a crowd there. Four people reportedly were killed last week in clashes with security forces. Radio reports Saturday said soldiers killed eight youths who attacked the home of a special police agent in suburban Port-au-Prince. Opposition politicians complained of the violence in the capital. They called for neighborhood self-defense groups to protect people from marauding gunmen. The opposition was at odds with the army over who would be named provisional president. The army's choice was Supreme Court President Gilbert Austin, 63, who said Saturday he expected to be appointed. Austin was appointed chief justice by Avril last year after serving as the general's justice minister. But Unity Assembly rejected him Sunday. It believes he has been too much under Avril's influence. The group has favored the court's vice president, Gabriel Volcy, but he is 74 and ill. The new president is to appoint a Cabinet approved by an 11-member advisory council made up of representatives of the Roman Catholic Church, civic, human rights and opposition groups, and one member of the army. United Assembly did not name an alternative choice for president. But conservative politician Gerard Philippe-Auguste said: ``Our first priority is a new provisional head of state. We don't have a government yet. When we do, we will tackle the problem of elections.'' Speculation that Avril might be on his way out began growing Monday after a soldier killed an 11-year-old girl, apparently accidentally during a demonstration. The killing set off violent anti-government protests across the country. Avril came to power in September 1988 in a coup by non-commissioned officers. He promised to hand over power to a civilian government after elections in October. But critics said a brutal crackdown in January on government critics made clear that Avril intended instead to make himself a dictator. After Jean-Claude Duvalier went into exile in 1986, he was replaced by Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy, Duvalier's army chief of staff and Avril's predecessor. A first election attempt in November 1987 was called off after thugs killed at least 34 voters. In January 1988, Leslie Manigat, a university professor, was elected president, but most opposition leaders refused to participate. Five months later, Namphy deposed him.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Cosby and Roseanne Barr Dominate People's Choice Awards
DOC.TEXT: Bill Cosby and ``The Cosby Show'' won three awards, and Roseanne Barr captured two at the 16th annual People's Choice Awards Sunday night. Meryl Streep, Tom Cruise and Dustin Hoffman got the top nod in motion picture categories, and ``Batman'' took two trophies in the awards, determined by a national poll. Musical honors went to Paula Abdul, Bobby Brown, Randy Travis and Kenny Rogers. Arsenio Hall won in the first-time category as favorite late-night talk show host for his syndicated show, beating out Johnny Carson and David Letterman. Cosby won his sixth straight trophy for favorite male television performer. He was also named as favorite all-around male entertainer. Miss Barr captured the same two awards in the female category, beating out Phylicia Rashad of ``The Cosby Show'' for favorite all-around female television performer. The awards, determined by a nationwide Gallup Organization poll, were announced during a two-hour broadcast on CBS. Twenty-two categories span the entertainment world, from television and film to music. Here is a list of winners: All-around female entertainer: Roseanne Barr. All-around male entertainer: Bill Cosby. Female TV performer: Roseanne Barr. Male TV performer: Bill Cosby. Young TV performer: Fred Savage. TV comedy series: ``The Cosby Show.'' TV dramatic series: ``L.A. Law.'' Male performer in a new TV series: Neil Patrick Harris. Female performer in a new TV series: Jamie Lee Curtis. New TV comedy series: ``Doogie Howser, M.D.'' New TV dramatic series: ``Rescue 911.'' Late-night talk show host: Arsenio Hall. Motion picture: ``Batman.'' Dramatic motion picture: ``Batman'' and ``Steel Magnolias.'' Motion picture actor: Tom Cruise. Motion picture actress: Meryl Streep. Male musical performer: Bobby Brown. Female musical performer: Paula Abdul. Country music performer: Randy Travis and Kenny Rogers. World motion picture actress: Meryl Streep. World motion picture actor: Dustin Hoffman. World comedy motion picture: ``Look Who's Talking.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Disciplined for Letting Tape Play in Court
DOC.TEXT: A federal prosecutor has been suspended without pay for two weeks for making public a secretly recorded tape that featured a reputed mobster boasting of bribing government officials, a newspaper reported. The tape, played in a Feb. 9 federal court detention hearing, sent several politicians scrambling to deny any wrongdoing. No charges have been filed against any of the officials named in the tape. The U.S. Justice Department suspended Jeffrey M. Johnson, a 17-year veteran prosecutor and an organized crime specialist with the U.S. attorney's office in Chicago, at the request of acting U.S. Attorney Ira Raphaelson, the Chicago Tribune reported, citing unidentified sources. The suspension began Monday, the paper said. Raphaelson refused to acknowledge the suspension, and David Runkel, a spokesman for the Justice Department in Washington, D.C., said he had no knowlege of it, the Tribune reported Saturday. Neither Johnson nor Raphaelson returned telephone calls from the Associated Press on Sunday. The tape, played at a detention hearing for five alleged mobsters, was recorded Sept. 14 by an alleged bookie-turned-government informant who was wearing a recording device. Featured on the tape was Rocco Infelise, a reputed crime syndicate gambling boss. Infelise spoke on the tape of making payoffs to law enforcement officials and influencing the last Chicago mayoral race. He also said he had been making $35,000 in payoffs to police and officials each month, including $10,000 a month to the sheriff's office through somebody called the Bohemian. An IRS agent said in court that the informant, William Jahoda, who was also indicted, had identified the Bohemian as James Dvorak, a former top aide in the Cook County sheriff's office and still chairman of the Cook County GOP. Dvorak, as well as others named in the tape, denied the accusations. Infelise and others who were subjects of the detention hearing were among 20 people charged in indictments alleging that violence and threats were used to run a gambling operation. Raphaelson asked for the suspension after Dvorak complained to government officials that the tape cast him in an unfair light and lent credence to Infelise's boasts, the Tribune said. Dvorak denied he had anything to do with the suspension. Infelise had also boasted on the tape that he helped Chicago Mayor Richard M. Daley win election last year by discouraging campaign contributions to a Daley opponent. Daley dismissed the statement as a fabrication.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Ends Visit to Tanzania, Heads for Sweden
DOC.TEXT: A weary Nelson Mandela dined with President Ali Hassan Mwinyi Sunday before heading to Sweden, the last stop on a five-nation tour to visit supporters of his movement for black majority rule of South Africa. Mandela, 71, was to take a late-night flight from this East African capital to Stockholm. Visibly tired, Mandela was seen by doctors Saturday evening in the Tanzanian town of Morogoro, home to about 2,500 South African refugees and a school and training camp run by his African National Congress guerrilla movement. ``He's no longer a 41-year-old,'' Solly Rathabe, an ANC spokesman, said Sunday. ``He was tired, and we called doctors to check him. He's not sick; he's just tired.'' Rathabe denied reports that Mandela would shorten his visit to Sweden, where he will visit ANC president Oliver Tambo, who is being treated for a stroke he suffered late last year. Rathabe said Mandela will remain there a full five days ``and might even extend his stay.'' A Swedish Foreign Ministry spokesman said last week that Mandela planned to cut short his visit. The Swedish National News Agency attributed the reported move to his concern over recent violence in South Africa's black homelands that has taken more than 200 lives. Mandela was named deputy president of the ANC shortly after his release last month after 27 years in South African prisons. With Tambo ill, the appointment made Mandela the virtual head of the ANC, the leading group in the fight against South Africa's white government and its policies of racial discrimination. On his last day of a six-day visit in Tanzania, Mandela toured the ANC's Solomon Mahlangu Freedom College in Morogoro, named for an ANC guerrilla executed in 1979. He then flew by helicopter to Dar es Salaam, where he had a private dinner with the president. Since being freed by South African President F.W. de Klerk on Feb. 11, Mandela has kept an exhausting schedule. His current trip has also taken him to Zambia, Zimbabwe, and Ethiopia for public rallies and conferences with government and African leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Space Shuttle Atlantis Delayed in Texas Because of Storms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with shuttle's return trip to Florida halted in Texas because of bad weather. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Atlantis touched...
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Atlantis, strapped to the back of a Boeing 747 for a return trip to Florida was grounded at Biggs Army Airfield Sunday because of storms, officials said. The piggyback plane and shuttle landed here at 12:15 MST, after taking off from Edwards Air Force Base, 60 miles north of downtown Los Angeles, at 9:02 a.m. PST. Storms across the South forced posponement of the rest of the trip, and NASA officials said they would decide Monday when the shuttle could continue its return trip to Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Atlantis touched down at Edwards on Wednesday, completing a secret four-day, 10-hour military mission that included the release of a $500 million spy satellite. It reportedly will be able to deliver high-resolution photographs and eavesdrop on communications. The next shuttle flight is scheduled for April 12 when Discovery is to begin a five-day mission to deploy the $1.55 billion Hubble Space Telescope. Atlantis' next flight in space is another Defense Department mission, set for July 9.

DOC.HEAD: Aide to Assassinated Candidate Claims Win in Colombia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE Gaviria's rivals conceding defeat, early vote compilations by RCN, other details; pickup 12th graf pvs, `Gaviria, an...'
DOC.TEXT: ADDS 1 graf at end of story with constitutional referendum results; no pickup.

An aide to a leading presidential candidate killed by drug traffickers claimed victory Sunday in primary elections for the governing Liberal Party's presidential nomination. No official results were released Sunday night but all five of Cesar Gaviria's political rivals conceded defeat in the nation's first presidential primary. The election and others for federal, state and local office followed a night of political violence that left six people dead. A leftist guerrilla from a group trying to disrupt the elections was killed Sunday, military officials said. In the capital, Bogota, the leader of a leftist group that laid down its arms this week won a surprising 9 percent of the vote in the mayor's race, according to an exit poll. Gaviria, 43, won more than 58 percent of the votes cast in the race for the centrist Liberal Party presidential nomination, a wide margin over his rivals, according to an exit poll of 150,000 Colombians conducted by the RCN radio network. ``This backing from the Colombian people makes me very happy,'' Gaviria told reporters at his Bogota campaign headquarters. ``I never thought I would win by such a wide margin.'' Gaviria faces the opposition Conservative candidate, Rodrigo Lloreda, in the May 27 presidential elections. Party leaders previously selected the Liberal Democratic presidential candidate at a closed convention. Lloreda was chosen at a Conservative Party convention in November. About 13.8 million Colombians, 18 years or older, were eligible to vote Sunday. Colombians elected all 313 members of the nation's bicameral legislature, 9,042 city councilmen, 1,009 mayors, and 421 state assembly members. There were a total of 1,009 polling districts. The National Voting Registry did not release vote counts but said preliminary results indicated the Liberal Party would mantain its majority in both the House and the Senate. The party previously held 67 of the 114 Senate seats and 111 of the 199 House seats. RCN said late Sunday that its count from regional election boards showed Gaviria winning 60.1 percent of the early vote, 403,611 to 671,478 for his rivals. Gaviria's closest opponent, Ernesto Samper, received 123,917 votes, or 18.45 percent, according to the RCN compilation. Gaviria, an economist by training, was managing the presidential campaign of Sen. Luis Carlos Galan when the candidate was killed by drug traffickers on Aug. 18. ``This was Luis Carlos Galan's victory,'' Gaviria declared late Sunday. The assassination touched off a war between Colombian drug lords and the U.S.-backed government of President Virgilio Barco. Barco cannot run for re-election under the constitution. The presidential term is four years. Gaviria decided to seek the Liberal Party's nomination several weeks after Galan was killed and pledged to carry out Galan's reform platform if elected. He has also promised to carry out Barco's anti-drug campaign. Gaviria is associated in the minds of many Colombians with a campaign to open the country's political system to more participation by the masses. The only fatal incident during the elections occurred when police shot and killed a member of the leftist National Liberation Army in the southeastern town of Puerto Nidia, said Gen. Nelson Mejia, the commander of the country's armed forces. Leftist guerrillas attacked voting booths in at least six towns and prevented balloting in four towns, Mejia said in a radio interview. The National Liberation Army has carried on a campaign of violence in the last two months to disrupt elections in several of the country's rural regions. Late Saturday, members of the rebel group assassinated two police officers guarding voting precincts in Chaparral, a town 125 miles south of Bogota, according to Tolima state police. Nevertheless, elections went ahead in the town without further incident, according to RCN. In his campaign for the presidential nomination, Gaviria supported Barco's anti-drug war. But he indicated that his administration, after reforming the country's judicial system, may try traffickers in Colombia rather than extradite them to the United States. Barco's administration has extradited 14 drug suspects since it intensified a campaign against the country's cocaine cartels following Galan's death. Traffickers responded with 262 terrorist attacks, mostly bombings, that killed 209 people. They called a unilateral truce in the drug war on Jan. 17 and have said they are willing to surrender their illicit business and themselves if the government scraps its extradition policy and promises to try them in Colombia. Barco, aware that traffickers have been able to evade Colombian justice by bribing and killing judges, has publicly refused to include the policy in any negotiations. The Liberal Party's candidate for mayor of Bogota, Juan Martin Caicedo, was expected to recapture the capital's top post from the Conservative Party, according to preliminary results. Former leaders of a leftist guerrilla group _ April 19 Movement, or M19 _ campaigned in many races Saturday hours after signing a treaty with the government that ended their 16-year insurgency. RCN said Carlos Pizarro, the leader of the group, won 9 percent of the vote in the Bogota mayor's race. The Liberals were expected to lose mayor's races to the Conservative Party in two other cities, Cali and Barranquilla, according to the RCN exit poll. Cali is home to Colombia' second-largest cocaine cartel. According to preliminary results, a majority of voters approved a non-binding referendum to call a convention to reform the country's constitution. Changes would be aimed at increasing political participation through voting reform and reducing political patronage.

The chairman of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee on Sunday called for a one-year government spending freeze _ including Social Security benefits _ and new taxes on gasoline, alcohol, tobacco and the wealthy. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., said his proposal would reduce the federal deficit by more than half a trillion dollars over the next five years, producing slight government surpluses in 1994 and 1995. Just in fiscal 1991, which begins next October, Rostenkowski said his package would cut the deficit from $161 billion as projected by the Congressional Budget Office to $106 billion. The next year, the deficit would fall to $39 billion under his proposal, instead of $124 billion as projected by the CBO, he said. Rostenkowski estimated the 1991 spending freeze alone _ including no cost-of-living adjustments, or COLAs, in Social Security and other programs except those covering the very poor _ would save $105 billion over five years.

Israel's Cabinet again failed to decide on a response to U.S. peace proposals Sunday, and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir blamed the United States for upsetting peace efforts with recent comments about the status of Jerusalem. An angry Vice Premier Shimon Peres left the nearly three-hour session of the 12-member Inner Cabinet after Shamir refused to call a vote and announced that a few more days of debate were needed. Peres, head of the center-left Labor Party, said he would seek a free hand from his party to break up the coalition governmment. Shamir, leader of the right-wing Likud bloc, indicated he was open to compromise and vowed to do all he could to save the government. After nearly six months of dicussing U.S. proposals, the Labor leader said he viewed the lack of a decision as a rejection.

Brash and sometimes bumbling criminals have staged a rash of bank robberies in Ohio's capital city and its suburbs. The Columbus area, with a population of about 1.2 million, has had 42 bank robberies this year, more than Chicago, Detroit, Pittsburgh and Cleveland combined. ``Why are there so many bank robberies? Frankly, right now we don't have a clue,'' said FBI agent Douglass Ogden. ``If we knew that, we'd stop them.'' Authorities suspect many of the robbers are down-and-out drug addicts looking for quick cash.

The sheriff of this mountain county says he's stopped the old custom of giving away seized moonshine for home remedies since his arrest, even though a grand jury has refused to indict him. ``I ain't done nothing nobody else had done,'' said Madison County Sheriff Dedrick Brown, who was arrested after giving friends six half-gallon jars of ``white lightning'' in front of a state investigator. His supporters, including Republican Gov. Jim Martin, say the practice dates back a century or more and his arrest was politically motivated. The arrest was made by agents of the State Bureau of Investigation, which is headed by a Democrat. Not everyone in Madison County agrees, however, with the grand jury's decision not to indict Brown on charges of destroying criminal evidence.

The Lithuanian parliament voted Sunday to break away from the Soviet Union and restore the independence the Baltic republic lost when it was forcibly annexed by the Kremlin 50 years ago. Legislators joined hands, raised them over their heads and chanted ``Lietuva, Lietuva,'' or ``Lithuania,'' after they voted to proclaim their homeland independent once more. The vote was 124-0 with six deputies abstaining. The move was not immediately recognized or sanctioned by Moscow, and legislators acknowledged that full independence would only be won after long, difficult negotiations with the Kremlin leadership. But outside the parliament hall, a small crowd broke into wild cheers. Earlier, the crowd ripped down a metal Soviet crest from the outside door of the legislative building and carted it away. Some stamped on it.

Gen. Augusto Pinochet surrendered rule to elected President Patricio Aylwin on Sunday, ending 16{ years of military rule and completing South America's transition to civilian government. To thunderous applause and cheers, Aylwin put on the red, white and blue presidential sash in a ceremony in this seaport city, 70 miles northeast of Santiago. To begin his presidency, Aylwin pardoned all political prisoners under the Pinchet regime. Pinochet shook the new president's hand at Sunday's inauguration and then quickly left the hall, where his entrance sparked competing chants of ``Pinochet! Pinochet!'' and ``Murderer! Murderer!'' from the galleries.

DOC.HEAD: Two Months After Radical Change, Poland Adjusting to Shocks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Two months into their switch from communism to capitalism, Poles have more to buy with less money, inflation and production are down and unemployment is up. That's just as expected, the planners say. Deputy Premier Leszek Balcerowicz, who devised the program, said there were no surprises so far and his assistants in the Finance Ministry agreed. ``I can see absolutely no reason why we should change our policy,'' Marek Dabrowski, undersecretary of finance, told the government newspaper Rzeczpospolita. On Jan. 1, the Solidarity-led government put an economic plan into effect that involved a sharp initial increase in prices, holding down wages, devaluing the currency and making it convertible, and stopping subsidies and easy loans to state enterprises. Its first stage is intended to make prices realistic and bring inflation of 700 percent a year under control with a tight money policy. In the second stage, the goal is to reform the economy, now 80 percent state-owned. This would be accomplished by forcing inefficient companies to shape up or close, selling state concerns to private owners, breaking up monopolies, and removing barriers to free enterprise. When the plan took effect, coal prices rose 600 percent overnight, electricity 400 percent, gasoline 200 percent and food 100 percent to 200 percent. Costs of food, manufactured goods and services continued to climb until late January as the higher prices of energy and raw materials were passed on. Figures for January showed average prices up nearly 79 percent from December. Communist governments had raised prices, but none was as successful in holding down wages. Families had to adjust instantly to what the government statistics office said was a 43 percent decline in real incomes in January. By the program's third week, a fundamental change became evident. Prices reached levels at which consumers were unable or unwilling to buy goods. Suddenly, there were no more lines at gas stations. Getting a table in a restaurant was easy, and international telephone lines were open more frequently. Furniture stores, empty before, filled with merchandise. Butcher shops were full of sausages and a bicycle could be bought without waiting weeks. Stores cut back orders because of full inventories. Producers became desperate for cash. There were no more subsidies or government bailouts and the new loan rates were too high. Producers and manufacturers started to bypass the middleman and sell directly to the public. Trucks loaded with meat, eggs, butter, sugar, shoes, clothes, plumbing supplies, TVs and other products now park outside stores and markets. After decades of rudeness from employees of state stores, consumers welcome the competition for their trade. ``I prefer to buy here because I can at least choose and complain if I don't like a piece,'' said Krystyna Wilczyk, shopping at a meat truck outside the Hala Mirowska market. Partly in response to low prices on the trucks, food stores began cutting prices. The price of an egg had risen to the equivalent of 6 cents, but soon fell to 3 cents. Many people still prefer the trucks. ``Even if it's not that much cheaper anymore, at least you know it's fresh,'' Jolanta Budzak said outside the Hala Mirowska market. Some stores are having sales, a Western phenomenon new to Poland. A major department store introduced another novelty, letting customers pay in installments. Inflation is dropping from its peak in late January. Wojciech Misiag, another undersecretary of finance, told reporters March 2 that prices rose only about 1 percent a week in February and similar figures were expected for March. Deputy Premier Balcerowicz wrote cautiously in mid-February: ``We are relatively close to the goal of suppressing inflation, but it is too early for fanfares. It is necessary to keep the harsh rules ... in force.'' Tight money and slow sales have squeezed manufacturers. Unsold merchandise is backing up in their warehouses. Government figures indicate production fell in January and February. The slowdown is being reflected in worker layoffs. Unemployment was virtually unknown under Communist rule, but 55,000 workers were registered as jobless in January and more than 152,000 in February. Benefits for 400,000 unemployed were budgeted under the new program, but the government now says the number may surpass 1.7 million in a work force of about 18 million. Lowered production has been criticized, but manufacturers and farmers say they cannot maintain output without lower-cost loans. Although the government says easing up now would invite renewed inflation, Balcerowicz said in a recent interview: ``While some recession was inevitable and we expected it, we must defend ourselves from a really deep recession.'' Another criticism, voiced by Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, is that Balcerowicz has been too slow in converting the economy to private ownership. Legislation to accomplish the conversion has been written and will go to Parliament soon. The government has devalued the zloty by 38 percent, to 9,500 to the dollar, and the national bank proclaimed full convertibility Jan. 2, supported by a $1 billion loan from Western countries. For decades, the real value of the of the zloty was one-fourth the official rate. Traders have accepted the level and no black market has emerged to sell the Polish currency more cheaply. The national bank said it had not used any of the $1 billion fund because the market remained in balance. ``Our guess was perfect,'' Balcerowicz said. ``Success in this respect was extremely important for the whole economic program, including prices, because a stable exchange rate means ... prices of imported goods do not go up.''

DOC.HEAD: No Coins For The Pay Phone, No Room For The Stamps
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: One woman reported canvassing shops for a half-hour to find the right coin to make a one-minute telephone call. Another had to paste stamps across most of the front _ and half the back _ of the envelope to amass enough postage for her letter to London. Then there are the new public transit ticket machines, rendered virtually useless because the fare rose to 480 zlotys. The chances of finding 24 of the largest coin available _ 20 zlotys _ are about nil. And so it goes, as Poland adjusts its money and postage to the real prices of doing business. Triple-digit inflation has accompanied a massive overhaul of the economy, which included removing government budget subsidies long used to keep prices artificially low. The largest bill in circulation is worth 200,000 zlotys, or $21, and was issued in November. A 100,000 zloty note worth $10.50 went into circulation last month. Higher denomination postage stamps are being created, with the largest now worth 1,000 zlotys, or nine cents, about one-sixth the cost of an express letter to London. But until the larger denomination stamps are produced and circulated, extensive licking and pasting will be required. Tales of post office chaos are widely traded, including one about the man sent home to re-package his goods so the box would be big enough to accommodate all the stamps. The new box he returned with weighed more, and it was not big enough to take the additional stamps. With 20 zlotys worth 0.2 cents, coins have been rendered virtually obsolete except for use in pay telephones. When the price of a call was raised last year from five zlotys to 20, the pay telephones were adjusted to accept only one of the three sizes of 20 zloty coins in circulation. ``We did not know it would be so hard to find them,'' said Maciej Zdzieniecki, spokesman for the Polish telephone company. ``It was a surprise. We adjusted the phones to this new 20 zloty coin and it turned out they were in short supply.'' The lack of proper coins for pay phones is no small problem in a country where home telephones are scarce. Reports from the World Bank and other sources put the number of telephones at 10 to 12 per 100 people, the lowest in Europe except for Albania. ``It is impossible to make a call,'' sighed Iwona Terlikowska, a psychologist waiting at the bank of pay phones in Warsaw's main post office. A young man with no telephone at home said he had waited 30 minutes to get a bill changed to 20 zloty coins at the post office. ``You have to get here very early to get change, or they run out,'' he said. A black market has developed in the 20 zloty coins, although Zdzieniecki said reports they were selling for up to 400 zlotys apiece were exaggerated. The telephone company is hurrying to introduce tokens but the spokesman said delays at the mint have postponed production.

DOC.HEAD: More Emphasis on Organic Farming Advocated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Agricultural researchers would spend more time looking for ways to help farmers cut their use of chemicals under a bill by Sen. Tom Daschle, D-S.D. Contending the government has disregarded efforts to promote sustainable agriculture _ sometimes called organic farming _ Daschle wants to broaden the Agriculture Research and Extension Service's environmental goals as part of the 1990 farm bill. Daschle's proposal would require the Agriculture Department to direct at least 30 percent of its competitive research grants toward using crop rotation and mechanical cultivation techniques rather than chemicals and pesticides for controlling weeds, predators and insects. Co-sponsored by Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., it also would establish boards for coordinating and assessing research needs and activities. ``The Secretary should take a proactive role on research, extension and education on sustainable agriculture,'' the proposal says. The Bush administration's 1990 farm bill proposals recognize an increased interest in sustainable agriculture but recommend no initiatives beyond the rather small research program now under way. The bill will establish the nation's agriculture policy for the next five years. A report last week by Congress' Offike of Technology Assessment said the Agriculture Department needs to focus more on sustainable agriculture and change its traditional research and extension service approach. ``Agriculture research is a form of social planning,'' said Chuck Hassebrook, a policy analyst with the Sustainable Agriculture Coalition, a group supporting Daschle's bill. ``Decisions about how public research dollars are spent and what farming systems technologies are developed go far in shaping life in rural communities,'' Hassebrook said.

DOC.HEAD: Reform Issues Thoroughly Aired At Futures Meeting
DOC.TEXT: The battle to reform the futures markets returns to Washington after last week's gathering of the industry's largest trade group. A House committee vote is scheduled for Tuesday on a measure to give the Securities and Exchange Commission limited jurisdiction over stock-index futures. And Sen. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., says he will soon introduce a bill creating a bridge between the SEC and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which regulates futures trading, although the agencies would retain their separate jurisdictions. Such controversial issues as dual trading and user fees also got a workout during the three-day annual meeting of the Futures Industry Association here. Congressional debate on those matters should heat up after Easter, when the Senate is expected to vote on reauthorization of the CFTC. Rep. Edward Markey, D-Mass., one of about 20 federal legislators who spoke at the meeting, said Saturday that the House Energy and Commerce Committee would vote Tuesday on his bill giving the SEC temporary jurisdiction over stock-index futures during periods of ``extraordinary volatility,'' such as when the Dow Jones industrial average plunges 200 points in an hour. The SEC has long sought jurisdiction over stock-index futures, financial instruments regulated by the CFTC that allow investors to trade contracts representing the cash value of stocks without ever owning the stocks themselves. Some experts believe stock-index futures trading causes volatility in the stock market, especially when they are used in computer-driven program trades involving huge amounts of stocks and futures contracts. Markey, who chairs an energy subcommittee on finance, has been critical of the CFTC in the past. He called his proposal a step toward a more permanent solution, which he hopes to bring about as a moderator in negotiations between the securities and futures industries. ``In the end, some central responsibility is the goal,'' he said. The 1987 stock market crash and the unusually high degree of market volatility since then have resulted in a number of measures aimed at better coordinating the movements of the stock and futures markets. Dixon, who chairs a Senate subcommittee on regulatory affairs, said this intermarket ``harmonization'' would be enhanced by his plan to make one SEC commissioner a member of the CFTC and one CFTC commissioner a member of the SEC. ``This kind of cross-membership will help further encourage the kind of regulatory cooperation we have already seen ... and will institutionalize their working relationship,'' he said. Dixon, a friend of Chicago's powerful futures exchanges, suggested that cross-membership also would quiet critics who say the CFTC is too close to the futures industry to be an effective regulator. Markey expressed opposition to Dixon's plan, saying he ``would prefer a more formalized resolution of the problem.''

DOC.HEAD: Bonwit Teller Stores Sold; Name Likely to Survive
DOC.TEXT: The Pyramid Companies will buy five Bonwit Teller stores in an agreement that is likely to ensure the survival of the elegant chain's name, according to a published report. Sale of the stores, owned by financially troubled L.J. Hooker Corp., must be approved by a federal bankruptcy court, The New York Times reported in Sunday's editions. L.J. Hooker, which filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Code last August, owned B. Altman & Co., another elegant New York-based retail chain. Hooker liquidated six Altman stores in January after the stores failed to draw acceptable bids. The Bonwit stores Pyramid intends to buy are located in Boston, Buffalo, Manhasset, N.Y., and Short Hills, N.J. Two others will operate in Cincinnati and Columbia, S.C., the Times said. L.J. Hooker plans to try to sell the remaining nine Bonwit stores, the Times said. Pyramid is a Syracuse-based private company that operates 16 malls in New York and Massachusetts. The purchase price was not disclosed, but the Times noted it was a cash transaction and did not involve any debt. Estimates within the retail industry put the pricetag on the deal at about $17 million, the Times said. Bonwit was founded in 1895 as a small Manhattan millinery shop and grew into one of America's most respected fashion retailers. But it had not earned a profit for at least a decade, partly because its corporate owners were reluctant to pay for improvements and expansion. Retail executives said they expect Pyramid to sell more moderately priced clothes at Bonwit than what has been sold there in the past. L.J. Hooker is the U.S. arm of Australia's Hooker Corp. The Sydney-based parent company last autumn revealed severe cash flow problems due to high interest rates and a sagging real estate market in Australia. The company now is being liquidated.

DOC.HEAD: Leipzig Industrial Fair Focuses on German-German Links
LaserPhoto LEI1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Leipzig Trade Fair opened Sunday, providing the first major meeting ground for West German firms rushing to link with partners in East Germany since the collapse of Communist control. The spring edition of the twice-yearly fair, which focuses on industrial machines and electrical equipment, comes at a time when both Germanys are moving steadily toward de facto economic unity. Few cooperation agreements are expected to be signed, however, before the March 18 parliamentary elections in East Germany. Small and middle-sized Western firms are especially prominent at the week-long fair, which East German Economic Minister Christa Luft dubbed ``a marketplace of new chances.'' West German companies increased their presence by about 25 percent over last year, accounting for some 1,000 of the show's 9,000 displays by manufacturers from 60 countries. Hans Modrow, Communist premier of the East German caretaker government, rejected recent West German charges that his country is not moving quickly enough toward a market economy. ``There is no way Modrow could act as a brake,'' the premier said as he walked through the fair. Modrow appealed to West German industrialists to work together with his country's struggling firms. ``Have faith in us,'' he said. On the fringes of the fair, Adam Opel AG, the West German arm of U.S. automaking giant General Motors, signed an agreement Sunday to co-produce passenger cars in East Germany with the Automobilwerk Eisenach company. Under the joint venture agreement, both partners said they hope to produce 150,000 Opel cars yearly at the East German company's plant at Eisenach near the West German border.
