Organizers expect half a million visitors in the fair halls, where all available display space was occupied for the first time in years. Some applicants were put on a waiting list. Fair director Siegfried Fischer said he received a rash of late applications after last fall's peaceful popular revolt, which forced out hard-line Communist leaders, opened East Germany's western border and set the economically moribund country on course for unity with its rich, powerful neighbor. West German firms are looking for East German partners to tap the country's skilled workers and gain access to what is expected to be a major consumer market. East German companies, run for 40 years under a state-controlled planned economy, are hoping for injections of Western technology and capital. Several dozen West German banks, which will provide much of the credits needed for investments in East Germany, are also plugging their services at the Leipzig fair. The banks have already begun to set up offices in East Germany. The Bonn government is hoping that private sector moves to shore up its neighbor's economy will stem the influx of worried and dissatisfied East Germans that is straining West Germany's social services.

DOC.HEAD: Skinner Sees Major Federal Role in Transportation, Despite Shift
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The federal government still will have a ``very major'' role in transportation programs, despite a Bush administration proposal that would shift more spending to the state and local level, Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner said Sunday. Skinner, whose national transportation plan last week was criticized by transport industries and some members of Congress, defended the proposed increase in user fees and local gas taxes that would raise costs for travelers and shippers. Interviewed on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press,'' Skinner said decreases in federal funding would apply primarily to projects that benefit local economies and private businesses, which would be asked to pay a greater share. ``In some parts of the system, where the local component is very important and where the cost of that system is being expanded because we have to build more facilities for that local development, we think local development can pay a bigger share,'' Skinner said. ``The federal government's role is still going to be very, very major,'' he said, adding that two-thirds of the $28 billion federal transportation budget goes for infrastructure projects. Skinner said more than 33 states already have raised gas taxes or found some independent funding source for transportation. The 9-cent federal gas tax will continue to support transportation, he said. ``We don't have a mess on our hands,'' Skinner said, referring to complaints of congestion in air and land transportation. ``We're trying to avoid a major crisis.'' Skinner predicted that within the next 10 years, the busy short-haul routes between major U.S. cities would have high-speed rail systems paid for by private developers ``who then pass the costs on to the user.'' He said commuters have indicated they are willing to pay for better service at the local level. ``That will give us more funds to expand all over the country on a national basis to deal with these pockets of congestion,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Test of Coke II Adds New Name to Soft Drink `Megabrand'
DOC.TEXT: In the beginning, there was Coca-Cola. But these days, store shelves are stocked with Coca-Cola, Coke Classic, caffeine-free Coke Classic, caffeine-free Coke, diet Coke, caffeine-free diet Coke, Cherry Coke and diet Cherry Coke. And last week, officials of the Atlanta-based soft drink maker confirmed that Coca-Cola, also known as new Coke, may be renamed Coke II. The newly named version will be test marketed later this year. If Coke II catches on, there will no longer be a drink called simply Coca-Cola. As incredible as that may seem, given the enormous power and recognition of the Coca-Cola brand name, Coke spokesman Randy Donaldson said, ``It's not a big deal to us.'' Donaldson rejected the notion that there would be no more Coca-Cola if Coke II takes off. ``We disagree,'' he said. ``There would be eight products with Coca-Cola in the name.'' Ever since the 1982 introduction of diet Coke, Coca-Cola has pursued the so-called ``megabrand'' concept of marketing its soft drinks. That approach intensified after the 1985 introduction of the reformulated new Coke, and the consumer firestorm that resulted in the return of the original formula (now called Coke Classic). Instead of selling one flagship brand, store shelves are crammed with a large family of Coke products. Coca-Cola's main competitor, Purchase, N.Y.-based Pepsico Inc., has adopted a similar approach: there currently are seven products with Pepsi Cola in the name. The numbers say the concept works, according to Jesse Meyers, publisher of the industry newsletter Beverage Digest. In 1985, Meyers said, all Coke products held 38.8 percent of the U.S. soft drink market; Pepsi's had 29.2 percent. Five years later, the Coke line _ including those, such as Sprite, that do not have ``Coca-Cola'' in the name _ has increased to 41.1 percent and Pepsi to 31.1 percent. ``Let me put that in perspective,'' Meyers said. ``Each (percentage) point is worth $444 million at retail.'' According to Donaldson, sales of products with the ``Coca-Cola'' name account for 33 percent of the soft drink market. In 1981, original Coca-Cola, then the only product with Coke in its name, had a 25 percent market share, he said. ``The segmentation in the market has taken place because the consumers have said they wanted it,'' he said. Donaldson said it is less important for there to remain a single product merely called Coke than to put the brand name to its best use by spreading it out. ``The strategy is to utilize the strongest trademark in the world and give the consumers what they want, which is to say caffeine-free, diet and cherry versions of our drink,'' Donaldson said. ``The trademark is so strong that it clearly supports a wide variety of products.'' Some analysts, including Meyers, say a successful Coke II tryout would pave the way for Coke Classic to drop the ``Classic'' from its name. Coke Classic is the best-selling soft drink, and most people who purchase it just call it Coke anyway. But Donaldson, who said one of the aims of the Coke II experiment was to diminish confusion between Coca-Cola and Coke Classic, denied such a move was being considered. Despite all the hoopla last week over the news about Coke II, the name switch is not necessarily a sure thing, said Emanuel Goldman, a soft drink industry analyst with Paine Webber Inc. in San Francisco. ``They're going to tread gently,'' Goldman said, recalling the now legendary backfire when the original Coca-Cola was replaced by new Coke. ``They don't want to add insult to injury by doing something wrong with new Coke.'' Goldman said that although new Coke is a relatively weak seller _ with 1.4 percent of the market compared to No. 1 Coke Classic's 20 percent _ it still generates about $621 million a year in retail sales for the company.

DOC.HEAD: Western Publishers Make Push into Russian-Language Magazines
DOC.TEXT: A Pennsylvania publisher plans to provide food for Soviet minds along with better-tasting sausage for Russian bodies as part of a new joint venture in the Soviet Union. Rodale Press Inc. recently announced it has teamed up with two Soviet partners to publish Russian-language magazines and books in the Soviet Union, where the government has been taking steps to encourage private enterprise. As part of the deal, the Emmaus, Pa.-based publisher of magazines such as Prevention, Runner's World and Organic Gardening, plans to contribute machinery to produce sausage and processed meats that will be sold for hard currency needed for paper and printing. It is one of the more unusual joint ventures as Western publishers move rapidly in the wake of improved U.S.-Soviet relations to produce Russian-language magazines that American advertisers can use to reach a new market. McGraw-Hill Inc.'s Business Week magazine plans to publish a Russian-language edition every other month starting in September in the Soviet Union. Reader's Digest Association Inc. is considering publishing a Russian-language edition of its flagship magazine, already available in 39 languages. VGP Inc., a Boston-based company that has previously published tourism and travel magazines, has teamed up with a Soviet partner to publish The American-Soviet Medical Market Journal. The quarterly magazine, which includes summaries of articles that have appeared in Western medical journals, was sent for free late last month to 10,000 medical research facilities, labs, physicians, scientists and public health officials in the Soviet Union. The first issue ran 44 pages with 13 pages of advertising, including sponsors such as Johnson & Johnson, Pfizer Inc. and Upjohn Co. Kompass Intercontinental Publishing, also based in Boston, recently launched two Russian-language quarterlies and plans a third for the fall. In a partnership with a Russian publisher, Kompass is distributing Moscow International Business in the Soviet Union and expects to sell 100,000 copes by subscription or at news kiosks. The first issue was 52 pages with 11 pages of advertising from both American and Russian companies. The magazine is designed to help Soviets do business with the West. Kompass also is producing Music International, a retitled version of the Russian-language magazine Music in the USSR, in a partnership with the Russian agency that brings performers into the Spoviet Union. The quarterly magazine covers classical music, and 25,000 copies are expected to be sold at Soviet newsstands. Procter & Gamble and MCA Classics Records were among the four advertisers in the first 48-page issue, according to John M. Rose, Kompass chief executive. In late summer, Kompass plans to begin publishing a Russian-language popular music magazine, Koncert, with a planned circulation of 100,000 in the Soviet Union. An English-language version will be sold here. But some advertising executives question whether buying space in Russian-language magazines makes sense since the Russian ruble is not easily converted into other currencies, many Western products are not available in Russia and circulation figures cannot be independently verified. Associate publisher Richard Mills of The American-Soviet Medical Market Journal said advertisers aren't looking for immediate sales but want ``to establish a beachhead.'' The Hewlett-Packard Medical Products Group of Andover, Mass., bought a two-page ad that explained in straightforward terms what the company does. Spokesman Joseph Laskowski said the company wanted to establish itself as ``a credible manufacturer and someone who has been supportive'' so that its salesmen can get right to business when the market is opened. Rodale's first Russian-language magazine will be a bimonthly called The New Farmer, which expects a circulation of 200,000 when it debuts this fall. It is designed mainly for the millions of people who rent small plots of land and use organic methods of farming, according to Robert Rodale, chairman of the privately-held Rodale Press. The magazine will include original material and reprints or condensations of stories from American farm magazines, he said. The original copy will be from Rodale staffers and the staff of the Russian publishing partner. The venture plans to publish a Russian-language version of Prevention magazine in 1991 and has begun translating a number of self-help and how-to books Rodale has published in the United States. But Rodale, who is interested in agricultural research and wants to replicate in Russia the Rodale research center in operation in Maxatawny, Pa., included the state farm at Kudinova as a partner in the venture as well. The farm produces about 60,000 pigs a year, but has primitive processing equipment, he said. Rodale said his company plans to buy about $250,000 in meat processing equipment for the farm, which can use it to produce higher grades of processed meats and sausage. Proceeds from the meat sales will be used to pay for publishing expenses, and Rodale said advertising sale profits will be used partly to fund the Russian agricultural research center.

DOC.HEAD: GM Launches Second Move into Europe
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. is making its second major move into Europe in a new venture with the East German manufacturer of the antiquated Wartburg, GM said Sunday. Adam Opel AG, the West Germany subsidiary of GM, signed an agreement Sunday in Leipzig, East Germany, with Automobilwerk Eisenach that puts the automaker in the midst of a nation edging away from communist economies. ``We have a good presence in Europe, now we'll have more of a presence in Eastern Europe,'' GM spokesman Jack Harned said Sunday. ``It's a very important move for GM.'' Harned confirmed the agreement was signed and said GM would release more details, such as the plant's capacity, on Monday. Opel, based in Ruesselsheim near Frankfurt, and Automobilwerk Eisenach said they hope to produce 150,000 Opel cars yearly at the East German company's plant in Eisenach near the West German border. The cars will be marketed in East Germany through the manufacturers' existing European network, Harned said. ``This has a lot to do with the unification of Germany,'' he added. Opel, which makes passenger and commercial vehicles, primarily pursued the venture with assistance from GM. ``Opel is its own business with its own major investments,'' Harned said. ``And General Motors is interested in the businesses there.'' Harned was uncertain if the Opel models would completely replace the Wartburg, an East German passenger car. ``They won't be making the Wartburg for very long as competitive cars come into the market,'' he said. Opel and AWE officials signed the agreement in the presence of East German Economics Minister Christa Luft. The ceremony coincided with the opening of the Leipzig Trade Fair, marked by a sharply increased presence of West German industrial firms. GM is already working on a $150-million investment in Hungarian automaker RABA, Hungary's state-owned manufacturer of trucks, diesel engines and axles. The plant is under construction in the city of Szentgotthard. That deal made GM the first U.S automaker to invest in Eastern Europe since recent political and economical liberalization. Volkswagen AG was the first West German automaker to engage in a joint venture in East Germany. The company is developing a modern model of the Trabant, an East German-built compact car with a two-stroke, two-cylinder engine. The automaker said it expected the Trabant plant to start production of the new model by the end of the year, producing up to 300,000 vehicles annually. Some customers have waited up to 15 years for delivery of their Trabant car. Suzuki Motor Co. was the first Japanese automaker to produce in Eastern Europe, with plans to build 15,000 cars a year in Hungary starting in 1992. Officials at Ford Motor Co. have said they were carefully watching the Eastern European market, but no negotiations were pending. Chrysler Corp. sells cars in Europe but doesn't run independent manufacturing plants there.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Industry Faces Environmental, High-Tech Challenges On 300th Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: As the paper industry celebrates its tricentennial this week, it returns to the lessons of William Rittenhouse _ America's first paper maker and in essence, the first recycler _ to set its strategy for a new era. Rittenhouse traveled the globe 300 years ago scrounging for used rags to haul back to his mill on the banks of the Wissahickson Creek outside Philadelphia. Laboriously, he beat the old rags into pulp and fashioned the nation's first sheets of paper. With his small mill, Rittenhouse planted the seed that has grown into the nation's 10th largest manufacturing industry, producing $112 billion worth of products last year ranging from puzzles and postage stamps to shoe boxes and home insulation. But as the nation's 6,400 paper plants and mills churn out 76 million tons of paper and paperboard products annually, the industry is pressured by a nation bent on recycling. Just as the electronic age two decades ago threatened to dwindle the need for paper, some have argued that recycling will drastically limit the markets for traditional paper products. But America's paper makers are beginning to prowl the nation's dumpsters for discarded paper to recycle into new products, much as Rittenhouse searched for old rags to recycle. ``We see recycling as a big opportunity,'' says Red Cavaney, president of the American Paper Institute, the trade association for makers of pulp, paper and paperboard. The Institute kicks off a three-day anniversary forum on Monday in New York. In the era of the ``green consumer,'' demand for products made of waste paper is so great that by 1995, it will lead to the ``consumption of all waste paper that can be reasonably recovered in usable condition,'' according to a new study by Franklin Associates Ltd. commissioned by the paper industry. Last month, Cavaney announced the industry intended to be part of the ``solid waste solution'' and was setting a goal of 40 percent paper recycling by 1995. Also by that year, the U.S. paper industry expects to use waste paper for 30 percent of its raw material in the production of new paper and paperboard. With total paper use expected to be just over 100 million tons by 1995, that would represent a recycling goal of about 40 million tons, according to figures supplied by the institute. Already, for example, the insides of cereal boxes are last year's recycled newspapers. Cardboard boxes containing televisions and VCRs are recycled waste paper. And before the decade is out, the drywall in people's homes could be yesterday's disposable diapers. Cavaney is counting on such innovations to meet the latest environmental challenges and carry the industry into the next century. In the 1970s, the biggest threat to the industry was thought to be the proliferation of computers, which some believed would lead to paperless offices. Instead, the demand for paper has exploded, says Hugh Hansen, a former executive with Weyerhaeuser Paper Co. The demand for printing and writing paper _ used largely for computer printouts _ increased 70 percent between 1978 and 1988, while the growth of the economy at large increased by 28 percent, according to the American Paper Institute. ``The proliferation of computers has actually spurred the need for paper rather than reduced it,'' says Hansen, president of Friends of Historic RittenhouseTown, the rural village outside Philadelphia which is the site of the nation's first paper mill. ``What seems to happen is people find more uses rather than less for paper.'' In fact, as computers cut production time to a fraction, business executives decided they needed four or five drafts of documents instead of one or two, says Cavaney. ``People still prefer to deal with paper rather than the screen on a computer,'' Cavaney says. The arrival of modern facsimile machines has spawned a growth market in thermal paper, which is expected to continue expanding.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors Oppose SEC Role in Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission already has gotten $500 million out of Drexel Burnham Lambert. So who better than the SEC to pan for more money from the drying river bed of the Wall Street firm? Well, according to the U.S. Trustee's office, the Bank of China, Bank Negara of Indonesia, Copenhagen Handelsbank and 14 other creditors are better candidates than the SEC to sit on the committee investigating the Drexel bankruptcy. The SEC, which has the largest claim against Drexel, was denied a spot on the official committee of unsecured creditors, and the goverment regulator has come up against opposition from other creditors in its appeal to join the group. The committee's goal is to recoup as much money as possible for more than 2,000 creditors. Drexel still owes the SEC $150 million of a $650 million settlement of securities fraud charges. The unpaid amount would compensate individual investors who can prove they were harmed by Drexel's actions. But the SEC was left off the committee when it was formed last month. It has filed a motion in U.S. Bankruptcy Court to gain admission, which would have to be granted by the U.S. Trustee administering the case. The creditors haven't exactly rallied to the SEC's cause. After two weeks of negotiations, creditors committee attorney Marc Kirschner said in court Friday: ``I'm not really confident this one can be resolved.'' In other words, the committee doesn't want the SEC hanging around. ``I think the creditors are distrustful of the SEC,'' said a lawyer for a large creditor not on the committee. ``I think there is a view ... that the SEC is the bad guy, the entity that brought Drexel down, and they don't want to be on the same committee as them.'' The SEC initiated the investigation of Drexel in 1987 after the firm was linked to suspicious behavior involving takeover deals. Drexel last year agreed to settle the charges by pleading guilty to six felonies and paying a $650 million fine. Drexel's business suffered because of the charges and was further hurt by a decline in the junk-bond market it helped create. The parent company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Feb. 13 after defaulting on $100 million in short-term loans and failing to obtain new credit. Drexel subsidiaries, which are not in the bankruptcy case, have liquidated tens of billions of dollars of assets since. The request by the SEC is unprecedented, bankruptcy experts say. The U.S. Bankruptcy Code prohibits government agencies from sitting on creditor panels. But an amendment permits such participation if the agency is acting on behalf of a ``person.'' The SEC argued in legal papers that it qualifies since the money it is owed by Drexel is earmarked for individual investors. A hearing on the issue is set for Tuesday. ``I have attempted to work out a compromise with the committee on this issue, and we have not been able to agree,'' SEC chief counsel Richard Kirby said. Creditors have said they will go after the $500 million Drexel already has paid the government. But Kirby said that shouldn't pose a conflict because the SEC could remove itself from discussions about the money. He added the SEC believes ``there's no claim'' to the $500 million. Creditors can seek back debt payments made up to 90 days before a bankruptcy filing or up to one year for payments to company insiders. Kirby said neither applies to the Drexel payment, which was made last September. Another reason for exclusion could be that the SEC's regulatory role would prove chilling to potential asset sales or investigations of old transactions. With the SEC in the room, some participants may be reluctant to talk about relations with Drexel. ``Our concern on the creditors committee is getting as much money from the estate as possible, not necessarily enforcing the securities regulations,'' said Steven Felderstein, attorney for the California Public Employees Retirement System. Unlike the SEC, the system was granted a non-voting role on the committee after failing to be appointed initially. On the other hand, the SEC's encyclopedic knowledge of Drexel and the securities industry could aid in scrutinizing the firm's past and present actions. The SEC has an apparent ally in U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Howard Buschman III, who said in court Friday it is ``very hard to imagine'' keeping the largest creditor off the committee, ``regardless of what hat they wear.''

DOC.HEAD: Union to Decide Pact Offer for Non-member Paperworkers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf pvs, `I think...Local 14,' to UPDATE with union withholding vote tally until Monday. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `Roy, who was...
DOC.TEXT: Members of a paperworkers' union who lost their jobs during a bitter 16-month strike against International Paper Co. voted Sunday on a contract offered to hundreds of their replacements. ``I think everybody expects the same outcome _ a `no' vote,'' said Ronald Roy, a member of the United Paperworkers International Union Local 14. Union officials said results wouldn't be released until Monday, after the union's national headquarters and the company had been notified of the results. Roy, who was recalled to his old job at the mill last week, is among 137 mill employees who are members of either the United Paperworkers union or the International Brotherhood of Firemen and Oilers, according to company officials. About 750 other members who claim rights to be rehired also were eligible to vote. Most of the roughly 1,100 hourly mill employees who would be affected by the contract were hired as replacement workers during a sometimes violent strike in this central Maine town that ended in October 1988. The work force includes about 70 former union members who crossed the picket lines during the strike. The union represents both the present and past mill workers, and all are allowed to vote. International Paper spokesman Brad Peters called Sunday's vote ``a unique set of circumstances, to some extent unprecedented.'' ``We are hopeful ... the membership will accept'' the company's offer, Peters said Sunday. Local 14 President William Meserve has said the proposed contract ``stinks.'' He declined to elaborate when asked whether the union's executive board was recommending rejection. In February, the company offered what it described as its best offer: a package retroactive to last October, providing pay raises totaling 6{ percent over three years, a company-sponsored retirement savings plan and an increase in the company's contribution to the health insurance plan. The contract would replace an open-ended pact that the company imposed unilaterally during the strike. The union continues to represent mill workers despite an effort begun two years ago before the National Labor Relations Board to have the union decertified.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Reported Injured When Shot Fired on Greyhound Bus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to RESTORE dropped first reference to union spokesman Nelson, RECAST first two grafs; DELETE byline. Pick up 10th graf, `The driver...
DOC.TEXT: A gunshot tore through a bus run by strike-beset Greyhound Lines Inc. in Florida on Sunday, showering passengers with glass and debris and injuring least seven people, authorities said. The attack apparently involved just one shot, sheriff's spokesman Steve Weintraub. Although none of the injuries appeared life-threatening, two people underwent surgery for shrapnel wounds in the throat and side, and all seven were taken to hospitals, Weintraub said. Initial reports to Greyhound were that eight were hurt, said George Gravley, a spokesman at the company's Dallas headquarters. The union representing Greyhound drivers went on strike 1{ weeks ago, and there have been scattered incidents of violence. A striking driver was crushed to death by a bus driven by a replacement driver on a picket line in Redding, Calif., earlier in the strike. There were no immediate arrests. Asked if the incident appeared strike-related, Weintraub said: ``I think it is. I don't know why anybody would want to shoot a Greyhound bus.'' Bill Nicholson, executive board member of the Jacksonville local of the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, said he doubted a striker was to blame. ``As far as I'm concerned it wasn't one of our strikers. ... They've been like choirboys,'' Nicholson said. Said Dallas union spokesman Jeffrey Nelson: ``We believe it's important for the public to understand that this is a strike against the company, not against the traveling public.'' The driver, uninjured when the shot was fired shortly before 8 p.m. EST, was able to bring the bus to a safe stop, Weintraub said. The bus, carrying 41 passengers from Jacksonville to Daytona Beach, was on U.S. Route 1 about 10 miles south of Jacksonville when the shot apparently was fired from the Interstate 95 overpass. Greyhound said earlier that buses were again running Sunday to 120 communities that hadn't been served since drivers walked off their jobs at the only nationwide bus line. The company was able to add routes to spots in the Southeast and Southwest Sunday after a new class of drivers graduated from training courses, said Greyhound spokeswoman Elizabeth Hale. The spokeswoman didn't know how many of the 9,500 communities the bus line served before the strike were being served as of Sunday night. On Saturday, Greyhound carried 38 percent of the number of passengers it did on the same Saturday a year ago and operated one-third of the number of departing buses, Ms. Hale said. Figures for Sunday would reflect the larger number of routes, but were unavailable until Monday, she said. The 120 communities had been without service since the union, which represents 6,300 drivers and more than 3,000 office and maintenance workers, went on strike March 2. Officials at the union's headquarters in Phoenix, and at offices in Dallas and Washington, D.C., didn't respond to telephone calls Sunday. Big cities had been served by Greyhound virtually since the strike began. The additions Sunday included smaller cities and small towns along routes between metropolitan areas, Ms. Hale said. ``Our goal is to rebuild our passenger service to a full national network by the end of this month,'' said Greyhound President Frank Schmieder. The expansion Sunday included two transcontinental routes, one from Washington, D.C., along a southern route to Los Angeles, and one from New York to Los Angeles along a northern route. On Saturday, federal mediators called the union to Washington for a meeting Monday. The company may be called to a separate meeting, a Greyhound negotiator said. No meeting had been set between the company and mediators as of Sunday, Ms. Hale said. Negotiations on a new three-year contract broke down March 1 and the two sides have met by telephone only a few times since.
